对于汤姆和多特·哈里斯来说，

对于生命、宇宙和一切

For Tom and Dot Harris,

for life, the universe, and everything

前言

Preface

方法

Approach

最不幸的是，人们对语言学普遍无知且心存恐惧——尤其如此，因为语言对于我们人类来说是不可言喻的基础。看看赫伯特·斯宾塞在 19 世纪（当时语言学正在取得惊人的进步）提出的这个奇怪的比较：

There is, most unfortunately, a widespread ignorance and trepidation about linguistics—peculiarly so, since language is unutterably fundamental to our humanhood. Look at this odd comparison Herbert Spencer offered in the nineteenth century (when linguistics was making spectacular advances):

印度人对英国犁的功用感到惊奇，于是他们给犁上色、竖立，并崇拜它；这样，他们就把工具变成了偶像。语言学家对语言也做了同样的事情。（1865 [1852]：33）

Astonished at the performances of the English plough, the Hindoos paint it, set it up, and worship it; thus turning a tool into an idol. Linguists do the same with language. (1865 [1852]:33)

这种比较，除了虚构了一些神话般愚蠢的印度人之外，还完全是本末倒置。语言学家会拿出扳手和螺丝刀，把犁拆开，试图弄清楚它是如何工作的。无知的人崇拜和恐惧。科学家崇拜和研究。但斯宾塞所表现出的态度——如果“语言恐惧症”这个词没有让人联想到对某些性行为或意大利面切块的恐惧，我们可能会称之为语言恐惧症——并没有减弱。继续挑英国人的毛病，我们可以引用奥伯龙·沃的话，他发现当代语言学家非常邪恶，以至于被尼安德特保守派利用：

The comparison, in addition to inventing some mythically idiotic Hindoos, has it exactly backwards. Linguists would take out their wrenches and screwdrivers, pull the plow apart, and try to figure out how it works. The ignorant worship and fear. Scientists worship and investigate. But the attitude Spencer displays—something we might call linguiphobia if that term didn’t conjure up a fear of certain sexual practices or pasta cuts—has not abated. Continuing to pick on the British, we can cite one Auberon Waugh, who finds contemporary linguists to be so evil as to play into the hands of Neanderthal conservatives:

语言学已被乔姆斯基及其信徒们贬低到令人难以置信的愚蠢和无足轻重的程度。如果 [首相] 想要找个理由关闭一所大学，她只需看看该大学的语言学系。（1988）

Linguistics [has been] reduced by Chomsky and his disciples to a positively mind-boggling level of stupidity and insignificance. If ever [the Prime Minister] wants an excuse to close down a university, she has only to look at its department of linguistics. (1988)

对于需要善意言辞的沃来说，“无知”是一个善意的词，但他的无知并非独一无二。

Ignorance is a kind word for Waugh, who is in need of kind words, but his isn’t a unique ignorance.

本书通过叙述二十世纪六七十年代一场有影响力的争论，以“科普”的方式审视语言学，试图阐明语言学家做什么、为什么做以及为什么其他人应该关心他们所做的事情。

This book—a “popular science” look at linguistics by way of narrating an influential dispute in the sixties and seventies—attempts to clarify what linguists do, why they do it, and why everyone else should care about what they do.

我希望语言学家会发现这本书很有用，因为他们中的许多人对自己近代史的看法不稳定或有偏见，但我更大的希望是非语言学家会发现一个有趣且信息丰富的描述，关于我们最深刻和最普遍的人类属性——语言的科学。

My hope is that linguists will find this book useful, since many of them have a shaky or partisan view of their own recent history, but my greater hope is that nonlinguists will find an entertaining and informative account of the science of our most profound and pervasive human attribute, language.

技术说明

Technical Notes

文本中的参考书目非常标准。引文按作者、出版年份和页码给出（通常在正文中），参考文献主要按作者和出版年份排列。（当同一作者在同一年有多个参考书目条目时，在文本和参考文献中，出版年份后面会加一个小写字母。）但有两个问题。

The bibliographical references in the text are quite standard. Citations are given by author, year of publication, and page number—usually in the main text—with the Works Cited accordingly organized primarily by author and year of publication. (A lowercase letter is suffixed to the year of publication, in the text and the Works Cited, when there is more than one bibliographical entry in the same year by the same author.) But there are two wrinkles.

首先，在感兴趣的时期，有大量地下文献流传，但只有其中一部分最终浮出水面，因此创作时间往往比出版时间更重要，我试图在这里提供一些路线图，在出版年份后加上括号，注明创作年份。例如，乔治·莱考夫 (George Lakoff) 声称“生成语义理论可能比解释理论更简单、更经济”，结果显示为“Lakoff (1976a [1963]:50)”。为了保持一致性，我也对大多数其他作者保持这种风格，有时会导致一些看起来很尴尬的引用，例如“詹姆斯 (1981 [1907])”，用于他的实用主义讲座。我唯一避免使用这种风格的作者是古人——他们更喜欢传统的“亚里士多德（修辞学1358 b）”，而不是丑陋且过于具体的“亚里士多德（1954 [c355 BC .]：32）”。

First, there was a great deal of underground literature circulating during the period of interest, only some of which eventually surfaced, so that time-of-composition is often more important than time-of-publication, and I have tried to provide a bit of a road map here by including year-of-composition, in brackets, after year-of-publication. For instance, George Lakoff’s claim that “a generative semantic theory may well be simpler and more economical than an interpretive theory” shows up as “Lakoff (1976a [1963]:50).” Consistency called for me to maintain this style for most other authors as well, leading at times to some awkward looking citations like “James (1981 [1907]),” for his Pragmatism lectures. The only authors for whom I have avoided this style are the ancients—preferring the conventional “Aristotle (Rhetoric 1358b)” to the ugly and overly specific “Aristotle (1954 [c355 B.C.]:32).”

其次，本书的研究有时会模糊地变成一个口述历史项目，产生了数百页的采访记录、数百页的信件和电子邮件打印件以及几乎同样多的电话账单。引用这些材料时——我在后面的章节中引用得相当多——根本没有引用。因此，嵌入的引用，如“用罗斯的话来说，莱考夫‘无所畏惧，绝对无所畏惧’”，如果没有进一步的归属，默认是罗斯直接对我说的话。

Second, the research for this book blurred at times into an oral-history project, generating hundreds of pages of interview transcripts, hundreds of pages more of letters and e-mail printouts, and almost as many pages of telephone bills. When quoting from this material—which I do quite extensively in the later chapters—there is no citation at all. An embedded quotation, then, like “In Ross’s terms, Lakoff ‘is fearless, absolutely fearless’,” without further attribution, is by default a remark made directly to me by Ross.

致谢

Acknowledgments

我要非常感激地感谢许多人对本书的贡献和帮助。

I would like, very gratefully, to acknowledge the contributions and assistance of a great many people to this book.

首先，我要感谢许多学者，他们对我的信件、电子邮件、电话和走廊伏击做出了善意、坦率和慷慨的回应：Dwight Bolinger、Guy Carden、Wallace Chafe、Bruce Derwing、Matthew Dryer、Joseph Emonds、Charles Fillmore、Susan Fischer、Bruce Fraser、Gerald Gazdar、Allan Gleason、John Goldsmith、Joseph Greenberg、Geoffrey Huck、Robert Kirsner、EF Konrad Koerner、Yuki Kuroda、Robin Lakoff、Judith Levi、George Miller、Stephen Murray、Greg Myers、Margaret Nizhnikov、Gary Prideaux、Geoffrey Pullum、Wallace Reid、Sally Rice、Sarah Grey Thomason、Don Walker 和 Anna Wierzbicka。

First, I thank the many scholars who responded to my letters, e-mail, phone calls, and hallway ambushes with (mostly) good will, candor, and generosity: Dwight Bolinger, Guy Carden, Wallace Chafe, Bruce Derwing, Matthew Dryer, Joseph Emonds, Charles Fillmore, Susan Fischer, Bruce Fraser, Gerald Gazdar, Allan Gleason, John Goldsmith, Joseph Greenberg, Geoffrey Huck, Robert Kirsner, E. F. Konrad Koerner, Yuki Kuroda, Robin Lakoff, Judith Levi, George Miller, Stephen Murray, Greg Myers, Margaret Nizhnikov, Gary Prideaux, Geoffrey Pullum, Wallace Reid, Sally Rice, Sarah Grey Thomason, Don Walker, and Anna Wierzbicka.

其次，我要更加感激那些抽出宝贵时间与我进行长谈的学者，他们（大多）怀着善意、坦率和慷慨：托马斯·贝弗、诺姆·乔姆斯基、杰里·福多尔、莫里斯·哈勒、雷·杰肯多夫、杰罗德·卡茨、杰伊·凯泽、库诺进、乔治·莱考夫、霍华德·拉斯尼克、罗伯特·利斯、詹姆斯·麦考利、弗雷德里克·纽迈耶、保罗·波斯特尔、哈伊·罗斯、杰罗德·萨多克和阿诺德·兹维基。

Second, and with even more gratitude, I thank the scholars who set aside valuable time to speak with me at length, also with (mostly) good will, candor, and generosity: Thomas Bever, Noam Chomsky, Jerry Fodor, Morris Halle, Ray Jackendoff, Jerrold Katz, Jay Keyser, Susumu Kuno, George Lakoff, Howard Lasnik, Robert Lees, James McCawley, Frederick Newmeyer, Paul Postal, Háj Ross, Jerrold Sadock, and Arnold Zwicky.

博林格、查菲、乔姆斯基、格里森、杰肯多夫、莱科夫、拉斯尼克、麦考利、Murray、Myers、Newmeyer、Postal、Prideaux 和 Ross 值得更多的感谢，他们阅读并评论了本书的早期部分，Victoria Bergval、Allen Fitchen、Michael Halloran、Lou Hammer、Pete Matthews、Leo Mos、Terry Nearey、Cynthia Read、Nicolette Saina 和 Jim Zappen 也值得感谢。我的编辑 Cynthia 也得到了更多的感谢，她超出了职责范围，表现得非常愉快。还要感谢 Susan Hannan、Kim Honeyford、Sylvia Moon、Jean Mulder 和 Philip Reynolds。

Bolinger, Chafe, Chomsky, Gleason, Jackendoff, Lakoff, Lasnik, McCawley, Murray, Myers, Newmeyer, Postal, Prideaux, and Ross deserve still more gratitude, for reading and commenting on various earlier bits and pieces of this book, as do Victoria Bergval, Allen Fitchen, Michael Halloran, Lou Hammer, Pete Matthews, Leo Mos, Terry Nearey, Cynthia Read, Nicolette Saina, and Jim Zappen. Cynthia, my editor, gets another large measure of gratitude for cheerfulness beyond the call of duty. Many thanks also to Susan Hannan, Kim Honeyford, Sylvia Moon, Jean Mulder, and Philip Reynolds.

当然，并不是所有人都同意这本书的内容，或者它是如何表达的，大多数人会很乐意坚持认为任何错误都是我一个人的错，但有两个人对这本书的内容有非常强烈的反对意见，需要特别注意，他们就是乔姆斯基和莱科夫。两人都对这本书的前身发表了非常广泛的评论，我发现这些评论大多非常有益，对此我非常感激，但他们都对这本书的整体安排和方向做出了非常强烈的负面反应。他们的反应基本上是相反的，莱科夫认为我站在解释语义学家一边，乔姆斯基认为我讲的是生成语义学版本，两人都觉得我轻视或忽视了他们对这场争论的印象或解释。我应该强调，他们看到的版本在很多方面都与您手中的版本大不相同，但我有理由相信他们两人都不会对这个版本感到满意（事实上，他们的不满可能会增加，因为他们认为早期版本中一些潜在的令人反感的因素在这里更直接地陈述了出来；我与他们的通信使我对一些问题的判断更加清晰，有时是朝着他们两人都不希望的方向）。事实上，乔姆斯基甚至强烈反对我在这篇序言中对他的描述；他认为他和拉科夫对这本书的反对之间没有“对称性”。我自然对他们的负面反应感到不安，但毫无疑问，我不可能同时满足他们两人；也许通过不满足任何一方，我比他们两人都更接近中立。

Not all of these people agree with what this book says, of course, or how it says what it says, and most will happily insist that any flaws are mine alone, but two people disagree so violently with the substance of this book as to require special notice, Chomsky and Lakoff. Both had very extensive comments on the same previous incarnation of the book, comments which I found mostly very profitable, and for which I remain extremely grateful, but both had very strong negative responses to the overall arrangement and orientation. Their responses were essentially inverse, Lakoff finding me to have sided with the interpretive semanticists, Chomsky finding me to have told the generative semantics version, both feeling that I slighted or ignored their own impressions or interpretations of the dispute. I should stress that the version they saw is very different in many ways from the one in your hands, but I have reason to believe that neither of them will be much more pleased with this version (their displeasure, in fact, may very well increase, since some of the latent elements that they found objectionable in the earlier version are stated a little more directly here; my correspondence with them sharpened my judgments on several matters, sometimes in directions neither of them would have preferred). Indeed, Chomsky even objects strenuously to my characterization of him in this preface; he sees no “symmetry” between his and Lakoff’s opposition to the book. I am naturally distressed by their negative reactions, but it would have unquestionably been impossible to satisfy both; perhaps by satisfying neither, I am closer to neutrality than either of them believe.

我还要感谢阿尔伯塔大学、特别是伦斯勒理工学院馆际互借人员提供的超出要求的帮助；感谢 X 女士，将纽约州未分配给高等教育的时间、金钱和复印资源用于高等教育；感谢北方贝尔研究中心的许多支持我工作的人们，特别是 Bill Hosier、John Phillips 和 Andy Sutcliffe；感谢遗产信托基金、伦斯勒理工学院、加拿大社会科学与人文研究理事会，特别是 Dorothy 和 Izaak Walton Killam 遗产的资助；感谢《语言史》、《修辞评论》、《修辞学会季刊》、《大学英语》、《词》和《修辞与意识形态》（Kneupper，1989）的编辑和出版商允许我重印本书在其他地方出版的部分内容；以及阿尔伯塔大学语言学系的教职员工和学生，他们激发了我和他们的工作之间的讨论。

I also thank the interlibrary loan people at the University of Alberta, and especially, at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, for above-and-beyond-the-call assistance; Madam X, for diverting to higher education a little time, money, and photocopying resources that the State of New York had not allocated to higher education; the many people at Bell-Northern Research who supported my work, especially Bill Hosier, John Phillips, and Andy Sutcliffe; the Heritage Trust Fund, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada, and, particularly, the estate of Dorothy and Izaak Walton Killam, for financial assistance; the editors and publishers of Historiographia Linguistica, Rhetoric Review, Rhetoric Society Quarterly, College English, Word, and Rhetoric and Ideology (Kneupper, 1989) for permission to reprint the portions of this book that have appeared elsewhere; and the staff and students of the department of linguistics, at the University of Alberta, for stimulating discussions of my work and theirs.

最后，也是最重要的，我要感谢我的妻子和引路人英迪拉·奈杜·哈里斯。

Lastly, and therefore most importantly, I thank my wife and guiding light, Indira Naidoo-Harris.

安大略省滑铁                                                       卢 RAH

Waterloo, Ontario                                                       R.A.H.

指数

Index

语言之争

THE LINGUISTICS WARS

第一章

语言、思想和语言学之争

CHAPTER 1

Language, Thought, and the Linguistics Wars

语言和我们的思维方式是密不可分的，从某种意义上来说，它们是同一个。

Language and our thought-grooves are inextricably related, are, in a sense, one and the same.

爱德华·萨丕尔

Edward Sapir

每句话都是有缺陷的——它说的比它想说的少。

每句话都是丰富的——它传达的信息比它计划的多。

Every utterance is deficient—it says less than it wishes to say.

Every utterance is exuberant—it conveys more than it plans.

何塞·奥特加·加塞特

José Ortega y Gasset

“永远不要吃超过你能举起的食物”，Miss Piggy 建议道；或者，引用不那么贪吃的 Ms. Anonymous 的话，“不要贪多嚼不烂”。抛开给这些警告增添风味的规模差异不谈，我们得到了一个非常明确的警告，它的核心是如此明显，以至于释义只会使其更加混乱。但这不是一个特别容易遵循的警告，特别是对于有趣的话题。我们正在讨论与人类嘴巴相关的最有趣的话题：意义、噪音和力量的混合，它们都包含在语言这个词中。桌上的每一口食物都带有遥远地区的味道，深沉、神秘、引人注目；甚至我们目前发现的味觉隐喻也正在向我们逼近。也许另一段话会有所帮助。

“Never eat more than you can lift,” advises Miss Piggy; or, to quote the somewhat less voracious Ms. Anonymous, “Don’t bite off more than you can chew.” Putting aside the differences of scale which give these cautions their flavor, we get a very clear warning, one whose kernel is so apparent that paraphrase only mangles it. But it’s not an especially easy warning to follow, especially for juicy topics. And we are pulling up to a spread of the juiciest topics associated with the human mouth: the commingle of meaning, noise, and power bundled into the word language. Every morsel on the table savours of faraway regions, deep, mysterious, compelling; even the gustatory metaphor we currently find closing in on us. Perhaps another paragraph will help.

语言是本书的主题和客体。它是方法和材料、产品和过程、凿子和石头——语言本身就是这样，当我们被更紧迫的事情占据时，这些点往往会悄无声息地溜走，但是语言本身就是这样，当我们最意想不到的时候，它们也会从阴影中突然出现。有时我们似乎看透了语言，听到了语言的声音，直接领悟了纸上文字之下、空中文字背后的思想；有时我们无法摆脱它。有时另一个段落会有所帮助。

Language is the subject and the object of this book. It is the method and the material, the product and the process, the chisel and the stone—points which, language being what it is, often slip noiselessly away while more immediate matters occupy us, but which, language being what it is, also lurch crashing from the shadows when we least expect it. Sometimes we seem to look right through language, hear right past it, and apprehend directly the ideas beneath the writing on the page, behind the words in the air; sometimes we can’t get it out of the way. Sometimes another paragraph helps.

有时则不然。

Sometimes not.

但贯穿整个话语的，是无限的、难以形容的微妙的纽带，它们将语言和思想联系在一起。正如

But always weaving in and out, off and on, through and through the discourse, are the infinite, indescribably subtle sinews that bind language and thought. As Miss

Piggy 和 Ms. Anonymous 表明，将想法与载体分开并非一项弱者的工作；事实上，也不是坚强者的工作。我们可以说，Miss Piggy 和 Ms. Anonymous 的表达意思相同，尽管她们的具体用词存在显著差异。我们甚至可以说，它们的意思与苏格兰谚语“如果你看不到底部，就不要涉水”相同。此外，我们可以将“相同”表述为“不要处理超出你能力范围的工作”，或者更直白地说为“不要做超出你能力范围的事情”，或者更直白地说，

Piggy and Ms. Anonymous demonstrate, separating the idea from the vehicle is not a job for the faint; nor, in fact, for the sturdy. We can say that Miss Piggy’s and Ms. Anonymous’s expressions mean the same thing, despite the significant difference in their specific words. We can even say they both mean the same thing as the Scottish proverb, “If ye canna see the bottom, dinna wade.” Moreover, we can state that ‘same thing’ as “Don’t tackle a job beyond your capacity,” or, more baldly, as “Do not do something which is not within your abilities,” or, more baldly,

∀x ∀y ¬((拥有 (你 (能力 x)) & 需要 (任务性 (能力 x)) ⊃ ¬做 (你 (任务性))。

∀x ∀y ¬((HAVE (YOU (ABILITYx)) & NEED (TASKy (ABILITYx)) ⊃ ¬DO (YOU (TASKy)).

但是，当然，我们只是在语言中移动，试图保持思想的稳定。我们并没有剥离语言来获得思想；事实上，我们在每次翻译中都会对思想进行一些扭曲。我们也可以在思想中移动，试图保持语言的稳定——通过阐明一个模棱两可的词的含义，比如bank或一个模棱两可的句子的含义，比如“罗伯托看见了图书馆里的男人”（罗伯托可能正看着图书馆的窗户，看到了那个男人，或者他可能正走在街上，看到了一个他认识的图书馆里的男人），或者一个模棱两可的话语，比如Hamlet。这里的问题在于，尽管有重要的相似之处，但bank在指你存钱的地方和指河边的土地时并不是同一个词；这两个 Roberto 句子是不一样的；你的Hamlet不是我的Hamlet。Miss Piggy 和 Ms. Anonymous 的对应问题是，尽管有重要的相似之处，但她们的思想并不相同。

But, of course, we are only moving around in language, trying to hold the thought steady. We haven’t peeled away the language to get at the thought; indeed, we’ve mangled the thought a bit with every translation. We can also move around in thought, trying to hold the language steady—by setting out the meanings of an ambiguous word, like bank or the meanings of an ambiguous sentence, like “Roberto saw the man from the library” (Roberto could be looking out the library window and see the man, or he could be walking down the street and see a man he knows from the library), or an ambiguous discourse, like Hamlet. The rub here is that, despite important similarities, bank is not the same word when it refers to a place where you keep your money and when it refers to land next to a river; the two Roberto-sentences are not the same; your Hamlet is not my Hamlet. The corresponding rub for Miss Piggy and Ms. Anonymous is that, despite important similarities, their thoughts are not the same.

语言和思想并不相同，因为它们可以部分地独立于彼此进行操纵；但仅仅是部分地进行操纵，并且只能通过故意忽略无限的、难以形容的微妙筋骨来进行。

Language and thought are not identical, since each can be partially manipulated independently of the other; but only partially, and only by willfully ignoring infinite, indescribably subtle sinews.

总会有一些东西丢失。这就引出了语言学，这门科学承担着一项艰巨的任务：解开语言和思想之间的联系。

Something is always lost. Which brings us to linguistics, the science with the unenviable task of disentangling language and thought.

并非所有语言学家都同意他们的科学描绘了语言与思想、思想与语言之间的曲折关系，甚至不同意语言学是一门科学，如果是的话，也不同意它是一门什么样的科学。这些分歧是下文中许多内容的关键主题，语言学家是一群有争议的人，这也是不可避免的结论。以本书核心故事中的剧中人物为例，这些战争发生在（曾经或现在）信奉名单上第一个人的原则的人之间：

Not all linguists would agree that their science charts the sinuous relations of language to thought, thought to language, nor even that linguistics is a science, nor, if it is, about what sort of science it is. And these disagreements are crucial themes in much of what follows, as is the unavoidable conclusion that linguists are a contentious lot. Take the dramatis personae from the story at the heart of this book, the wars fought among (one-time or still) adherents to the principles of the first man in the list:

诺姆·乔姆斯基

Noam Chomsky

雷·杰肯多夫

Ray Jackendoff

杰罗德·卡茨

Jerrold Katz

乔治·莱考夫

George Lakoff

詹姆斯·麦考利

James McCawley

保罗邮政

Paul Postal

哈吉罗斯

Háj Ross

我们刚刚给出的语言学定义与其中几个概念相矛盾。例如，Katz 和 Postal 认为语言学非常像数学，是一种纯粹的形式科学，与思想这样复杂的东西没有联系。莱科夫和乔姆斯基都认为语言学非常关注心智，是一门经验科学，但他们在许多细节上存在严重分歧，包括什么是经验科学。罗斯、麦考利和杰肯道夫都属于经验科学阵营，但在一些细节上，他们的观点介于莱科夫和乔姆斯基之间，这取决于所讨论的问题。所有这些人和问题都反复出现在语言学之争的故事中。现在，我们将通过提供一个更为传统的语言学定义来缓解人们对基本问题的不和感，几乎所有语言学家都会同意这个定义（尽管对于语言学家和大多数有反思能力的人而言，我们实际上离不开这个定义）：研究声音和意义之间的联系。

The definition for linguistics we just gave runs afoul of several of them. Katz and Postal, for instance, regard linguistics as something very much like mathematics, a pristine formal science without connection to anything as messy as thought. Lakoff and Chomsky both agree that linguistics is very much concerned with mind, and that it is an empirical science, but disagree severely on many specifics, including what it is to be an empirical science. Ross, McCawley, and Jackendoff are in the empirical science camp, but fall between Lakoff and Chomsky on various specifics, depending on the issues. All of these people and issues show up recurrently in the story of the linguistics wars. For now, we will alleviate the sense of discord over fundamental issues by offering a more conventional definition of linguistics, one that virtually all linguists would agree to (although with linguists, as with most reflective humans, we can’t do without that virtually): the study of the links between sound and meaning.

不过，有两个限定条件是立即需要的。首先，声音在这里是对语言中最容易理解的元素的简写；而意义则是对语言中最难以捉摸的元素的简写。也就是说，在这个定义中，声音包括我们发出的声音，也代表书面语言（如英语）的字母、象形语言（如中文）的字符、手语（如阿梅斯兰语）​​的手势。意义涵盖了从逻辑和语法概念（如否定和主谓关系）到含糊不清的暗示和细微差别领域（如通过对某人咆哮“这里好冷”来让他关窗，同时加强社会关系）。声音是硬通货；意义是文化和形式惯例的网络，它将意义变成糖果店里的一块口香糖。

Two qualifications, though, are immediately necessary. First, sound is something of a short-hand here for the most accessible elements of language; meaning, for the most elusive. That is, sound in this definition includes the noises we make, but also stands in for the letters of written languages (like English), the characters of pictographic languages (like Chinese), the gestures of signing languages (like Ameslan). Meaning runs the gamut from logical and grammatical concepts (like negation and subject/predicate relations) to the nebulous domains of implication and nuance (like getting someone to close the window by snarling “It’s cold in here” at her, enforcing social relations to boot). Sound is the hard currency; meaning is the network of cultural and formal conventions that turns it into a stick of gum at the candy store.

其次，替代的概念是语言学定义中一个关键但隐含的部分，因此更准确的定义应该是“研究符号声音和意义之间的联系”。火车的轰鸣声意味着你应该离开铁轨，但在这里，声音和意义是因果相关的，就像温度计读数与热量相关一样。符号——比如“小心火车！”——传达的意义更微妙、更微妙、更难以捉摸。

Second, the idea of standing-in is a critical, but implicit, part of the definition of linguistics, so much so that the definition would be more accurately rendered as “the study of the links between symbolic sound and meaning.” The clatter of a train is a sound that means you should clear off the tracks, but sound and meaning are causally related here, the way a thermometer reading is linked to heat. Symbols—like “Watch out for the train!”—carry their meaning more tenuously, more subtly, more inscrutably.

这就是语言学家们正在探究的巨大奥秘。有时，当所分析的现象像“你好”或“请递盐”或“你觉得热吗？”一样熟悉和空洞时，它看起来可能相当平凡，但它的深度不亚于对物理宇宙基本部分或生命指导原则的探索，而且它与作为人类的意义（又是这个词）有着更为密切的联系。

Such is the tremendous mystery linguists plumb. It can look pretty mundane at times—when the phenomena under analysis are as familiar and vacuous as “Hello” or “Please pass the salt” or “Hot enough for you?”—but it is every fathom as deep as the search for the fundamental bits and pieces of the physical universe or for the guiding principles of life, and it is far more intimately connected with what it means (there’s that word again) to be human.

语言学家以各种各样机会主义的方式研究语言，就像物理学家研究物质，生物学家研究生命一样，但他们的主要方法包括勘察。他们将声音和意义之间的广阔领域划分为更易于管理的区域。这些区域之间的边界经常存在争议，并取决于一些非常技术性的问题，其中只有一些在语言学之争中发挥作用，但它们的存在和主要关注点都是众所周知的。沿着传统的方向，语音学涉及语言声音的声学维度。音系学研究将这些声学特性聚集成重要的线索。形态学研究将这些线索聚集成有意义的单位。句法学研究将这些有意义的单位排列成富有表现力的序列。语义学研究这些序列的复合意义。

Linguists examine language in a variety of largely opportunistic ways, as physicists examine matter, biologists life, but among their primary methods are those of the surveyor. They carve up the vast territory between sound and meaning into more manageable provinces. The borders between these provinces are frequently in dispute and hang on some very technical issues, only some of which play a role in the linguistics wars, but their existence and their primary concerns are well established. Moving in the conventional direction, phonetics concerns the acoustic dimensions of linguistic sound. Phonology studies the clustering of those acoustic properties into significant cues. Morphology studies the clustering of those cues into meaningful units. Syntax studies the arrangement of those meaningful units into expressive sequences. Semantics studies the composite meaning of those sequences.

对于不熟悉语言学的人来说，这些定义肯定是一堆陌生且难以理解的术语。当它们与我们的故事相关时，它们就变得清晰了。但是，作为速成课程，请考虑这个句子“Fideau 追赶猫”。语音学涉及声波本身，即每当有人说出这个表达时，空气分子会发生系统性紊乱。音系学涉及波形的元素，这些元素可识别地标点声流——辅音、元音和音节，在本页上用字母表示。形态学涉及由音系元素构成的单词和有意义的子词——Fideau是一个名词，指某个杂种狗，chase是一个动词，表示一个特定的动作，既需要追逐者，也需要被追逐者，-ed是一个后缀，表示过去的动作，等等。句法涉及将这些形态元素排列成短语和句子——“追逐猫”是一个动词短语，“猫”是其名词短语（被追逐者），“菲多”是另一个名词短语（追逐者），整个句子是一个句子。语义涉及该句子表达的命题——具体而言，当且仅当某只名为菲多的杂种狗追逐了某只确定的猫时，该命题才为真。

For anyone unfamiliar with linguistics, those definitions are sure to constitute a stew of alien and undigestible terms. As they become relevant to our story, they become clear. But, as a crash course, consider the sentence, “Fideau chased the cat.” Phonetics concerns the acoustic waveform itself, the systematic disruptions of air molecules that occur whenever someone utters the expression. Phonology concerns the elements of that waveform which recognizably punctuate the sonic flow—consonants, vowels, and syllables, represented on this page by letters. Morphology concerns the words and meaningful subwords constructed out of the phonological elements—that Fideau is a noun, naming some mongrel, that chase is a verb signifying a specific action which calls for both a chaser and a chasee, that -ed is a suffix indicating past action, and so on. Syntax concerns the arrangement of those morphological elements into phrases and sentences—that chased the cat is a verb phrase, that the cat is its noun phrase (the chasee), that Fideau is another noun phrase (the chaser), that the whole thing is a sentence. Semantics concerns the proposition expressed by that sentence—in particular, that it is true if and only if some mutt named Fideau has chased some definite cat.

这些语言土地授予的细节本身并不特别重要，只是说明了语言学家将科学中特有的分而治之方法运用到的关键用途之一，但趋势应该非常明显：它们的方向是从声音到意义，从可理解到难以捉摸。我们从可观察的事物开始——咿呀作响的舌头、扰动的空气分子、振动的耳膜——然后转向意义——意义、内容、意义。语音学告诉我们语音信号的幅度、持续时间和成分频率等；语义学告诉我们人们使用语音信号来断言一只狗和一只猫；中间分支描绘了意义的发展。尽管一些语言学家对此持保留态度，但我们也毫无疑问地转向了思想。事实上，意义在其许多用途中只是思想的别名；更具体地说，它的许多用途标记了某些重要的思想子集，这些子集与人类最相关。当我对你说“我的意思是 X”时，我是在说“X”在我的脑海里，并且通过我咂舌的声音或敲击键盘的声音，我希望它也进入你的脑海里。

These details of the linguistic land grants are not especially important in and of themselves, beyond illustrating one of the key uses to which linguists put the divide-and-conquer approach endemic to science, but a trend should be very clear: their direction is from sound to meaning, from accessible to elusive. We start with the observable—clacking tongues, disturbed air molecules, vibrating ear drums—and move toward significance—meaning, content, sense. Phonetics tells us such things as the amplitude, duration, and component frequencies of the speech signal; semantics tells us people use that speech signal to make assertions about a dog and a cat; the intermediate branches chart the growth of meaning. We also move, then, despite the reservations of some linguists, unmistakably toward thought. Indeed, meaning is in many of its uses just an alias for thought; more specifically, many of its uses tag certain important subsets of thought, the ones which have the most to do with being human. When I say “I mean X” to you, I am saying that “X” is in my head and, by way of my clacking tongue or clacking keyboard, I want it to end up in your head too.

本书的核心事件——诺姆·乔姆斯基的作品、它所引发的语义叛乱以及两者对现代语言学的影响——与思想和人性息息相关。故事始于乔姆斯基令人信服的论点，即如果没有他的创新，人类行为的基本方面（例如语言创造力和语言习得）就无法实现。当他的追随者（主要是莱考夫和麦考利）将这项工作扩展到比乔姆斯基预期更深的思想领域时，它进一步发展。当乔姆斯基在其他追随者（最著名的是杰肯多夫）的怂恿下缩减了他的某些工作以消除这种扩展，否定莱考夫、麦考利及其同胞的工作时，它爆发了公开的战争。即使结局如何，也存在争议，但普遍的看法是，莱考夫和麦考利因不合理和错误而被击溃，而语言学因他们的失败而变得更好。也许吧。然而，尽管他们的运动的名称——生成语义学——在语言学正统派中已经成为一种讽刺笑话，本书的目的之一就是帮助它重新找回一些已失去的美德——但是请记住，它应该得到一些耻辱；而乔姆斯基阵营则应该得到一些荣耀。

The events at the heart of this book—the work of Noam Chomsky, the semantic rebellion it sparked, and the impact of both on modern linguistics—have everything to do with thought and being human. The story begins with Chomsky’s compelling arguments that fundamental aspects of human behavior (linguistic creativity, for instance, and language acquisition) are inaccessible without his innovations. It develops further when his followers, principally Lakoff and McCawley, extend this work much deeper into the territory of thought than Chomsky intended. And it erupts into open warfare when Chomsky, soon abetted by the work of other followers, most notably Jackendoff, retrenches aspects of his work to banish such extensions, repudiating the work of Lakoff, McCawley, and their compatriots. How it ends, even if it ends, is controversial, but the received view is that Lakoff and McCawley were routed for irrationality and error, and that linguistics is much the better for their defeat. Perhaps. But, although the name for their movement, generative semantics, has become something of a snide joke in linguistic orthodoxy, one of the aims of this book is to help it regain a bit of its lost virtue—keeping in mind, however, that it deserves some of its shame; Chomsky’s camp, some of its glory.

本书的核心事件也与边界有关；更具体地说，与边界争端有关。涉及语音学和音系学的事件在辩论中几乎没有什么进展，但形态学、句法学和语义学——与意义更直接相关的领域——都是爆发点，而且领土越接近意义的圣地，战斗就越激烈。极端的生成语义学家认为语言是一个大混战，根本没有边界，即使在原则上也是如此；声音在语言连续体的一端，意义在另一端，一小群统一的规则，没有被标记为传统语言学分支学科，将一个映射到另一个。极端的乔姆斯基阵营，即解释语义学家，是划界癖者，每天都在重新划定他们的边界；某一天，一个给定的现象是句法的，第二天是形态的；一天是语义的，第二天是句法的。双方都视对方为不正当的，并且以生动、毫不妥协的言辞表达出来。

The events at the heart of this book also have everything to do with borders; more specifically, with border disputes. The ones involving phonetics and phonology saw very little action in the debate, but those among morphology, syntax, and semantics—the provinces more directly involved in meaning—were all flash points, and the closer the territory was to the holy land of meaning, the hotter the battles. In extreme, generative semanticists argued that language was one big shmoosh, with no place at all for borders, even in principle; sound was at one end of the linguistic continuum, meaning at the other, and a small group of uniform rules, untagged as to traditional linguistic subdiscipline, mapped one into the other. In extreme, Chomsky’s camp, the interpretive semanticists, were demarcation fetishists, redrawing their borders daily; one day a given phenomenon was syntactic, the next day morphological; one day it was semantic, the next syntactic. Each saw the other side as perverse, and said so in graphic, uncompromising terms.

这种内部边界之争在很大程度上是一种理论与另一种理论之间的争论，就像云状亚原子模型与小太阳系模型之间的争论、固定大陆与漂移大陆之间的争论、达尔文进化论与拉马克进化论之间的争论一样。生成语义学希望将语言饼作为一个整体，以非侵入性的方式描述其形状和结构。解释语义学希望将其切成更易于管理的部分。但随着战斗变得更加激烈，另一场边界之争出现了，这是一场理论之外的争论，涉及整个领域的定义、语言研究的范围、语言学是什么这个问题的答案。

Such internal border disputes are largely a matter of one theory against another, much the same as a dispute between a cloud-like subatomic model and a minisolar-system model, between fixed continents and drifting ones, between Darwinian and Lamarckian evolution. Generative semantics wanted to leave the language pie pretty much as a whole, describing its shape and texture noninvasively. Interpretive semantics wanted to slice it into more manageable pieces. But as the battle became more fierce another border dispute arose, an extra-theoretical one, concerning the definition of the entire field, the scope of language study, the answer to the question, What is linguistics?

每一门科学都需要界定那些它可以合理地生成解释理论的现象。至少从赫拉克利特开始，自然界就显然处于令人眼花缭乱的变化之中，充斥着碰撞、混乱、模糊的事件；它是一个细节无限、浩瀚无垠的宇宙。我们的感官已经适应了这一点，只关注其中很小一部分事件，即与我们的生存和繁衍最相关的事件。我们只能看到某一狭窄的光频带，只能听到一小部分声音、气味和味道，只能感受到最粗糙的数据。其他一切都被我们过滤掉、忽略。科学也是做同样的事情。它们共同克服了许多物质限制，极大地增强了我们的感官，但它们的选择也比我们的感官更为独特。即使在一些目前正在研究万物理论的物理学家的奇异的总体方案中，也只涵盖最狭窄的现象；万物理论无法解释飞蛾扑火、狼向月亮咆哮、物理学家撰写资助提案等现象。它也不应该解释。科学，就像任何其他理解世界的方式一样，如果没有自我设限，就不可能存在。

Every science needs to rope off those phenomena for which it can reasonably generate explanatory theories. Nature, it has been clear since at least Heraclitus, is in dizzying flux, abuzz with colliding, chaotic, blurred events; it is a universe of infinitesimal detail and immeasurable vastness. Our senses have adapted to this by tuning to only a tiny range of those events, the ones most relevant to our survival and propagation. We see only a certain narrow band of light frequencies, hear only a small range of sound, smell and taste and feel only the grossest of data. Everything else we filter off, ignore. Sciences do exactly the same thing. Collectively they have overcome many corporeal limitations, augmenting our senses astonishingly well, but they also make even more exclusive choices than our senses. Even in the outlandishly general schemes of some physicists, currently working on a Theory of Everything, only the narrowest of phenomena would be covered; a Theory of Everything would not explain, for instance, a moth drawn to a flame, a wolf baying at the moon, a physicist writing a grant proposal. Nor should it. Science, like any other form of apprehending the world, would be impossible without its selfimposed limits.

乔姆斯基有力地论证说，在语言学中，应该在语言知识和语言使用之间划出这样的界限。想想懂得下棋和下具体棋步的区别。前者相对比较整齐——车可以横着走，也可以竖着走，象可以斜着走，骑士勾住了扣子。第二个因素取决于一系列短暂的条件——过去的动作、对手的技巧、情绪状态，甚至棋盘上的光量或观众的咳嗽声。前者可以通过一套规则全面描述。后者只能泛泛地描述，观察者永远无法准确预测。在语言中，知识在童年习得后相对稳定，尽管词汇和概念知识会增长和衰退，但使用会受到生活中所有变迁的影响——压力、分心、意识状态的改变。一个知道two和martinis发音的说话者如果因为驾驶不稳定而被拦下，可能仍会声称自己只喝了“tee martoonies”，尤其是在 20 世纪 50 年代的情景喜剧中。乔姆斯基和解释主义者认为，隔离语言学可处理问题的唯一方法是关注知识并过滤掉使用的短暂事物。

Chomsky argued forcefully that in linguistics such limits should be drawn between the knowledge of language and the use of language. Consider the difference between knowing how to play chess and making a specific move. The first is relatively tidy—the rook goes horizontally and vertically, the bishop goes diagonally, the knight does a buttonhook. The second depends on a welter of ephemeral conditions—past moves, adversarial skill, emotional state, even the amount of light on the board or the cough of a spectator. The first can be described comprehensively by a body of rules. The second can only be described broadly, and never predicted with anything approaching certainty by an observer. In language, knowledge is relatively stable after childhood acquisition, though vocablary and conceptual knowledge grow and decay, while use is subject to all the vicissitudes of life—stress, distraction, altered states of consciousness. A speaker who knows the pronunciation of two and martinis might still claim to have had only “tee martoonies” if pulled over for erratic driving, especially in a 1950s sitcom. Chomsky and the interpretivists felt the only way to isolate tractable problems for linguistics was to focus on knowledge and filter off the ephemera of use.

生成语义学家认为这种方法荒谬而武断，认为语言知识的描述与知识的应用（即使用）分离后就完全是人为的；麦考利将解释主义的形式和功能分离比作一种忽略消化的胃理论。当然，无论这些比喻多么有价值，语言既不是国际象棋也不是消化。它比国际象棋更混乱，更不精确，比消化更复杂，尽管可能没有那么混乱：将知识与使用分开并不容易。在极端情况下，生成语义学家认为没有可辩护的分离。对他们来说，对“你觉得热吗？”做出适当的回应与确保代词与其先行词相匹配的规则是一样的。在极端情况下，解释语义学家每天都在改变他们的定义。昨天的知识是今天的用途；今天的用途，明天的知识。同样，双方都只看到对方方法论倾向的扭曲。

Generative semanticists found this approach absurd and arbitrary, regarding accounts of linguistic knowledge to be completely artifactual when separated from the application of that knowledge, its use; McCawley’s analogy for the interpretivist separation of form and function was to a theory of the stomach which ignored digestion. And, of course, however worthy the metaphors, language is neither chess nor digestion. It is far messier and far less exact than chess, far more ramified than digestion, though perhaps not so messy: separating knowledge from use is not easy. In extreme, generative semantics said there was no defensible separation. Responding appropriately to “Hot enough for you?” was the same for them as a rule for making sure pronouns matched their antecedents. In extreme, interpretive semanticists shifted their definitions daily. Yesterday’s knowledge was today’s use; today’s use, tomorrow’s knowledge. Again, each side saw little more than perversion in the other’s methodological proclivities.

因此，这个故事在很大程度上是关于多少才算太多，关于语言学无法咀嚼多少。乔姆斯基指责生成语义学家贪得无厌，甚至超出了 Miss Piggy 的广泛限制，试图吞下所有可以想象到的与语言最间接相关的事物。反驳的指责是，解释语义学家只从庞大且极具挑战性的人类现象——语言中获取了保守、无味、无营养的小点心。

The story, then, is in large measure about how much is too much, about how big a bite of language is more than linguistics can chew. Chomsky charged the generative semanticists with gluttony beyond even Miss Piggy’s broad constraints, of trying to swallow every conceivable thing with the most oblique relation to language. The return accusation was that interpretive semanticists took only conservative, tasteless, nutritionless little nibbles from the immense, and immensely challenging, human phenomenon, language.

这场争论的数据包括句子及其含义等。例如，句子 1a 和 1b 在争论的初期很重要；句子 2a 在争论的最后阶段很重要。

The data of this dispute included such things as sentences and their meanings. So, for instance, sentences like 1a and 1b were important in the germinal stages of the debate; sentences like 2a, in its death throes.

1

1

a 鸬鹚岛上的每个人都说两种语言。

a Everyone on Cormorant Island speaks two languages.

 

 

b 鸬鹚岛上的每个人都说两种语言。

b Two languages are spoken by everyone on Cormorant Island.

2

2

Spiro 推测 Ex-Lax。

a Spiro conjectures Ex-Lax.

1a 和 1b 的问题和诉求非常狭隘，技术性很强，并且完全围绕着竞争理论所需的正式机制来解释它们对 Cormorant 岛民的不同影响：1a 意味着一个他们都说双语的世界，但他们说的语言可能非常多样化；1b 意味着一个他们都说同一种语言的世界（比如 Kwakwala 和英语）。句子 1a 可能在 1b 为假的情况下为真，反之亦然。围绕 2a 的问题和诉求非常广泛，相对非正式，并且围绕着比哪种理论更好更大的问题；他们问，什么是语言？什么是语言学？

The issue and appeals surrounding 1a and 1b are very narrow, highly technical, and revolve exclusively around the formal machinery required by the competing theories to explain their different implications for Cormorant Islanders: 1a implies a world where they are all bilingual, but the languages they speak might be quite diverse; 1b implies a world where they all speak the same two languages (say, Kwakwala and English). Sentence 1a could be true in circumstances where 1b was false, and vice versa. The issues and appeals surrounding 2a are very wide, relatively informal, and revolve around much bigger questions than which theory is better; they ask, What is language? and What is linguistics?

当这些问题浮出水面时，解释语义学家和生成语义学家的差异已经超出了“争论”这个术语的范围。最初只是乔姆斯基语言学内部对一个假设的小型分歧，但后来却发展成为具有根本性的分歧。双方都非常清楚地看到了 1a 和 1b 的相关性，也都看到了解决方案。但是，多年来这些句子和 2a 之间的激烈争论和分歧改变了他们的看法。解释语义学家甚至不把 2a 看作数据，并将另一阵营对它的引用视为他们不再从事语言学研究的确凿证据；生成语义学家将 2a 视为“实验十字架”的关键，并认为另一阵营对它的驳斥是的确凿证据，表明他们所实践的语言学非常贫乏和空洞，以至于他们的工作完全是空洞的。甚至 2a 中的政治和异想天开的元素也显示出昔日伙伴之间日益加深的鸿沟。

By the time these questions surfaced, the interpretive-generative semantics differences had outgrown and exhausted the term debate. What began as a compact, in-house disagreement over a single hypothesis within Chomskyan linguistics had mushroomed into foundational proportions. Both sides saw the relevance of 1a and 1b very clearly, and both sides saw a resolution within reach. But the years of acrimony and diverging arguments between those sentences and 2a had altered their vision. Interpretive semanticists didn’t even see 2a as data, and regarded its invocation by the other camp as clear and damning evidence they were no longer doing linguistics; generative semanticists saw 2a as the crux of an experimentum crucis, and saw its dismissal by the other camp as clear and damning evidence that they were practicing a brand of linguistics so sterile and navel-contemplative that their work was completely hollow. Even the political and whimsical elements of 2a chart the chasm that had grown between the erstwhile companions.

简而言之，尽管这些术语并不特别简单，但分歧存在于共识与分歧之间。当 1a 和 1b 与我们的故事相关时，所有争论者都对其含义以及语言学应该成为什么样的事业达成了高度一致；但对于 2a，几乎没有人达成一致，以至于争论者几乎不予采纳。但这幅图只捕捉到了冲突最粗略的形象，即墙上的阴影。在 60 年代中期，在双语言句子中，解释语义学家和生成语义学家当然对如何研究语言达成了一致，但他们与他们的直接前辈意见不一致。到 70 年代中期，随着 Spiro 的泻药猜想，他们彼此意见不一，但现在生成语义学家开始与前乔姆斯基语言学家找到一致之处。这种不断变化的共识基础——也就是历史——不仅构成了解释语义学和生成语义学之争的决定性背景，而且构成了语言研究的所有为什么、是什么和如何的决定性背景。乔姆斯基和他以前的门徒之间的分歧所体现的问题，可以追溯到几个世纪以来的其他争议、其他的同意和反对群体，可以追溯到对语言的最早研究，可以追溯到语言学和科学的诞生，所有这些我们稍后都会谈到。

Simply put, the chasm stretched between consensus and dissensus, although these terms are not particularly simple. When 1a and 1b were relevant to our story, all the arguers agreed closely about their implications, and about what sort of enterprise linguistics should be; with 2a, there was so little agreement that arguers hardly applies. But this picture only catches the grossest image of the conflict, the shadows on the wall. In the mid-sixties, with the two-languages sentences, interpretive and generative semanticists agreed with one another about how to study language, certainly, but they disagreed collectively with their immediate predecessors. By the mid-seventies, with Spiro’s laxative conjecture, they disagreed with one another, but now the generative semanticists began to find points of agreement with pre-Chomskyan linguists. This shifting ground of agreements—that is, history—forms not only the defining backdrop for the interpretive-generative semantics dispute, but for all the whys, whats, and hows of language study. The issues which crystallized in the divergences of Chomsky and his former disciples echo back through the centuries to other controversies, other clusters of assent and dissent, back to the earliest investigations of language, back to the birth of linguistics, and science, all of which we will get to anon.

不过，在我们这样做之前，Spiro 仍然在讨论之中，我们应该把他排除在外：2a 的核心是，它在孤立的情况下毫无意义（解释语义学家一直喜欢他们的句子的方式），但在上下文中却完全没有问题（生成语义学家逐渐喜欢他们的句子的方式）；也就是说，作为对 2b 中问题的回答。

Before we do, though, Spiro is still on the table, and we should clear him away: the nub of 2a is that it is hopelessly nonsensical in isolation (the way interpretive semanticists always preferred their sentences), but is perfectly fine in context (the way generative semanticists grew to prefer their sentences); namely, as a response to the question in 2b.

2

2

b 有人知道帕特·尼克松用什么给她的蛋糕抹糖霜吗？

b Does anyone know what Pat Nixon frosts her cakes with?

第 2 章

语言学

CHAPTER 2

Linguistics

广义上讲，语言学是包含所有与语言有关的实证研究的科学分支。

Linguistics, in the widest sense, is that branch of science which contains all empirical investigations concerning languages.

鲁道夫卡尔纳普

Rudolph Carnap

简单来说，在人类的言语中，不同的声音具有不同的含义。研究特定声音与特定含义之间的这种协调就是研究语言。

To put it briefly, in human speech, different sounds have different meanings. To study this co-ordination of certain sounds with certain meanings is to study language.

伦纳德·布卢姆菲尔德

Leonard Bloomfield

语言科学

The Science of Language

语言学，简明扼要但并非毫无争议，是一门关于语言的科学。如果需要，可以使用各种迂回的说法，但毫无疑问，语言是研究的对象，科学最能体现几乎所有研究过该对象的人共同的研究精神，这种研究方式（无论是现在还是回顾）都符合语言学这一术语。研究语言的其他方法有很多，包括诗学、语言学和修辞学，但自从英语中有语言学这个词以来，语言学就一直与科学的方法、目标和结果联系在一起。1当威廉·惠威尔（他也是创造“科学家”一词的人）首次提出这一术语时，是在他的《归纳科学史》（1837.1：cxiv；他是从德国人那里借来的，而德国人，颇具日耳曼特色，后来更喜欢使用“语言科学”这个词）。

Linguistics is, concisely but not uncontroversially, the science of language. There are various circumlocutions available, if necessary, but language is unquestionably the object of study, and scientific best captures the spirit of investigation common to almost everyone who has examined that object in a way that (currently or retrospectively) fits the term, linguistic. Other approaches to studying language, and there are many, go by names like poetics, philology, and rhetoric, but as long as we have had the word in English, linguistics has been associated with the methods, goals, and results of science.1 When William Whewell (who is also responsible for the coinage, scientist) first proposed the term, it was in his History of the Inductive Sciences (1837.1:cxiv; he was borrowing it from the Germans, who, Teutonically enough, later came to prefer Sprachwissenschaft).

归根结底，语言学是否适合科学范畴（或者，用更符合二十世纪科学魅力的说法，语言学是否值得成为科学）是一个相当琐碎的问题。显然，语言学家有充分的理由效仿物理学、化学和生物学等学科的工作者——这些学科是典型的科学。物理学家、化学家和生物学家取得了巨大的成功，产生了大量关于自然界的成果。

Ultimately, the matter of linguistics’ fit to the category of science (or, in terms more befitting the charismatic power of science in the twentieth century, the matter of linguistics’ merit for the status of science) is a pretty trivial one. Clearly there are compelling reasons for linguists to emulate workers in disciplines like physics, chemistry, and biology—the prototypical sciences. Physicists, chemists, and biologists have been immensely successful, producing vast quantities of results about the natural world.

语言学和其他科学之间也存在一些惊人的相似之处，相似性越强，语言学就越接近这些追求方法、目标和结果越准确，我们就越有信心给它贴上“科学”的标签。

There are also some striking parallels between linguistics and these other sciences, and the stronger those parallels are—the closer linguistics is to these pursuits in methods, goals, and results—the more confidence we have in giving it the label, science.

但更重要的是，每个知识领域都需要一定程度的完整性，同样有令人信服的理由让我们不要过于密切或盲目地模仿这些领域。必须让研究对象引导分析，音节不是夸克。意义不是分子。句子不是肝脏。

But, more crucially, each intellectual domain requires a certain measure of integrity, and there are equally compelling reasons not to emulate these fields too closely or too blindly. The object under investigation must be allowed to guide the analysis, and a syllable is not a quark. A meaning is not a molecule. A sentence is not a liver.

语言学也不需要科学的名义支持。它是一种系统的、寻求真理的、创造知识的事业，只要它通过提出关于语言的结果来获得知识，这个标签就不是那么重要。词源学在这方面很有帮助：科学是拉丁语中知识一词的后裔，只有知识才是重要的。

Nor does linguistics need the nominal blessing of science. It is some sort of systematic, truth-seeking, knowledge-making enterprise, and as long as it brings home the epistemic bacon by turning up results about language, the label isn’t terribly important. Etymology is helpful in this regard: science is a descendant of a Latin word for knowledge, and it is only the knowledge that matters.

然而，话虽如此，确实存在一系列的方法、目标和结果，将文学批评、哲学和历史等追求置于知识创造追求连续体的一端，将物理学、化学和生物学置于另一端。由于缺乏更好的术语，我们可以将批评和哲学端称为人文学科。由于缺乏更好的术语，我们可以将物理学和化学端称为科学。将语言学定义为“语言的科学”承认了它更接近物理学端而不是批评端。它的方法、目标和持久的结果来自于长期以来将语言视为自然对象的传统——有时是社会对象，有时是心理对象，有时两者兼而有之，但始终是可以观察到的东西，如星星和岩石，有时是可以被戳的东西，如动物和植物。

Having said all that, however, there is certainly a range of methods, goals, and results that places such pursuits as literary criticism, philosophy, and history at one end of a continuum of knowledge-making pursuits; physics, chemistry, and biology at the other. For lack of a better term, we can call the criticism and philosophy end humanities. For lack of a better term, we can call the physics and chemistry end sciences. And defining linguistics as “the science of language” acknowledges that it falls much closer to the physics end than the criticism end. Its methods, goals, and resilient results come from a long tradition of treating language as a natural object—sometimes a social object, sometimes a mental object, sometimes both, but always as something which could be observed, like the stars and the rocks, and sometimes poked, like the animals and the plants.

声音与意义

Sound and Meaning

语言是一种无形的东西，它通过声音来表达意义，而声音是一种物质的东西。

Speech is meaning—an incorporeal thing—expressed in sounds, which are material things.

恩斯特·卡西尔

Ernst Cassirer

尽管对语言的正式研究至少可以追溯到阿卡德人，而且肯定存在篝火语言学——弗雷德和巴尼一定有某种谈论谈话的方式，否则他们使用的就不是语言了——但时间的长河已经抹去了前希腊时期的所有痕迹，只留下了极少的痕迹。我们可以从斯多葛学派开始，除了其他活动外，他们系统地研究了语言作为自然界的一个对象。他们是哲学家、修辞学家、政治学家和众所周知的硬汉宿命论者，但他们也是语言学家。

Although the formal study of language dates at least back to the Akkadians, and there was surely campfire linguistics—Fred and Barney must have had some way of talking about talking, or what they were using wouldn’t have been language—the winds of time have erased all but a very few vestiges of pre-Hellenic work. We can start with the Stoics, who, among their other activities, systematically investigated language as an object in the natural world. They were philosophers, and rhetoricians, and political scientists, and proverbial tough-guy fatalists, but they were also linguists.

语言学家对语言本身感兴趣，就像物理学家对物质感兴趣，生物学家对生命感兴趣一样。这种说法虽然简单，但实际上与许多语言学家的既定目标相冲突，包括我们故事中占据中心位置的几位语言学家。诺姆·乔姆斯基尤其直截了当地说，他很少关心语言本身；从来没有，也永远不会。他最关心的是心理结构，语言是他了解思想的最有力的工具。如今，大多数语言学家都追随乔姆斯基的脚步。例如，乔治·莱考夫的主要著作的副标题是《分类揭示了思想》，在计算机科学系工作的雷·杰肯多夫认知科学的分支学科有一篇名为《语义学与认知》的文章；总体而言，语言学家现在将他们的学科视为心理学的一个分支。然而，在本世纪的大部分时间里，语言学家的忠诚度截然不同，他们将他们的学科视为文化人类学的一个分支。更早的时候，许多语言学家有着坦率的神学目标——19 世纪的历史语言学家追求一种“纯粹的”亚当语言，从伊甸园一直到宁录塔倒塌，中世纪的莫迪斯泰人用语言来绘制隐藏的创造结构。

Linguists qua linguists are interested in language in and of itself, the way a physicist is interested in matter, or a biologist in life. This statement, as simple as it is, actually conflicts with the stated goals of a great many linguists, including several who take center stage in our story. Noam Chomsky, in particular, says flatly and often that he has very little concern for language in and of itself; never has, never will. His driving concern is with mental structure, and language is the most revealing tool he has for getting at the mind. Most linguists these days follow Chomsky’s lead here. The subtitle of George Lakoff’s major book, for instance, is What Categories Reveal about the Mind, and Ray Jackendoff, who works in a department of cognitive science, has one entitled Semantics and Cognition; in general, linguists regard their discipline now as a branch of psychology. For most of this century, though, linguists had quite different allegiances, seeing their discipline as a branch of cultural anthropology. Earlier yet many linguists had frankly theological goals—historical linguists in the nineteenth century were after the one “pure” Adamic language, spoken from Eden to the collapse of the Nimrod’s tower, and the Medieval Modistae used language to map the hidden structures of creation.

但是，当然，科学家在研究更直接的数据和理论时，几乎总是怀有远大的目标，尤其是宗教目标。开普勒、牛顿和爱因斯坦等天体物理学家试图揭示上帝在自然界中的运作方式，卡普拉和祖卡夫等对上帝和自然有着截然不同看法的近代物理学家也是如此；即使是教会最大的恶魔——伽利略和达尔文——也将他们的研究描绘成自然神学的分支，揭示了上帝手艺的微妙和美丽。准世俗动机也受到科学家的欢迎，尤其是在本世纪，比如高能物理学家寻找时间的起点或最微小的物质，或者分子生物学家寻找生命的秘密。然而，无论他们的最终动机是什么，物理学家研究物质，生物学家研究生物，地质学家研究岩石。这就是他们获取数据的地方，也是他们试图用理论解释的地方。语言学家研究语言。他们从那里获取数据，并试图用他们的理论来解释。

But, of course, scientists almost always hold distant goals while they work on more immediate data and theories, especially religious goals. Astrophysicists like Kepler and Newton and Einstein were trying to uncover the workings of God in nature, as are more recent physicists with much different notions of God and nature, like Capra and Zukav; even the church’s biggest bogey men—Galileo and Darwin—portrayed their research as branches of natural theology, revealing the subtlety and beauty of God’s handiwork. Quasi-secular motives are also popular with scientists, particularly in this century, like high-energy physicists looking for the beginning of time or the tiniest bits of matter, or molecular biologists looking for the secret of life. Whatever their ultimate motives, though, physicists look at matter, biologists look at organisms, geologists look at rocks. That is where they go for their data, what they seek to explain with their theories. Linguists look at language. That is where they go for their data, what they seek to explain with their theories.

最常被引用的语言学定义（本节开头的一个版本）称语言是一条从声音到意义的路径，称语言学是对这条路径的探索。斯多葛学派是第一个正式确定这条路径的两个端点的人，“区分‘能指’和‘所指’”（Robins，1967：16），这是一个极其基本的见解，也是语言学的第一原则。科学的语言方法已被证明更有利于探索分裂的声音方面（能指），包括将声音排列成单词和句子。分裂的意义方面（所指）一直笼罩在猜测之中，许多最重要的贡献来自哲学家，但语言学家一直认为了解所指的前景非常诱人。斯多葛学派也是第一个在意义研究中确定不同领域的人——语音学、形态学和句法学。

The most frequently invoked definition of linguistics, a version of which begins this section, calls language a path running from sound to meaning, and calls linguistics the exploration of that path. The Stoics were the first to formalize the two end points of this path, “distinguishing between ‘the signifier’ and ‘the signified’” (Robins, 1967:16), an utterly fundamental insight, the first principle of linguistics. The scientific approach to language has uniformly proved more valuable for exploring the sonic side of the split (the signifier), including the arrangement of sounds into words and sentences. The meaning side of the divide (the signified) has remained shrouded in speculation, and many of the most substantial contributions have come from philosophers, but linguists have always found the prospect of getting at the signifieds very compelling. The Stoics were also the first to identify distinct areas within the study of signification—phonetics, morphology, and syntax.

这些都是重大进步，确立了语言学作为一门独立学科的参数，而这些进步的关键显然与希腊在宇宙学和力学方面取得进步的关键相同：抽象。语言与意识、理性和人性密切相关，许多思想家难以抽离出来，从一般而不是具体的角度来看待语言。但斯多葛学派蓬勃发展的时候，希腊语使用者和非希腊人之间的接触正在增加；事实上，斯多葛学派领袖（芝诺）的第一语言就是闪米特语。这种接触迫使斯多葛学派认识到，单词的声音或句子模式本身并不具有任何含义。chien 、Hund或dog的声音本身并不会使人联想到忠诚的、吠叫的四足动物；相反，正如斯多葛学派发现的那样，能指和所指之间的联系是惯例、共识和理性的产物。

These were major advances, establishing the parameters of linguistics as an autonomous pursuit, and the key to these advances was clearly the same as the key to Greek advances in cosmology and mechanics: abstraction. Language is so intimately tied to consciousness, reason, and being human, that it is difficult for many thinkers to detach themselves to the point where they can look at it in general rather than specific terms. But the Stoics flourished at a time when contacts between Greek speakers and non-Greeks were on the rise; indeed, the head Stoic’s (Zeno) first language was Semitic. This exposure forced the Stoics to realize that there was nothing inherent to the sound of a word or the pattern of a sentence which carried the meaning. There is nothing inherent in the sound of chien, or Hund, or dog, that evokes a loyal, barking quadruped; rather, as the Stoics found, the links between signifier and signified are the product of convention, consensus, and reason.

斯多葛学派还参与了一场关于语言的重要争论，这场争论历史学家用类比和异常这两个词来标记语言。类比论者认为语言是有序和有规律的，而异常论者则认为语言更加随意，尤其是在意义领域。辩论的参与者并没有把问题切得如此干净，直到公元前一世纪瓦罗重新审视这些问题之前，这些问题都没有得到非常精确的划分。历史对这场争论并不感冒，原因也不难理解。罗素告诉我们：“科学的任务是寻找一致性”（1967 [1912]：35），因此认为语言从根本上是随意的，就等于放弃科学。如果秩序是虚幻的或肤浅的，那么寻找模式——系统化、分类或抽象——就毫无意义。事实上，在一个完全独特的物体的世界中，抽象是不可想象的；更重要的是，这样的世界本身也是不可想象的，因为我们的大脑从根本上就是模式检测器。

The Stoics also participated in an important controversy about language, which historians tag with the words analogy and anomaly. The analogists saw language in terms of order and regularity; the anomalists saw it as far more haphazard, particularly in the domain of meaning. The participants in the debate did not cut the pie this cleanly, and the issues were not even delineated very precisely until Varro reexamined them in the first century B.C. History has not treated this dispute with much sympathy, and it is easy to see why. “The business of science,” as Russell tells us, “is to find uniformities” (1967 [1912]:35), so the position that language is fundamentally haphazard is tantamount to abandoning science. If order is illusory or superficial, there is no point in looking for patterns—in systematizing, or classifying, or abstracting. Indeed, abstraction is unthinkable in a world of totally unique objects; more importantly, such a world is itself unthinkable, since our brains are fundamentally pattern detectors.

奇怪的是，斯多葛学派基本属于异常论阵营。但这些立场既不僵化也不绝对——相反，它们是“对语言的两种态度，每种态度本身都合理地由部分证据证明”（Robins，1967：19）——斯多葛学派对过度概括、忽略数据并试图规定用法的类比论者做出了反应。斯多葛学派是经验主义者，对语言的复杂性有着健康的尊重——他们进步的一个重要基石是拒绝将一个词简单地等同于一个含义。他们也不像类比论者那样关心语言“纯粹性”的问题，因此对方言变化更加宽容。随着语言中更多规律的发现，例如屈折词素与语义上更重、更具个性的派生词素之间的关键区别，以及对意义的普遍忽视，争论逐渐平息。简而言之，这场争论悄然地以有利于类比论者的立场结束，尽管这场争论在语言学的几乎每一个部门辩论中都一再爆发，并且在生成性语言学—解释性语言学的分裂中扮演着特别关键的角色，当一个阵营沉迷于语义问题并深入探究语言的无序性和混乱性时，另一个阵营则安全地停留在表面附近。

The Stoics, curiously enough, were pretty much in the anomalist camp. But the positions were neither rigid nor absolute—rather, they were “two attitudes to language, each in itself reasonably justified by part of the evidence” (Robins, 1967:19)—and the Stoics were reacting to analogists who over-generalized, ignored data, and attempted to prescribe usage. The Stoics were empirical, with a healthy respect for the complexity of language—an important cornerstone of their advances was rejecting the simple equation of one word with one meaning. They were also less concerned than the analogists with issues of linguistic “purity,” and correspondingly more tolerant of dialectal variation. The dispute subsided with the discovery of more regularities in language, such as the critical distinction between inflectional morphemes and the semantically heavier, more idiosyncratic, derivational morphemes, and with the general neglect of meaning. In short, it was settled, quietly, in favor of the analogists, though it has flared up consistently in virtually every other divisional debate in linguistics, and it plays an especially critical role in the generative-interpretive schism, when one camp became consumed with semantic questions and pursued language deep into irregularity and chaos while the other stayed safely near the surface.

一个关键术语——形式——在讨论中多次出现，它标志着我们需要从希腊人那里吸取的最后一个标准教训。对于一些语言学家来说，形式这个词听起来很刺耳（主要是反对乔姆斯基方案的语言学家，尽管其他人指责他不够形式化），但它对语言学和任何科学来说都是绝对必要的，它只意味着编码的抽象。例如，/str/ 是抽象声音字符串的表示，string 的发音就是一个例子。string是英语正字法形式系统中的一种表达。“NP + VP”是一种形式表达，它代表了前一个句子的句法结构（因为它包含一个名词短语，后面跟着一个动词短语）。等等。希腊人探索了语言的抽象编码，改编了腓尼基字母表，并用它将相对连续的语音声波分割成离散的句子、短语、单词、词素和音素。

A crucial term—formal—has snuck into the discussion in several places, and it signals the last criterial lesson we need to take from the Greeks. Formal has a nasty ring about it for some linguists (mostly linguists opposed to Chomsky’s program, though others attack him for not being formal enough), but it is absolutely essential to linguistics, as it is to any science, and means nothing more than codified abstraction. For instance, /str/ is a representation of an abstract sound string, an instance of which occurs in the pronunciation of string. String is an expression in the formal system of English orthography. “NP + VP” is a formal expression which represents the syntactic structure of the previous sentence (since it contains a Noun Phrase followed by a Verb Phrase). And so on. The Greeks explored the abstract codification of language, adapting the Phonecian alphabet and using it to carve up the relatively continuous acoustic waveforms of speech into discrete sentences, phrases, words, morphemes, and phonemes.

希腊人、罗马人和中世纪早期的语法后裔都十分关注语言的声音（和图形）方面，但当古典语法在中世纪晚期遇到独特的亚里士多德思想时，语言研究就急剧转向了更为晦涩难懂的问题被称为经院哲学。用现代术语来说，由此产​​生的综合体可能更接近于人文学科之一的哲学，而不是自然科学，但用当时的术语来说，莫迪斯泰是严谨科学的，而且和哲学一样，与形式科学逻辑有重要的联系。他们的名字来自一部名为《意义模式》的代表性著作集，意义是他们关注的主要问题，但他们更感兴趣的是事物存在的方式、我们构想它们的方式和名义上的意义模式（我们表达它们的方式）之间的联系：简而言之，就是现实、思想和语言之间的联系。

The Greeks stayed pretty close to the sonic (and graphic) aspects of language, as did their Roman and early Medieval grammatical descendants, but the study of language veered sharply off toward more obscure matters when classical grammar met up with the unique brand of Aristotelian thought in the high Middle Ages known as Scholasticism. In modern terms, the resulting synthesis is probably closer to one of the humanities, philosophy, than to natural science, but in the terms of the period the Modistae were rigorously scientific, and, also like philosophy, had significant ties to a formal science, logic. They got their name from a collection of representative writings entitled De Modis Significandi, and significance was their defining concern, but they were more generally interested in the threads weaving among modi essendi (the ways things are), modi intellegendi (the ways we conceive them), and the titular modi significandi (the ways we express them): in short, among reality, thought, and language.

“在语言学史上，没有比这个更古老的思想了，”Pieter Seuren 写道，“即在句子的表面之下隐藏着一种形式或结构，它提供了语义分析并揭示了它们的逻辑结构”（1973 [1971]：528）；随着莫迪斯泰的出现，这种思想成为了驱动力。莫迪斯泰语法的最大特点是将形式逻辑系统地扩展到语言研究，并采用了亚里士多德对因果关系的关注。在大多数智力追求中，情绪波动是典型的，莫迪斯泰人对他们的前辈大加指责，指责他们没有深入研究原因，在需要解释时只满足于分类。

“No idea is older in the history of linguistics,” Pieter Seuren writes, “than the thought that there is, somehow hidden underneath the surface of sentences, a form or a structure which provides a semantic analysis and lays bare their logical structure” (1973 [1971]:528); with the Modistae, this thought became the driving concern. Modistic grammar is best characterized by the systematic extension of formal logic to the study of language, and by the adoption of Aristotle’s preoccupation for causation. In a mood swing typical of most intellectual pursuits, the Modistae jumped all over their predecessors for not looking deeply enough into causes, with settling for mere taxonomy when explanation was required.

他们严格的演绎方法所导致的一般解释让现代人觉得有些神秘——语言背后有一种普遍的语法，它“依赖于现实的结构”（Bursill-Hall，1971：35）——但这种立场的后果才是有意义的。与古人相比，莫迪斯泰人更关心抽象语言的一般原则（古人倾向于寻找个别语言的一般原则，尤其是希腊语）。例如，罗杰·培根说，有些问题只存在于特定语言中，有些问题存在于所有语言中，只有后者才具有科学意义。作为这种方法的自然延伸，他们得出的结论是，所有语言本质上都是相同的，“它们之间的表面差异只是偶然的变化”（Robins，1967：77），我们将再次看到这种立场。在该领域的标准定义模式中，语言学被视为对能指和所指之间联系的研究，莫迪斯泰人对链条所指端的联系比对能指的偶然变化更感兴趣。事实上，他们将所有与声音直接相关的问题完全排除在语法研究范围之外。

The general explanation to which their rigid deductive methodology led strikes moderns as somewhat mystical—that there is a universal grammar underlying language which is “dependant on the structure of reality” (Bursill-Hall, 1971:35)—but it is the consequences of this position that are relevant. The Modistae were far more concerned with abstracting general principles of language than the ancients (who tended to look for general principles of individual languages, particularly Greek). Roger Bacon, for instance, said that there were problems specific to a given language, and problems common to all languages, and only the latter were of scientific interest. As a natural extension of this approach, they came to the position that all languages were in essence the same, and “that surface differences between them are merely accidental variations” (Robins, 1967:77), a position we will see again. In the standard definitional schema of the field, which sees linguistics as the investigation of links between the signifier and the signified, the Modistae were a great deal more interested in the links at the signified end of the chain than in the accidental variations of the signifiers. Indeed, they ruled all matters directly concerning sound completely out of the realm of grammatical study.

经院哲学家们自己也遭受了相当剧烈的情绪波动。他们被日益增长的对实证研究和数学建模的关注赶出了知识界，而这些关注标志着现代科学的开端，莫迪斯泰的工作也基本被遗忘了。例如，Jespersen 的语言史调查用两句话就否定了整个中世纪 (1922:21)，而莫迪斯泰语法对现代语言学几乎没有直接影响，除了一些术语残余。但它的间接影响是巨大的：乔姆斯基年轻时就研究过莫迪斯泰，这一点显而易见。莫迪斯泰语法也对文艺复兴时期的语言哲学家产生了影响，尤其是波特-罗亚尔学派，乔姆斯基热情地承认它是他的纲领的思想先驱。

The scholastics were the victims of a rather violent mood swing themselves. They were driven from the intellectual scene by the increased concern for empirical research and mathematical modeling that marks the beginnings of modern science, and the work of the Modistae was largely forgotten. Jespersen’s survey of linguistic history, for instance, dismisses the entire Middle Ages in two sentences (1922:21), and Modistic grammar had very little direct influence on modern linguistics, aside from some terminological remnants. But its indirect influence is substantial: Chomsky studied the Modistae as a young man, and it shows. Modistic grammar also had an impact on Renaissance philosophers of language, especially the Port-Royal school that Chomsky has warmly acknowledged as an intellectual forerunner of his program.

语言学史上的下一个关键步骤，也是普遍采取的“现代语言学”出现的标志是著名的孟加拉首席大法官威廉·琼斯 (William Jones) 在 1786 年第三次向皇家亚洲学会发表的年度演讲，他在演讲中提出梵语、拉丁语和希腊语都是“某个共同来源，但这个来源也许已不复存在”的后代，而哥特语和凯尔特语可能有相似的根源。当时，人们对梵语已经进行了大量研究；关于分类、亲缘关系和假设来源的争论已经展开，甚至有人提出梵语、拉丁语和希腊语有一个共同来源。但琼斯的论文对于历史研究来说是一个方便的结晶，因为它将所有这些线索汇集到一个简洁的讨论中；很长一段时间以来，人们甚至普遍将琼斯的论文视为语言研究前科学时期和科学时期的分水岭。2琼斯的演讲中达到顶峰的研究工作迅速发展成为被称为比较语言学的范式。

The next critical step in the history of linguistics, and the one generally taken to mark the emergence of “modern linguistics” comes with the famous chief justice of Bengal, William Jones, in his 1786 Third Annual Discourse to the Royal Asiatic Society, in which he suggested that Sanskrit, Latin, and Greek were all the descendants of “some common source, which, perhaps, no longer exists,” and that Gothic and Celtic might have similar roots. There had already been substantial work done on Sanskrit; there had been debate about classification, genetic relations, and hypothetical sources, and the proposal of a common source for Sanskrit, Latin, and Greek had even been advanced. But Jones’s paper is a convenient crystallization for historical purposes, because it draws all these threads into a succinct discussion; it was even commonplace for quite some time to view Jones’s paper as the dividing point between the pre-scientific and scientific periods of language study.2 The work which came to a head in Jones’s address rapidly hardened into the paradigm known as comparative linguistics.

比较法非常简单，但其结果往往取决于惊人的勤奋和惊人的知识广度。语言学家只需仔细观察一种语言中的声音和意义包与另一种语言中的声音和意义包的相似之处，并找出相似之处的解释。这个过程与其他观察科学（如天文学和古生物学）的过程完全相似；事实上，Kiparsky（1974）称其从业者为古语言学家。

The comparative method was extremely simple, though its results frequently depended on staggering diligence and an astonishing breadth of knowledge. Linguists just looked closely for packages of sound and meaning in one language which were similar to packages of sound and meaning in another language and worked out explanations for the similarities. The process is exactly parallel to that of other observational sciences, like astronomy and paleontology; indeed, Kiparsky (1974) calls its practitioners paleogrammarians.

在某些情况下，比较学者对相似性的解释可能是邻近语言群体采用了某个词，在其他情况下，对应性只能解释为巧合，但很明显，许多欧洲语言和西亚语言是“相关的”，是同一祖先的后代。这些关系最著名的证明是格林定律（然而，雅各布·格林简单地称之为“音变”，而不是定律，拉斯穆斯·拉斯克在他之前就观察到了），它解释了拉丁语pater、德语Vater和英语father之间的相似性，以及拉丁语piscis、德语Fisch和英语fish之间的相似性。格林定律的美妙之处在于，它通过一些简单的发音相似性（比如p和f都用嘴唇发音）非常巧妙地识别出了印欧语系的一个主要分支，即日耳曼语，并且在短短几十年内，类似的见解将印欧语系的当前结构确立为确凿的科学事实——稳固地成为十九世纪最主要的智力成就之一。

In some cases, the explanation of similarity the comparativists came up with might be that a word was adopted by neighboring language groups, in other cases the correspondences could only be explained as coincidences, but it became very clear that many of the European and West Asian languages were “related,” descendants of the same parent. The most famous demonstration of these relations is Grimm’s law (which, however, Jacob Grimm simply called a “sound shift,” not a law, and which Rasmus Rask had observed before him), accounting for the parallels among, for instance, Latin pater, German Vater, and English father, and among Latin piscis, German Fisch, and English fish. The beauty of Grimm’s law is that it very neatly identified a major branch of the Indo-European family tree, the Germanic languages, by way of a few simple articulatory similarities (such as the fact that both p and f are pronounced using the lips), and within a few intense decades, similar insights had established the present configuration of the Indo-European family as a hard scientific fact—solidly among the chief intellectual accomplishments of the nineteenth century.

比较语言学家的成果经受住了时间的侵蚀，但到了本世纪末，比较语言学家本身却遭到了自封的新语法学家的猛烈攻击，许多语言学家认为这种权力转移是“假革命”——事实上，这是典型的假革命，只有热度，没有光亮——但最好将其视为半革命。它极大地影响了该领域的数据和范围。新语法学家（最著名的是卡尔·布鲁格曼和赫尔曼·保罗）更广泛地关注当代语言和方言，认为它们本身很有价值，而比较语言学家主要关注已消亡的语言，主要从当代语言中寻找它们可以照亮过去的东西。这种转变也影响了语言学的目标和论据，转向心理问题并产生了新类别的保证和上诉。例如，新语法学家寻求的是法律而不是规律，并禁止对语言起源等不可证实的问题进行推测。他们自认为很像物理学家；而比较语言学家最喜欢将自己比作自然学家。这种转变并没有以任何有趣的方式改变比较语言学巨大成功的堡垒，即其方法论——新语法对科学原理的编纂“在很大程度上引出了[比较语言学家的工作]所暗示的内容”(Robins, 1967:187)——而且它对比较语言学家的结果没有影响，除了可能加强了其中一些结果。另一场革命是费迪南德索绪尔的巨著《普通语言学教程》（1966 [1915]），它开创了通常被称为结构主义的语言学流派（顺便说一句，有人说这是现代科学语言学的开端；正如中产阶级在不断崛起，语言学也一直在成为一门科学）。

The comparativist results have withstood the corrosive passage of time remarkably well, but the comparativists themselves were viciously attacked by the selfstyled neogrammarians toward the end of the century, in a power shift that many linguists regard as a “false revolution”—in fact, as the prototypical false revolution, all heat, no light—but which is best regarded as a demi-revolution. It affected the data and the scope of the field substantially. The neogrammarians (the most famous being Karl Brugmann and Hermann Paul) attended more widely to contemporary languages and dialects as valuable in their own rights, where the comparativists had focused largely on dead languages, looking to contemporary languages primarily for the light they could throw on the past. This shift also affected the goals and argument lines of linguistics, by turning toward psychological questions and generating new classes of warrants and appeals. The neogrammarians, for instance, looked for laws rather than regularities, and banned speculation on nonverifiable matters, like the origins of language. They fancied themselves much like physicists; the comparativists’ favorite analogy was to naturalists. What this shift did not alter in any interesting way was the bulwark of comparative linguistics’ great success, its methodology—the neogrammarian codifications of scientific principles “were largely drawing out what had been implied by [the comparativists’ work]” (Robins, 1967:187)—and it had no effect on comparativists’ results, except perhaps to strengthen some of them. The other revolutionary shoe fell with Ferdinand de Saussure’s monumental Course in General Linguistics (1966 [1915]), which initiated the linguistic strain commonly known as structuralism (and which, incidentally, is another point that marks, some say, the beginning of modern, scientific linguistics; just as the middle class is always rising, linguistics is always becoming a science).

结构主义

Structuralism

当我们研究语言事实时，我们首先想到的是，对于说话者来说，语言在时间上的连续性并不存在。他面临的是一种状态。

The first thing that strikes us when we study the facts of language is that their succession in time does not exist insofar as the speaker is concerned. He is confronted with a state.

索绪尔

Ferdinand de Saussure

索绪尔的影响是巨大的，但有些间接，因为他的《课程》是他的两位同事（查尔斯·巴利和阿尔伯特·塞切海耶，与索绪尔笔记做得更好的学生之一阿尔伯特·里德林格合作）对他晚期一些讲座的遗作。不过，为了我们对语言史进行大奖赛回顾，我们只需要考虑索绪尔最深远的概念影响中的两个，这两个理想化都有助于孤立语言学的对象。

Saussure’s influence was vast, but somewhat indirect, since his Course is a posthumous reconstruction of some of his late lectures by two of his colleagues (Charles Bally and Albert Sechehaye, in collaboration with one of Saussure’s better notetaking students, Albert Riedlinger). For the purposes of our Grand Prix review of linguistic history, though, we need to consider only two of Saussure’s most ramified conceptual impacts, both idealizations which help to isolate the object of linguistics.

在索绪尔之前，许多人都对语言学的研究对象——语言——充满热情，但没有人特别关心如何严格地定义它。语言就是当你在餐桌上张开嘴，从声带中挤出一些声音，从而诱导苏格拉底递盐时发生的事情。斯多葛学派想看看它的点点滴滴——声音、词素、词语。莫迪斯泰学派采纳了其中一些发现（而忽略了其他发现），以及他们自己的许多发现，并从中筛选出现实的结构（或者，上帝的思想）。比较学者为语言学增加了时间，大量的时间，试图将其拉回到起点。他们所有人都对语言“真正是什么”有一些背景概念——亚当的舌头，只剩下退化的碎片；宇宙的蓝图；或者，对于深信不疑的希腊人来说，希腊语。但他们并不特别关心如何定义显而易见的语言。索绪尔则关心。

Before Saussure, many people cared passionately about the object of linguistics—language—but no one was particularly concerned about defining it in a rigorous way. Language was just that thing that happened when you opened your mouth at the table, squeezed a few noises out of your vocal chords, and induced Socrates thereby to pass the salt. The Stoics wanted to see what its bits and pieces were—sounds, morphemes, words. The Modistae took some of these discoveries (and ignored others), along with many of their own, and sifted through them for the structure of reality (or, what was the same, the mind of God). The comparativists added time, huge stretches of time, to linguistics, trying to reel it back to the starting point. And all of them had some background notion of what language “really was”—the Adamic tongue, of which only degenerate scraps remained; the blueprint of the universe; or, for the deeply chauvinistic Greeks, Greek. But they weren’t especially concerned with defining the perfectly obvious, language. Saussure was.

他非常担心，以至于面对新语法学家对这种漠视的持续态度，他几乎感到无能为力，他告诉他的一位朋友，他无法写任何关于语言的文章，因为这个领域没有人知道他们在做什么。他先是离开了新语法学家世界的中心莱比锡，前往巴黎担任教授；然后他离开了巴黎，因为巴黎仍然离被误导的主流太近，他去了相对默默无闻的日内瓦；然后，在他去世前，他销毁了大部分讲义，这些讲义阐明了他对语言和语言研究的观念。但是，在日内瓦语言偏远地区教授通识课程时，他摆脱了假设的束缚，重新定义了该领域。

He was so concerned that he felt almost paralyzed in the face of the neogrammarian continuation of this disregard, telling one of his friends that he couldn’t write anything on language because no one in the field knew what they were doing. First he left Leipzig, the center of the neogrammarian universe, for a chair in Paris; then he left Paris, still too close to the misguided mainstream, for the relative obscurity of Geneva; then, before he died, he destroyed most of the lecture notes articulating his notions of language and language study. But, teaching a general course in the linguistic outback of Geneva, he was free of suppositional constraints, and redefined the field.

为此，第一种理想化做法是将语言与比较语言学家所赋予它的几个世纪的重担分开，这种重担沉重地压在语言学家身上，但说话者在日常的意义交流中却完全没有注意到。索绪尔明确区分了历时语言学和共时语言学。历时字面意思是跨越时间，它描述了任何描绘语言在几个世纪以来的变化、断裂和突变的研究。大体上，它类似于进化生物学，描绘物种随时间的转变、断裂和突变，也类似于地质学，描绘岩石的变化和改造。共时字面意思是与时间一起，但这里的词源具有误导性，因为索绪尔的术语描述的是一种非时间语言学，即不受时间影响的语言学，它抽象出时代的影响，研究某一给定冻结时刻的语言。他在这方面使用的另外两个词——进化语言学和静态语言学——有助于使区别更加清晰，但它们也提请人们注意研究语言的特殊性，就好像时间并不重要。

The first idealization to this end was to separate language from the weight of the centuries the comparativists had laid on it, a weight which pressed heavily on linguists but was wholly unnoticed by speakers in their daily trade of meanings. Saussure distinguished sharply between diachronic linguistics and synchronic linguistics. Diachronic literally means across-time, and it describes any work which maps the shifts and fractures and mutations of languages over the centuries. In gross outline, it is similar to evolutionary biology, which maps the shifts and fractures and mutations of species over time, and to geology, which maps the shifts and transformations of rocks. Synchronic literally means with-time, though etymology is misleading here, since Saussure’s term describes an atemporal linguistics, linguistics which proceeds without time, which abstracts away from the effects of the ages and studies language at a given, frozen moment. Two other words he used in this regard—evolutionary and static linguistics—help make the distinction clearer, but they also draw attention to the peculiarity of studying language as if time didn’t matter.

静态语言学是一个相当令人困惑的概念，其他自然科学中没有明确的类比。生态生物学与之类似，它研究物种在特定时间的相互作用，而不太考虑产生这些物种的选择压力，化学也是如此，它研究化学物质的相互作用，而不考虑它们的历史，但这两门科学都有明确的时间维度。事实上，最接近的类比是形式科学，如数学和逻辑的大多数分支；三角形和存在量词超越了时间。但语言，一种不可避免的经验现象，怎么能成为形式科学的对象呢？一个词怎么会像三角形呢？答案和问题一样成问题，在我们结束之前，我们将看到很多这个问题，但无论原则上的复杂性如何，在实践中，索绪尔的区分是非常可行的。实际上，共时性意味着“在一代人之内”，因为语言的变化只是通过儿子和女儿、孙子和孙女的创新和误解来实现的，索绪尔要求他的学生进行一个思想实验来证明这一点。“想象一个孤立的人活了几个世纪，”他问道。“我们可能注意到不了任何变化；时间不会影响语言”（1966 [1916]：78）。3

Static linguistics is a pretty baffling notion, to which there are no clear analogies in other natural sciences. Ecological biology is similar, in that it looks at the interactions of species at a given time, without too much regard for the selective pressures that gave rise to them, and so is chemistry, in that it looks at the interactions of chemicals, irrespective of their history, but both of these sciences have definite temporal dimensions. The closest analogies, in fact, are to formal sciences, like most branches of mathematics and logic; triangles and existential quantifiers are outside of time. But how can language, an inescapably empirical phenomenon, be the object of a formal science? How can a word be like a triangle? The answers are as problematic as the questions, and we will see a good deal of this issue before we are through, but whatever the in-principle complications are, in practice Saussure’s distinction is very workable. In practice, synchronic means something like “within a generation,” since it is only through the innovations and misunderstandings of sons and daughters, grandsons and granddaughters, that languages change, and Saussure asked his students for a thought-experiment to make this point. “Imagine an isolated individual living for several centuries,” he asks. “We would probably notice no change; time would not influence language” (1966 [1916]:78).3

因此，共时和历时并不是指语言的各个方面，而是指对语言的看法。

Synchronic and diachronic, then, refer not to aspects of language so much as perspectives on language.

索绪尔思想实验中的关键术语显然是孤立的。即使是一位不老的演说家——例如迪克·克拉克——也必须改变他的讲话方式以跟上时代潮流。也就是说，语言是一种社会产品，这将我们带到了索绪尔的第二个理想化，另一个鲜明的区分，即语言在使用时、电视上的霍金唱片和使霍金成为可能的系统之间的区分。第一个，使用中的语言，索绪尔称之为parole；第二个，语言使用背后的系统，他称之为langue 。两者的区别大致在于普通的用语术语， speech和language之间的区别，这两个词本身就很宽泛，但它们仍然是最好的英文翻译对于索绪尔的术语来说，言语与谈论和倾听更密切相关，语言与原则和规则更密切相关，这些原则和规则使得我们在谈论和倾听时能够进行意义交换。更抽象地说，我们可以分别将索绪尔的术语与行为和语法联系起来。言语是口头活动：说、写、听、读。语言是使语言行为成为可能的背景系统。

The key term in Saussure’s thought experiment is clearly isolated. Even an ageless speaker—Dick Clark, for instance—has to change his speech to keep up with the generational tide. That is, language is a social product, which brings us to Saussure’s second idealization, another sharp division, this one between language when it is put to use, hawking records on television, and the system that makes hawking possible. The first, language in use, Saussure called parole; the second, the system behind language use, he called langue. The difference is roughly the one between the ordinary parlance terms, speech and language, words which are pretty loose in their own right, but which are, respectively, still the two best English translations for Saussure’s terms; speech is more closely associated with talking and listening, language with the principles and rules which make the trade of meanings possible when we talk and listen. More abstractly, we might identify Saussure’s terms, respectively, with behavior and grammar. Parole is verbal activity: speaking, writing, listening, reading. Langue is the background system that makes linguistic behavior possible.

科学地研究语言在很大程度上意味着将语言视为自然对象，即自然界中存在的某种东西，而这一概念显然是索绪尔思想的背后支撑——在《课程》中，语言有时甚至被称为“具体对象”，尽管它根本没有什么具体性。语言最具体的方面——空气中的声学扰动或页面上的字符——只是反射，几乎是偶然的。当然，当我们谈论语言时，我们指的不是舞动的空气分子、墨水和页面。而是空气和页面上的模式，以及将这些模式与行为和信念联系起来的关系网络。这些模式及其网络构成了索绪尔的语言。言语在很大程度上是他的方法的一个过滤器，用来筛选出这些模式的多变、脆弱、短暂的回声。他说，言语超出了语言学的范围和能力。索绪尔的语言学研究的是系统、游戏规则，而不是特定比赛的个别动作。 （顺便说一句，国际象棋是索绪尔最喜欢的语言类比。）

The scientific approach to language means, in large measure, taking it to be a natural object, something which exists in nature, and this notion clearly lies in back of Saussure’s thinking—in the Course language on a few occasions is even called a “concrete object,” though there is nothing concrete about it at all. The most concrete aspects of language—acoustic disturbances in the air or characters on the page—are only reflexes, virtually accidental. Certainly the dancing air molecules, the ink and the page, are not what we mean when we talk about language. It is the patterns in the air and on the page, and the network of relations which link those patterns to actions and beliefs. The patterns and their network constitute Saussure’s langue. Parole is largely a filter for his approach, to screen out the variable, vulnerable, ephemeral echoes of those patterns. Parole is, he says, outside the scope and capabilities of linguistics. Saussurean linguistics studies the system, the rules of the game, not the individual moves of a specific contest. (Chess, by the way, was a favorite Saussurean analogy for language.)

不难看出，这种推理方式存在一些令人望而生畏的复杂性。数据必须来自言语，来自人们张嘴并脱口而出的重要声音，但这些理论涉及语言，即将这些能指与所指联系起来的系统。更麻烦的是，能指是公共项目，只有与社区概念相结合才能有意义；所指是私人项目，只有与个人认知概念相结合才能有意义。语言是“存放在每个人大脑中的社会产物”（索绪尔，1966 [1916]：23）。因此，就语言是自然对象的程度而言，它在自然界中只有两个可以想象的位置，这两个位置都是必需的，但它们本身都非常模糊且难以理解，即社会和思想。这种情况使语言学成为一门非常两面性的职业，一个头朝向人类学和社会学，另一个头朝向心理学。 （索绪尔的思想其实兼具两种思想，但他深受涂尔干的影响，主要倾向面向社会学。）

There are, it is easy to see, some daunting complications to this style of reasoning. The data must come from parole, from people opening their mouths and blurting out significant sounds, but the theories concern langue, the system that links those signifiers to signifieds. More troublesome, the signifiers are public items, sensible only in concert with a notion of community; the signifieds are private items, sensible only in concert with a notion of individual cognition. Language is a “social product deposited in the brain of each individual” (Saussure, 1966 [1916]:23). To the extent that language is a natural object, then, there are only two conceivable locations for it to reside in nature, both of them necessary but both of them very amorphous and poorly understood themselves, society and mind. This situation makes linguistics a very Januslike profession, one head facing toward anthropology and sociology, the other toward psychology. (Saussure’s thought, in fact, accommodates both heads, but he was strongly influenced by Durkheim, and his overwhelming tendency is to face toward sociology.)

索绪尔模式的语言理论（即结构主义）描绘的是言语的基础系统，而不是言语本身。这个系统在语言学界被称为语法，现在占据了中心地位。

Linguistic theory in Saussure’s mode—that is, structuralism—charts the system underlying speech, not speech itself. This system, best known in linguistic circles as grammar, now takes center stage.

萨丕尔，尤其是布鲁姆菲尔德

Sapir, and, Especially, Bloomfield

大致来说，20 世纪上半叶，语言学出现了以下几个重要的理论发展：（1）19 世纪两个相对独立的传统——历史比较和哲学描述——的融合，以及随之而来的动荡，传教士和人类学家的实用描述主义成为重要的支流。（2）索绪尔、萨丕尔，尤其是布卢姆菲尔德不仅努力将语言学与历史比较和哲学描述结合起来，而且也做出了相应的努力。将这些传统的积极发现整合到一门学科中，更重要的是将该学科确立为一门受人尊敬的科学分支，并使其与其他分支保持适当的独立性。（3）音位原理的发现和发展。

Very roughly, the first half of the twentieth century saw the following major theoretical developments in [linguistics]: (1) the confluence, with all appropriate turbulence, of the two relatively independent nineteenth century traditions, the historical-comparative and the philosophical-descriptive, the practical descriptivism of missionaries and anthropologists coming in as an important tributary. (2) serious efforts by Saussure, Sapir, and especially Bloomfield, not only to integrate the positive findings of these traditions into a single discipline but, even more, to establish that discipline as a respectable branch of science with the proper degree of autonomy from other branches. (3) The discovery and development of the phonemic principle.

查尔斯·霍克特

Charles Hockett
