我们现在的故事发生在北美，结构主义在二十世纪二十年代和三十年代牢牢扎根，并持续蓬勃发展（尽管结构主义这个词实际上有些声名狼藉）。4但这是本土的结构主义。正如科学史上经常发生的那样，结构主义在当时盛行。事后看来，它起源于新语法学运动，旨在将严谨性和系统性引入比较方法，但在许多独立学者中也可以看到几条重要的线索——特别是在三个名叫威尔的人的语言学著作中：哲学家威廉·冯·洪堡、心理学家威廉·冯特和该群体中唯一的美国人、语言学家威廉·德怀特·惠特尼。洪堡是 19 世纪少数不主要关注语言历史方面的语言学者之一，他（在某种程度上让人想起莫迪斯泰）比他的同时代人更关心语言的一般属性，即语言系统。冯特深受洪堡的影响，他将语言学兴趣融入了他的《民族心理学》（大致为“文化心理学”），并将民族心理学兴趣融入了他的语言学。惠特尼受过德国新语法学家的训练，也非常关注语言的社会心理维度，最重要的是，他主张采取更系统、更独立的语言方法（布卢姆菲尔德认为他帮助消除了早期方法的“神秘模糊性和随意性理论”——1914：312）。这些威尔斯都不能被称为结构主义者，他们对语言学的贡献也各不相同，但他们都对索绪尔观点及其北美同源词的产生做出了重大贡献。

In North America, where our story now takes us, structuralism took very firm root in the twenties and thirties, and continues to flourish (though the word, structuralism, is actually in some disrepute).4 But it was a home-grown structuralism. As happens so often at critical junctures in the history of science, structuralism was in the air. It was, hindsight reveals, incipient in the neogrammarian moves to introduce rigor and systematicity into comparativist approaches, but several important threads are also noticeable in a number of independent scholars—in particular, in the linguistic work of three guys named Will: the philosopher, Wilhelm von Humboldt; the psychologist, Wilhelm Wundt; and the only American in the group, linguist William Dwight Whitney. Humboldt was one of the few nineteenth-century scholars of language not primarily concerned with its historical aspects, and he was (in a way that partially recalls the Modistae) far more interested in the general properties of language, its system, than his contemporaries. Wundt, who was strongly influenced by Humboldt, wove linguistic interests into his Völkerpsychologie— roughly, “cultural psychology”—and völkerpsychologische interests into his linguistics. Whitney, who was trained among the German neogrammarians, also had a solid concern for the social-psychological dimensions of language, and, most importantly, argued for a more systematic and independent approach to language (Bloomfield credits him with helping to banish the “mystic vagueness and haphazard theory” of earlier approaches—1914:312). None of these Wills could be called a structuralist, and their contributions to linguistics are quite varied, but they all contributed substantially to the climate which gave rise to Saussure’s views and their North American cognates.

美国结构主义发展史上最重要的人物无疑是爱德华·萨丕尔和伦纳德·布鲁姆菲尔德；而从该领域后来的发展方向来看，这两位人物中最重要的无疑是布鲁姆菲尔德。5

The most important figures in the development of American structuralism, far and away, are Edward Sapir and Leonard Bloomfield; and, given the subsequent direction of the field, the most important of these two, far and away, is Bloomfield.5

萨丕尔——以及早期的布卢姆菲尔德（程度较轻）——与冯特和惠特尼一样对文化心理学感兴趣，并且他与洪堡一样关注语言的一般系统属性，即他以洪堡的名字称之为语言的内在形式。他没有索绪尔明确的“此处有区别，彼处有区别”的理论，而是从这些线索编织出了一种非常相似的语言分析方法，其细节（无论是在索绪尔还是萨丕尔的理论中）会让我们离题太远。但是，这种编织中还有其他东西，这是美国语言学家与欧洲表亲之间最重要的区别，这种决定性特征最好被称为“美洲印第安人的命令”。萨丕尔的老师是世纪之交美国语言研究领域的思想和政治巨头弗朗兹·博厄斯，又名弗朗兹爸爸，又名美国语言学之父。博厄斯认识到美洲丰富、多样、富有挑战性的语言所带来的机遇和义务——这些语言与主导旧世界语言学的印欧语系非常不同。

Sapir—and, to a lesser extent, the early Bloomfield—had the cultural-psychological interests of Wundt and Whitney, and he had Humboldt’s concern for the general, systematic properties of language, for what he called, after Humboldt, its inner form. Without the explicit here-a-distinction-there-a-distinction theorizing of Saussure, he wove from these strands a remarkably parallel approach to linguistic analysis, the specifics of which (in both Saussure and Sapir) would take us too far afield. But there was something else in the weave as well, the most important characteristic separating American linguists from their European cousins, a defining trait best termed “the Amerindian imperative.” Sapir’s teacher was the intellectual and political juggernaut of U.S. language studies at the turn of the century, Franz Boas, a.k.a. Papa Franz, a.k.a. The Father of American Linguistics. Boas recognized both the opportunity and the obligation that came with the rich, diverse, challenging languages of the Americas—languages very different from the Indo-European tongues which dominated Old World linguistics.

（作为这些差异的一个非常肤浅的例子，以 Kwakwala 语的动词为例，Kwakwala 语是一种原生于加拿大西部潮湿地区（包括科莫兰特岛）的语言。Kwakwala 语动词与发生时间完全无关，不需要像大多数印欧语系动词那样标记时态。但它们高度关注说话者的权威性，必须进行标记以表明说话者对所描述的动作作出陈述的理由——标记以表明说话者是否亲眼目睹了这一动作，是否只是从别人那里听说了这一动作，或者是否在梦中经历过这一动作——这一概念对于印欧语系的语言和使用者来说非常陌生。）6

(As a very superficial example of these differences, take the verbs of Kwakwala, a language native to the damp western reaches of Canada, including Cormorant Island. Kwakwala verbs are wholly indifferent to time of occurrence, and needn’t be marked for tense in the way most Indo-European verbs are. But they are highly concerned about the authority of the speaker, and have to be marked to indicate the speaker’s justification for making a statement about the described action—marked to indicate whether the speaker saw the action, just heard about it from someone else, or experienced it in a dream—a notion highly alien to the languages, and the speakers, of the Indo-European families.)6

早期对非欧洲语言的研究大多出于两个直接贪婪的动机：征服和皈依。因此，多样性是一个问题，阻碍了“文明的进步和传教士的劳动”（Lyell，1870：461）。语法研究主要寻找将基督教或欧洲管理的概念强加到母语中的方法，以便以后可以在讲坛或书页上宣扬它们。这一目标，加上随意的训练、普遍认为“原始人”在种族、文化和语言上低劣，以及认为拉丁语是所有语言之王的扭曲的沙文主义倾向，导致对美洲印第安语言的处理几乎与对其使用者的处理一样野蛮。阿尔冈昆语、莫霍克语和特拉华语的表达被归入与格、虚拟语气和部分属格等类别，而无法归入这些类别的内容则被忽略。博厄斯和他的学生们对这种拙劣和混乱的做法只有鄙视。萨丕尔这样说道：

Much of the earliest research into non-European languages had one or the other, or both, of two straightforwardly rapacious motives: conquest and conversion. Diversity was therefore a problem, something which impeded “the advance of civilization and the labours of the missionary” (Lyell, 1870:461). Grammatical research primarily looked for ways of forcing the concepts of Christianity or of European administration into the native language, so they could be served up later from pulpit or page. This goal, along with haphazard training, a general belief in the racial, cultural, and linguistic inferiority of “primitives,” and a warping streak of chauvinism which held Latin to be Pope of all Languages, led to treatments of Amerindian languages almost as barbarous as the treatment of their speakers. Algonquin and Mohawk and Delaware expressions were pounded into categories like dative and subjunctive and partitive-genitive, and what couldn’t be pounded into these slots was ignored. Boas and his students had nothing but contempt for this bungling and mangling. Sapir put it this way:

一个语言学家如果坚持谈论拉丁语形态，好像它必然是语言发展的顶峰，就好比一个动物学家认为有机世界中赛马或泽西牛的进化是一个巨大阴谋。（1922:124）

A linguist who insists on talking about the Latin type of morphology as though it were necessarily the high-water mark of linguistic development is like the zoölogist that sees in the organic world a huge conspiracy to evolve the race-horse or the Jersey cow. (1922:124)

提到动物学并非偶然。博厄斯承认并强调了美洲印第安语言的完整性，将文本标本的收集视为重中之重，并引导他的学生以及（通过他在美国民族学局等机构的影响力）大部分可用资金，主要以描述性、数据驱动的方向发展。尽管其他态度和其他方法仍在继续，但在博厄斯的领导下，语言学的主流是他所谓的“分析技术”——在语言的原生地描述语言，提取其自身呈现的规律，不强加任何外部因素。 （顺便说一句，洪堡在这方面也有影响力；例如，他认为，某些马来-波利尼西亚语的单词表面上看起来像欧洲动词，但实际上，在它们自己的语言系统中，将其作为名词进行分析效果更好；见 Koerner，1990 年。）对于博厄斯和他的学生来说，多样性不是障碍，而是值得庆贺的事情，他们也开始对各种美洲印第安语言所包含的各种世界观产生了健康的尊重。博厄斯和大多数科学家一样，对事实的兴趣当然不止于此。他称语言是“灵魂之窗”，这与其说是精神上的定义，不如说是文化和心理上的定义。但弗朗茨爸爸的压倒性影响是密切关注语言并且对他们自己也产生了影响；对许多人来说，这种重视使他成为“北美语言真正科学研究之父” (Anderson, 1985: 198)。

The reference to zoology is not accidental. Boas recognized and enforced the integrity of Amerindian languages, prizing the collection of textual specimens above all, and steered his students, along with (through his influence at such institutes as the Bureau of American Ethnology) most of the available funds, in a primarily descriptive, data-driven direction. Though other attitudes and other approaches continued, under Boas the sanctioned mainstream of linguistics was what he called the “analytic technique”—to describe languages in their native habitat, extracting the regularities that presented themselves, imposing none from without. (Humboldt, incidentally, was also influential here; he had argued, for instance, that certain Malayo-Polynesian words which looked superficially like European verbs were in fact better analyzed, within their own linguistic systems, as nouns; see Koerner, 1990.) Variety for Boas and his students was not a hindrance, but a cause for celebration, and they also came to have a healthy respect for the various world views bundled up in the diverse Amerindian languages. Boas certainly had, like most scientists, interests beyond the brute facts. He called language a “window on the soul,” which was not so much a spiritual definition as a cultural and psychological one. But the overwhelming impact of Papa Franz was to focus closely on languages in and of themselves; this emphasis made him, for many, “the father of the authentically scientific study of language in North America” (Anderson, 1985:198).

萨丕尔——和索绪尔一样，孤立于渥太华这个冷酷的知识穷乡僻壤——以理论更丰富、哲学更深刻但又有些折衷的方法增强了博厄斯的数据驱动程序，发展出了一种独特的美国结构主义。7例如，他曾写到完全屈从于历史语言学的“进化偏见”的危险（1949a[1921]:123），并阐述了与索绪尔的“语言”非常相似的概念，认为语言的定义方面在于“形式模式和概念的关联”，并且“正是这种抽象的语言，而不是言语的物理事实”构成了语言学的主题（1949a[1921]:22）。他与索绪尔最明显的区别在于明确欣赏源自美洲印第安人命令的多样性。 （顺便注意，这个要求本身就足以决定美国语言学强烈的共时性倾向，因为几乎没有书面记录可以用来探究语言史；而且，博厄斯——无论如何，他几乎没有受过历史训练——积极劝阻他的学生进行比较研究。）萨丕尔的作品以其敏锐的洞察力、出色的跳跃以及对语言的一般属性与语言所使用的令人震惊的概念和范畴范围之间、一致性与多样性之间、用瓦罗有些生硬的说法就是类比与异常之间的紧张关系的仔细平衡而闻名。

Sapir—isolated, like Saussure, in a cold intellectual backwater, Ottawa—augmented Boas’s data-driven program with a theoretically richer, philosophically deeper, but somewhat eclectic approach, developing a uniquely American structuralism.7 He wrote about the dangers of succumbing wholly to the “evolutionary prejudice” of historical linguistics (1949a[1921]:123), for instance, and he articulated a notion closely parallel to Saussure’s langue, saying that the defining aspects of language lie “in the formal patterning and in the relating of concepts,” and that “it is this abstracted language, rather more than the physical facts of speech” which forms the subject matter of linguistics (1949a[1921]:22). Where he departs most clearly from Saussure is in the explicit appreciation of variety which grew out of the Amerindian imperative. (Notice, incidentally, that this imperative in and of itself was enough to determine a strong synchronic bent to American linguistics, since there was virtually no written records with which to plumb linguistic history; too, Boas—who, in any event, had little historical training—actively discouraged his students from comparativist work.) Sapir’s work is remarkable for penetrating insights, brilliant leaps, and a careful balancing of the tension between the general properties of language and the astonishing range of concepts and categories employed by languages; between uniformity and diversity; between, in Varro’s somewhat stilted terms, analogy and anomaly.

他雄辩地论述了“深刻的、控制形式的冲动”和“伟大的潜在规划”，并（用一个特别能让人联想到索绪尔的短语）主张“一种理想的语言实体主宰着语言使用者的言语习惯”（1949a[1921]:144, 148）。但他同样雄辩地、更滔滔不绝地论述了多样性，论述了导致不同语言使用者无法真正理解彼此（即使在翻译中）的决定性特征，因为每个人都缺乏“必要的形式凹槽来运行”彼此的思想（1949a[1921]:106）。

He writes eloquently about the “deep, controlling impulse to form” and “the great underlying ground-plans,” and (in a phrase particularly evocative of Saussure) argues for “an ideal linguistic entity dominating the speech habits” of language users (1949a[1921]:144, 148). But he is equally eloquent, and more voluble, about variety, about the defining traits that keep speakers of different languages from truly understanding one another, even in translation, because each lacks “the necessary form-grooves in which to run” one another’s thoughts (1949a[1921]:106).

因此，萨丕尔的结构主义比索绪尔的结构主义更彻底地是心理学的，而且——由于美国语言学家对语言的一般性主张持怀疑态度，萨丕尔对人类意义交换的多样性和易变性有了更深刻的认识。萨丕尔很有才华，很有影响力。但他不是那种会赞助学校的人，尽管在 40 年代和 50 年代，有些语言学家有时被称为萨丕尔派；Joos (1957:25) 引用他的话，并不是因为他“开发了任何方法，而是因为为与他本人或多或少相似的个性的自由智力发挥建立了宪章”，事实上，Joos 稍微批评了“萨丕尔所谓的‘方法’本质上的不负责任”。萨丕尔学派（几乎完全由萨丕尔的学生组成）的主要特点是他们对语言的精神生活有着非正统的兴趣，具有一定的方法论弹性主义，并偶尔批评正统观念，而不是一套特定的独特假设和原则。

Sapir’s structuralism, then, was more thoroughly psychological than Saussure’s, and it was—thanks to the wealth of native data that kept American linguists skeptical of general claims about language—much more aware of the diversity and volatility in the human trade of meanings. Sapir was ingenious, and very influential. But he was not, even though there were linguists sometimes known as Sapirians into the forties and fifties, the sort to sponsor a school; Joos (1957:25) cites him not for “the developing of any method, but rather the establishing of a charter for the free intellectual play of personalities more or less akin to his own,” and, in fact, Joos wags his finger a bit at “the essential irresponsibility of what has been called Sapir’s ‘method’.” Sapirians (almost entirely made up of Sapir’s students) were distinguished mostly by their unorthodox interest in the mental life of language, for a certain methodological elasticism, and for their occasional critiques of the orthodoxy, not for a specific body of unique postulates and principles.

同样的话也可以用在萨丕尔在芝加哥大学的同事、耶鲁大学斯特林语言学教授职位的继任者、20 世纪 40 年代和 50 年代正统语言学的奠基者伦纳德·布鲁姆菲尔德身上。同样的话也可以用在布鲁姆菲尔德身上，但有两件事除外。​​他发现了行为主义，并且他发现了逻辑实证主义，而现在人们对他这两种观点都嗤之以鼻；行为主义是心理学的过时分支，实证主义是哲学的过时分支。所以，布卢姆菲尔德的名字在过去几十年的语言学中经常出现，只不过是一个密码，与我们已经见过很多次、并且还会见到更多的名字乔姆斯基形成鲜明对比。在某种程度上，陪衬的角色是很自然的，因为当我们把乔姆斯基的影响看作对某些布卢姆菲尔德趋势的反应（如果不是纠正的话），我们最容易理解他的影响。在某种程度上，陪衬的角色是强加的，因为胜利者书写历史，而乔姆斯基的崛起是以牺牲受布卢姆菲尔德启发和强烈影响的一代人为代价的。

The same might have been said of Sapir’s colleague at the University of Chicago, and his successor to the Sterling Professorship in Linguistics at Yale, and the definer of the orthodoxy in the forties and fifties, Leonard Bloomfield. The same might have been said of Bloomfield, but for two things. He found behaviorism and he found logical positivism, for both of which he is now widely snickered at; behaviorism is an outmoded brand of psychology, positivism an outmoded brand of philosophy. So, Bloomfield’s name shows up frequently as little more than a cipher in the linguistics of the last few decades, a foil to another name we have already seen a good deal of, and will see much more of, Chomsky. In part, the role of foil is natural, since understanding Chomsky’s impact comes most easily when it is viewed as a reaction, if not a corrective, to certain Bloomfieldian trends. In part, the role of foil is imposed, since the victors write the history, and Chomsky’s rise came at the expense of a generation inspired and strongly influenced by Bloomfield.

最能概括布隆菲尔德的词是“有条不紊” ，尤其是与他的部分竞争对手萨丕尔相比。（乔姆斯基从来都不是布隆菲尔德的对手，除非在抽象层面上；布隆菲尔德在乔姆斯基出现之前就去世了。）例如，他们都写过书，题为《语言》，其中的区别显而易见。萨丕尔（1949a[1921]）的文章内容丰富、令人振奋——当然不乏结构和理论意义，但充满了精彩的见解和丰富的想象力。布隆菲尔德（1933）的文章是一本食谱——当然不乏才华和想象力，但系统性更强，在为读者提供获得类似结果的食谱方面更加谨慎，引导他们获得自己的见解，引导他们的想象力。这种比较可能对布卢姆菲尔德来说并不怎么好，而且它讽刺了两本书，尽管这两本书在语言学界经历了 60 多年的狂热，但仍然经久不衰，但它抓住了这两本书、语言学家以及他们各自对语言学领域的影响之间的主要区别。萨丕尔的书更有趣，也许更有激情，但它也不太实用，不太有用。布卢姆菲尔德给了一代语言学家一本手册。他给了他们一些事情去做（当然，很多人说，他让语言学成为一门科学）。8即便是萨丕尔最虔诚的学生也不得不承认，布卢姆菲尔德对该学科的影响远不止于此：

The word which best captures Bloomfield, especially in distinction to his partial rival, Sapir, is methodical. (Chomsky was never Bloomfield’s rival except in the abstract; Bloomfield died before Chomsky came on the scene.) They both wrote books entitled Language, for instance, and the differences are telling. Sapir’s (1949a[1921]) is a rich, invigorating essay—certainly not without structure and theoretical import, but heaped high with brilliant insights and imaginative leaps. Bloomfield’s (1933) is a cookbook—certainly not without brilliance and imagination, but far more systematic, and far more careful about giving its readers recipes with which to obtain similar results, leading them to their own insights, guiding their imagination. The comparison may be less than flattering to Bloomfield, and it caricatures two books which hold up astonishingly well, despite more than sixty intervening years of feverish linguistic activity, but it catches the primary difference between the books, the linguists, and their respective impacts on the field. Sapir’s book is more enjoyable, and perhaps more passionate, but it is also less practical, less useful. Bloomfield gave a generation of linguists a handbook. He gave them something to do (and, of course, many said, he made linguistics a science).8 Even Sapir’s most devout students had to admit Bloomfield’s impact on the discipline was far more comprehensive:

尽管萨丕尔以精湛的技巧运用语言学方法和程序，但在这方面，他是一位艺术家，而不是科学家。布卢姆菲尔德将语言学方法发展为一套定义明确、严密连贯的学说体系。（纽曼，1951：86）

Although Sapir used linguistic methods and procedures with consummate skill, he was an artist rather than a scientist in this regard. It was Bloomfield who formulated the methods of linguistic science into a clearly defined and tightly coherent body of doctrine. (Newman, 1951:86)

布卢姆菲尔德的《语言》和萨丕尔的《语言》只相隔了十多年，但对美国语言学来说却是重要的十年，它几乎可以解释这两本书之间的差异，就像解释作者性格的差异一样。那十年的决定性事件是美国语言学会的成立，其名称宣告了本世纪初独立运动的成功，并宣告另一场独立运动即将开始；学会两边的修饰语说明了一切。9介词短语“美洲”规范了将其成员与欧洲亲属区分开来的发展。形容词“语言学”则表明了与在平行学科中研究语言的学术亲属的分离。博厄斯、萨丕尔和布卢姆菲尔德都对成立该学会发挥了重要作用：博厄斯和萨丕尔是切断与欧洲联系的主要力量；布卢姆菲尔德则迅速成为切断心理学和民族学联系的主要力量。他撰写了 LSA 的宣言，呼吁建立一个不同于“现有学会、语言学、语言学家学会是一个由语言学家、 ...

Little more than a decade separates Bloomfield’s Language from Sapir’s, but it was an important one for American linguistics and goes almost as far toward explaining the differences between those two books as does the difference in their authors’ temperaments. The defining event of that decade was the formation of the Linguistic Society of America, whose name proclaims the success of the independence movement early in the century and declares another one just under way; the modifiers on either side of Society say it all.9 The prepositional phrase, of America, codifies the developments separating its members from their European relatives. The adjective, Linguistic, signals a separation from their academic relatives studying language in parallel disciplines. Appropriately, Boas, Sapir, and Bloomfield were all instrumental in forming the society: Boas and Sapir were the main forces in cutting the umbilical cord to Europe; Bloomfield was rapidly becoming the main force in cutting the apron strings to psychology and ethnology. He wrote the LSA’s manifesto, calling for an organization distinct from “the existing societies, Philological, Oriental, Modern Language, Anthropological, Psychological, and what not,” most of whose members “[do] not know that there is a science of language” (1925:1; 1970:109). Most people who called themselves linguists were in fact still housed in language or literature or anthropology departments—only three of the 264 Foundational Members of the LSA listed linguistics among the courses they taught—but they were beginning to feel more kinship with others who called themselves linguists than with their immediate colleagues, and Bloomfield articulated that kinship. Even linguists who maintained strong interests in literature or philology, for instance, took their papers in these areas to other forums. (Hill writes that he “felt forced to present” his literary analyses elsewhere—1991:14.)

LSA 很快启动了夏季语言学研究所，该研究所自此成为该领域的一个重要特色。该研究所是（现在仍然是）一个非常重要的培训和灌输场所，供那些认为自己首先是语言科学家，其次是文化或心灵或法语学者的学者使用。布鲁姆菲尔德是研究所的常任教师，鼓舞人心，直到 20 世纪 40 年代末生病去世（萨丕尔只在那里教过一次书）。随着 LSA 的成立，出版机构也应运而生——采用了常见、杂乱但恰当的标题《语言》——它很快就对语言学专业和实践产生了巨大影响，没有一篇文章在这两个方面比布鲁姆菲尔德在第二期上的文章《语言科学的一套公设》（1926；1970：128-40）更具影响力——三十年后，它仍被称为“当代描述语言学宪章”（Joos，1957：31）。这些公设涉及一个如今已为人熟知的话题，即语言学的研究对象（索绪尔的《课程》和萨丕尔的《语言》都被认为是其灵感来源），但比布鲁姆菲尔德的任何前辈所处理的问题都更为严格。下面是一个例子，幸好写得简短：

The LSA soon fired up what has become a prominent feature of the field’s landscape ever since, its summer Linguistic Institute. The Institute was (and remains) a very important training and indoctrination ground for scholars who saw themselves, or thereafter came to see themselves, as scientists of language first, scholars of culture or mind or French, second. Bloomfield was a regular and inspiring teacher at the Institute until his illness and death in the late forties (Sapir taught there only once). With the LSA also came a publishing organ—taking the common, omnivorous, but apropos title, Language—which soon became hugely influential to the profession and practice of linguistics, and no article was more influential in both regards than Bloomfield’s contribution to the second issue, “A Set of Postulates for the Science of Language” (1926; 1970:128–40)—three decades later still being called “the Charter of contemporary descriptive linguistics” (Joos, 1957:31). The postulates take up a now-familiar topic, the object of linguistics (Saussure’s Course and Sapir’s Language are both cited as inspirations), but with considerably more rigor than they had been tackled by any of Bloomfield’s predecessors. Here is a sample, kept mercifully brief:

8. 定义：最小X 是不完全由较小 X 组成的 X。因此，如果 X 1由 X 2 X 3 X 4组成，则X 1不是最小 X。但如果 X 1由 X 2 X 3 A 组成，或由 A 1 A 2组成，或不可分析，则 X 1是最小 X。

8. Def. A minimum X is an X which does not consist entirely of lesser X’s.

Thus, if X1 consists of X2X3X4, then X1 is not a minimum X. But if X1 consists of X2X3A, or of A1A2, or is unanalyzable, then X1 is a minimum X.

9. 定义：最小形式是词素；其意义是义素。

因此，词素是一种循环（有意义的）形式，不能反过来分析成更小的循环（有意义的）形式。因此，任何不可分析的词或构成词都是词素。

9. Def. A minimum form is a morpheme; its meaning a sememe.

Thus a morpheme is a recurrent (meaningful) form which cannot in turn be analyzed into smaller recurrent (meaningful) forms. Hence any unanalyzable word or formative is a morpheme.

10. 定义：可以作为话语的形式是自由的。不自由的形式是受约束的。因此，book、man是自由形式；-ing（如writing）、-er（如writer）是受约束形式，后者的含义与自由形式err不同。

10. Def. A form which may be an utterance is free. A form which is not free is bound. Thus, book, the man are free forms; -ing (as in writing),-er (as in writer) are bound forms, the last-named differing in meaning from the free form err.

11. 定义：一个最小自由形式是一个词。（1926：155-56；1970：130）

11. Def. A minimum free form is a word. (1926:155–56; 1970:130)

还有七十三个——总共五十个是关于共时语言学的，二十七个是关于历时语言学的（历史研究仍然非常活跃，但不再占据主导地位）。所有七十七个看起来都同样迂腐。但只有那些不愿意承认语言研究需要精确性的人才会这样认为。它们对于语言学的正式支柱是必不可少的。牛顿的《光学》在他同时代的一些人看来可能很迂腐，欧几里得的《原理》在他同时代的一些人看来也一样；10布卢姆菲尔德当然也有这样的同时代人。萨丕尔就是其中之一。萨丕尔并不反对精确或严谨，但他对语言的看法过于复杂，无法用一种简洁的语言来概括。自然科学方法，几年后，当他主张语言学“不模仿也不试图采用未经修改的自然科学概念”时，他肯定想到了布卢姆菲尔德，即使他没有瞄准布卢姆菲尔德。同样，他显然担心布卢姆菲尔德式的剪刀会扯住围裙带，因为他随后又呼吁语言学家“越来越多地关注语言领域的许多人类学、社会学和心理学问题”（1929:214），但毫无效果。11至少对于大多数语言学家来说，尤其是那些年轻的语言学家来说，这些束缚已经被切断了，他们把这些无菌公设牢记在心，晚上睡觉前还要读布卢姆菲尔德的《语言》一书，这是对这些公设的最全面阐述。

There are seventy-three more—fifty in all for synchronic linguistics, twenty-seven for diachronic linguistics (historical studies being still very much alive, but no longer in the driver’s seat). All seventy-seven look equally pedantic. But only to someone unwilling to grant the need for precision in the study of language. They were necessary to give linguistics a formal backbone. Newton’s Opticks may have looked pedantic to some of his contemporaries, Euclid’s Principles to some of his;10 certainly Bloomfield had such contemporaries. Sapir, for one. Sapir was no enemy of precision or of rigor, but his view of language was far too ramified for a neat natural science approach, and he surely had Bloomfield in his mind, if not his sights, when he argued a few years later for a linguistics “which does not ape nor attempt to adopt unrevised the concepts of the natural sciences.” Too, he was clearly worried about Bloomfieldian scissors at the apron strings when he followed that argument with a plea for linguists to “become increasingly concerned with the many anthropological, sociological, and psychological problems which invade the field of language” (1929:214), to no avail.11 The strings were cut, at least far as the majority of linguists was concerned, especially the younger ones, who took the antiseptic postulates to heart and their fullest exposition, Bloomfield’s Language, to bed with them at night.

在语言学领域之外，语言学十年中，语言学领域之外的两项附带发展对布卢姆菲尔德的手册更为重要，这两项发展显然都是在俄亥俄州立大学时为他结晶的，在那里，他与阿尔伯特·韦斯成为了好朋友（事实上，他的假设明确模仿了韦斯在 1925 年提出的心理学假设）。这些发展在前几页中有所预示，即行为主义和实证主义的兴起，这两者都在二十年代抬头。

Two collateral developments, outside the field of linguistics, in the Language-to-Language decade were even more important for Bloomfield’s handbook, both apparently crystallizing for him at Ohio State, where he became fast friends with Albert Weiss (in fact, his postulates were explicitly modeled on Weiss’ postulates for psychology—1925). These developments, foreshadowed a few pages back, were the rises of behaviorism and positivism, both of which reared their seductive heads in the twenties.

行为主义心理学自 20 世纪初巴甫洛夫获得诺贝尔奖的著名实验“敲响晚餐铃，观察狗流口水”以来一直在发展，但直到约翰·沃森及其同事在 10 到 20 年代的工作之后，行为主义才开始蓬勃发展，并得到正式名称。用最直白的话来说，行为主义认为信念、行为和知识都是奖励和惩罚的产物。每次鸽子打喷嚏时给它食物，它很快会在饿的时候打喷嚏。每当老鼠攻击另一只老鼠时电击它，它很快就会表现出较少的攻击性。当婴儿叫你“爸爸”时，对她微笑并给予她额外的关注，当她需要你额外的关注时，她就会（虽然很短暂）说“爸爸”。当孩子发错“light”的音、拼错不规则复数或拼错单词时，让她受到责备或嘲笑，她的语言行为就会趋近于常态；语言行为就会变得合乎语法。行为主义是一种简单、有力、令人信服的理论，尤其是对于简单的行为现象而言。它对布卢姆菲尔德的吸引力并不在于他可以用它来解释语言行为。恰恰相反。它是如此成功，以至于他觉得把语言的心理目的留给心理学家是件很舒服的事。12

Behaviorist psychology had been building since Pavlov’s famous Nobel-winning, ring-the-dinner-bell-and-watch-the-dog-drool experiments at the turn of the century, but it didn’t hit its stride, or get its name, until the work of John Watson and his collaborators in the teens and twenties. In the baldest terms, behaviorism is the position that beliefs, actions, and knowledge are all the products of rewards and punishments. Give a pigeon food every time it sneezes, and it will soon start sneezing whenever it gets hungry. Shock a rat whenever it attacks another rat, and it will soon show less aggression. Smile at a baby and give her extra attention when she calls you “papa” and she will (though all too briefly) say “papa” whenever she wants some extra attention from you. Expose a child to censure or ridicule when she mispronounces “light” or gets an irregular plural wrong or spells a word incorrectly, and her linguistic behavior will converge on the norm; it will become grammatical. Behaviorism is a simple, powerful, compelling theory, especially for simple behavioral phenomena. Its attraction for Bloomfield was not so much that he could put it to work explaining linguistic behavior. Quite the opposite. It was so successful, he felt comfortable leaving the psychological ends of language to the psychologists.12

简而言之，它让他轻松地避开了语言的复杂方面——学习语言、了解语言、使用语言、理解语言——这些方面困扰着早期的语言学家，包括前行为主义者布鲁姆菲尔德。他的早期作品表现出对语言的精神触角的关注，以及对心理学的依赖（“在所有心理科学中，语言学需要最好的心理洞察力在每一步中得到指导”——1914：323）。这种担忧消失了，布鲁姆菲尔德变得非常反心理。他早期作品中的心理学内容相当混乱，有时只是试探性地提出，他的第一篇文章因此受到批评。13然而，比这些批评更重要的是，在写作《语言学导论》和他所谓的“修订版”（但其他人都称之为“一部全新的作品”）之间的二十年里，14布卢姆菲尔德对非印欧语系（他加禄语、梅诺米尼语、福克斯语、奥吉布瓦语和克里语）进行了认真的田野研究，这些语言是他无法在闲暇时在老师的指导下研究的。他在大学里攻读硕士学位，而这些语言并没有经过数个世纪的研究。他与美洲印第安人的命令针锋相对。15在此过程中，他开始将语言的所有心理方面视为对实际工作（描述）的干扰：即获得正确的音系和形态结构。对他来说，心理解释与语言数据的关系类似于“上议院与下议院的关系：当上议院同意时，它是多余的；当上议院不同意时，它是令人讨厌的”（Hockett，1965 [1964]：196）。

In short, it let him comfortably avoid the messier aspects of language—learning a language, knowing it, using it, understanding it—aspects that nagged earlier linguists, the pre-behaviorist Bloomfield included. His early writings show a concern for the mental tentacles of language, and a dependence on psychology (“linguistics is, of all the mental sciences, in need of guidance at every step by the best psychologic insight available”—1914:323). This concern dropped away, and Bloomfield became profoundly anti-mental. The psychology that entered his early work was pretty muddy stuff, sometimes tentatively offered, and his first text was criticized for it.13 Far more important than this criticism, though, was that in the two decades between writing An Introduction to the Study of Language and what he called its “revised version” (but which everyone else called “a wholly new work”),14 Bloomfield did serious field research on non-Indo-European languages (Tagalog, Menomini, Fox, Ojibwa, and Cree)—languages he couldn’t study at leisure, under a master at university, languages which didn’t already have centuries of research on them. He bumped nose-to-pillar into the Amerindian imperative.15 In the process, he came to view all the mental aspects of language as distractions from the real job, description: getting the phonological and morphological structure right. The relation of mental explanation to linguistic data was for him something like the relation “of the House of Lords to the House of Commons: when it agrees, superfluous; when it disagrees, obnoxious” (Hockett, 1965 [1964]:196).

因此，他主要使用行为主义来呼吁将语言学从令人生畏的复杂思维中解放出来。在这一点上，他也从韦斯等心理学家那里获得了启发，他称赞韦斯驱逐了“我们部落泛灵论（思维、意识、意志等）的幽灵”（1931:220；1970:238）。这些心理学家，如布卢姆菲尔德，受到严谨的渴望所激励，因此也是科学的。听听乔治·米勒对沃森和早期行为主义者的解释：

His principal use of behaviorism, then, was as an appeal to justify cutting linguistics loose from the forbidding complexities of the mind. On this score, too, he took his lead from psychologists like Weiss, whom he praised for banishing “the specters of our tribal animism (mind, consciousness, will, and the like)” (1931:220; 1970:238). These psychologists, like Bloomfield, were motivated by the desire to be rigorous, and therefore scientific. Listen to George Miller’s paraphrase of Watson and the early behaviorists:

你看，内省是不可靠的，不同的人内省的方式不同，我无法证实你是否真的有过你告诉我的经历。让我们把心智从心理学中剔除——那都是宗教迷信。我们将成为头脑清醒、脚踏实地的科学家，（J. Miller，1983：21）

Look, introspection is unreliable, different people introspect differently, there’s no way I can verify that you really had the experience you told me you had. Let’s throw the mind out of psychology—that’s all religious superstition. We’ll be hard-headed, hard-nosed scientists, (in J. Miller, 1983:21)

行为主义心理学是一种奇特的现象，它抛弃了心理，只谈论直接可观察的行为；从真正意义上讲，这种心理学不是关于心智的，而是关于身体的。对于行为主义者和布卢姆菲尔德来说，摒弃一切无法直接验证的东西是成为科学的途径。他们知道这一点，因为逻辑实证主义者告诉他们。

With behaviorism you get the curious spectacle of a psychology that throws out the mental in order to talk exclusively about directly observable behavior; a psychology, in a very real sense, not of the mind, but of the body. Banishing everything not directly verifiable, for the behaviorists and for Bloomfield, was the way to be a science. They knew this because the logical positivists told them so.

实证主义有着古老的根源，可以追溯到伊壁鸠鲁学派甚至更早，十八世纪英国的伟大思想家洛克、贝克莱和休谟都曾影响过它；它以某种极端的方式表达了伟大的哲学传统，即经验主义，即所有知识都来自感觉。但它的正式开端是二十世纪二十年代著名的维也纳学派，这是一群彻底的经验主义哲学家，他们将维特根斯坦令人难以忍受的《逻辑哲学论》（1961 [1921]）作为他们的代表作。实证主义思想的简略版本，特别是当它与这个学派最关心的事业——科学——相关时，体现在验证原则中：命题的意义在于验证它的方法。“下雨了”的意思是把手伸出窗外；如果把手淋湿了，命题就是真的；否则，就不是真的。伽利略下降定律的含义是他的球在斜面上的实验，他“重复了整整一百次”，每次都发现“对于不同的平面倾斜度，下降时间彼此之间的比率恰好等于”该定律所蕴含的比率（1954 [1638]：179）。E = mc2 的含义是1945 年 7 月 16 日在新墨西哥沙漠发生的世界末日爆炸，此后重复了数百次。当然，验证的方法不止一种 — — 听屋顶上的雨声、看窗外、在菲多从狗门进来时揉揉他的头看它是否湿了 — — 但对实证主义者来说，关键的一点是，原则上存在某种经验的验证方法。对布卢姆菲尔德主义者来说，这种方法 — —与心理主义相对，称为机制— — 是将所有解释与身体联系起来。布鲁姆菲尔德告诉他的追随者，“机械论者认为“心理意象、感觉等只不过是各种身体运动的通俗术语” （1933：142；斜体为布卢姆菲尔德所加）。

Positivism has ancient roots, reaching back to the Epicureans and beyond, by way of the powerful British thinkers of the eighteenth century, Locke, Berkeley, and Hume; it is an articulation, somewhat extreme, of the grand philosophical tradition which says that all knowledge comes from the senses—empiricism. But its formal beginnings are with the famous Wiener Kreiss of twenties Vienna, a circle of thoroughly empiricist philosophers who took Wittgenstein’s insufferably titled Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus (1961 [1921]) as their defining document. The short version of positivist thought, particularly as it relates to the enterprise that most concerned the circle, science, comes in the verification principle: The meaning of a proposition is the method of its verification. The meaning of “It’s raining” is sticking your hand out the window; if it gets wet, the proposition is true; if not, not. The meaning of Galileo’s law of descent is his ball-on-the-inclined-plane experiment, “repeated a full hundred times” and finding each time that “the times of descent, for various inclinations of the plane, bore to one another precisely the ratio” entailed by the law (1954 [1638]:179). The meaning of E = mc2 is the apocalyptic detonation on 16 July 1945, in the New Mexico desert, repeated hundreds of times since. There is more than one method to skin a verification, of course—listen to the rain on the roof, look out the window, rub Fideau’s head to see if it is wet as he comes through the doggy door—but the critical point for the positivists is that there be, in principle, some empirical method of verification. For Bloomfieldians, this method—called mechanism, in contrast to mentalism—was to link all explanations to the body. “The mechanist,” Bloomfield told his followers, “believes that mental images, feelings, and the like are merely popular terms for various bodily movements” (1933:142; Bloomfield’s italics).

实证主义（以及一般的经验主义）的一个重要贡献是坚持怀疑论，并因此否定了连最微不足道的验证可能性都没有的主体。特别是，实证主义者继续拒绝上个世纪开始的形而上学，谴责它是彻头彻尾的胡说八道——不仅仅是非正式意义上的“愚蠢”，而且从字面上讲，毫无意义。例如，由于柏拉图的形式领域无法通过任何可以想象的方法来验证，因此有关它的所有陈述都是毫无意义的。维也纳学派将维特根斯坦著名的“凡是不能说的，就必须保持沉默”（Wittgenstein，1961 [1921]：150）折射成口号“形而上学家：闭嘴！”行为主义者和布卢姆菲尔德主义者从这个口号转向“心灵主义者：闭嘴！”只是一小步。甚至没有那么快。推杆。16

One of the important contributions of positivism (and empiricism generally) is its insistence on skepticism, and its consequent disavowal of subjects without even the most tenuous possibilities for verification. In particular, positivists continued the rejection of metaphysics begun in the previous century, condemning it as utter nonsense—not just in the informal sense of “silly,” but, literally, without sense. Since Plato’s Realm of the Forms, for instance, could be verified by no conceivable method, all statements about it were meaningless. The Vienna Circle refracted Wittgenstein’s famous “Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent” (Wittgenstein, 1961 [1921]:150) into the slogan “Metaphysicians: Shut your traps!” The behaviorist and Bloomfieldian move from this slogan to “Mentalists: Shut your traps!” was a short drive. Not even that. A putt.16

因此，心理学和语言学中的心灵主义就如同生物学中的活力论、化学中的燃素论、物理学中的以太论一样，心灵主义在离开时也打点行装。然而，心灵主义的其中一个行李箱对于该学科来说尤其重要，那就是将语言学中相当关键的一个主题——意义——放入其中。美洲印第安人的命令已经使语言学家专注于音系和形态描述，这使他们的注意力集中在能指上，远离所指——远离语言中更混乱、更难分离和分类的方面，远离意义。但布卢姆菲尔德将这种不情愿从实践提升到原则。他当然很清楚意义对语言学家的吸引力；如果语言只是人类发出的一些系统性声音，与思想或社会没有任何联系，那么它就和咳嗽、打喷嚏或吹风笛一样没有意思。但他也认识到语言学的巨大成功（主要是比较语言学家的成功）更接近声音和意义之间鸿沟的能指岸；更尖锐地说，“意义的陈述是语言研究的弱点”（1933：140）。

So, mentalism in psychology and linguistics went the way of vitalism in biology, phlogiston in chemistry, ether in physics, and, also like those other notions, mentalism packed its bags when it left. One of its suitcases was particularly crucial for the discipline, however, the one into which mentalism threw a rather critical part of linguistics’ subject matter, meaning. The Amerindian imperative had disposed linguists to concentrate on phonological and morphological description anyway, which kept their attention on the signifiers, away from the signifieds—away from the messier, harder-to-isolate-and-catalog aspects of language, away from meaning. But Bloomfield raised this reluctance from practice to principle. He was certainly well aware of the attractions meaning holds for linguists; if language was just some systematic noises humans made, with no connections to thought or society, it would be of no more interest than coughing, or sneezing, or playing the bagpipes. But he also recognized that linguistics’ big successes (principally those of the comparativists) were much nearer the signifier shore of the gulf between sound and meaning; more pointedly, that “the statement of meaning is the weak point of language study” (1933:140).

他对意义的厌恶涉及一些有趣的学科技巧。布卢姆菲尔德认为，处理手头事务的一种方法是，牢牢划定混乱数据和棘手问题的边界，把它们留在别人的后院：“不构成学科真正组成部分的问题应该通过简单地将其命名为属于其他科学的领域来妥善处理”（1926：154；1970：129）。尽管说意义不构成语言的真正组成部分很奇怪，但对布卢姆菲尔德来说，意义是那些可以随意处理的问题之一；他经常建议它更适合心理学、社会学、人类学，除了语言学之外的任何学科。语言学有更直接的关注​​，为了满足这些关注，他承认语言学家，“我们尽可能用其他科学来定义语言形式的意义。如果做不到，我们就求助于权宜之计”（1933：140）。布卢姆菲尔德本想用这句话来描述语言学家研究语言时通常的做法，事实也确实如此，但对于从他的《语言》中学习该领域的那一代语言学家来说，这句话也成了一种处方。17

His aversion of meaning involved some interesting sleight of discipline. One way to get on with the business at hand, Bloomfield held, was to establish your borders firmly on this side of messy data and recalcitrant issues, leaving them in someone else’s backyard: “matters which form no real part of the subject should properly be disposed of by merely naming them as belonging to the domain of other sciences” (1926:154; 1970:129). Despite the peculiarity of saying that it formed no real part of language, meaning was one of those disposable matters for Bloomfield; he regularly suggested that it belonged more properly to psychology, sociology, anthropology, anything but linguistics. Linguistics had more immediate concerns, and in order to satisfy those concerns, he confessed of linguists, “we define the meaning of a linguistic form, wherever we can, in terms of some other science. Where this is impossible, we resort to makeshift devices” (1933:140). Bloomfield intended this statement as a description of the way things were generally done when linguists looked at languages, and it was, but for the generation of linguists which learned the field from his Language, it also became a prescription.17

具有讽刺意味的是，实证主义——一种意义理论——支撑了将意义排除在语言学之外，但布鲁姆菲尔德和大多数科学家一样当时那些关注哲学的人，更关注验证原则的谓词而不是其主题，其中有一个词特别引人注目。实证主义者将他们的焦点放在验证方法上，从而将形而上学抛入黑暗。成为一门科学的重要之处在于拥有一种方法；更好的是，拥有一种方法论。布卢姆菲尔德在他的《语言》中编纂的本土美国结构主义，如果不是严格的方法论，就什么都不是了。

There is an irony as big as Everest that positivism—a theory of meaning—undergirded the exclusion of meaning from linguistics, but Bloomfield, like most scientists of the period who concerned themselves with philosophy, attended much more to the predicate of the verification principle than its subject, and one word was particularly eye-catching. The positivists cast metaphysics into the darkness by putting their spotlight brightly on the method of verification. The important thing about being a science was having a method; better yet, having a methodology. And the home-grown American structuralism that Bloomfield codified in his Language was nothing if not rigorously methodological.

布卢姆菲尔德方法论——现在我们可以放心地使用他的名字作为一个描述性形容词，这个形容词最能体现他的著作发表后大约三十年间美国结构主义的特征——当然，严格意义上来说并不是布卢姆菲尔德的。18它是索绪尔和萨皮尔的混合体，受到分析美洲各种正在消失的土著语言的实际需要的强烈影响；受到一些后索绪尔欧洲语言学家的温和影响；由布卢姆菲尔德重新加工、筛选和扩充；并被反精神主义、害怕意义的丝带所束缚。从布卢姆菲尔德手中，它传给了几位有影响力的继任者——最著名的是伯纳德·布洛赫、乔治·特雷格、泽利格·哈里斯和查尔斯·霍克特——其中一些人比他们鼓舞人心的领袖更加教条。这种方法，在一个对其灵活性造成一定破坏的缩影中，从某种语言的大量录音话语开始，即语料库。我们对语料库采用了一种明确的、逐步的、自下而上的分析策略，首先将声流分解成离散的声音，例如，嘴唇张开时释放的气流形成pin中的第一个音，或者气流通过舌头抵住牙齿形成的通道形成 和中的最后一个音。这些声音被分成各种音素，每种音素都有一小段声学实现范围。接下来是小单位，如per-和-vert，它们分为各种词素，每种词素都有一小段实现范围。接下来是词，分为名词和动词等类别，每种类别都有其实现。然后是话语本身 - 例如“哦，天哪！”和“我把牙线放哪儿了？” - 布卢姆菲尔德学派不再深入研究。对于没有参与其中的人来说，这项工作肯定显得枯燥乏味，但这是一项要求很高、需要很大智力挑战的工作，需要面对一连串陌生的噪音，并揭示出这些噪音中的结构，使人们能够互相传递干肉饼。

Bloomfieldian methodology—and at this point we can safely start using his name as a descriptive adjective, the one which best characterizes American structuralism for, roughly, the three decades following publication of his text—was not, of course, strictly Bloomfield’s.18 It was a Saussurean-Sapirian mélange, strongly influenced by the practical necessities of analyzing the diverse, disappearing aboriginal languages of the Americas; mildly influenced by a few post-Saussurean European linguists; reworked, winnowed, and augmented by Bloomfield; and tied up with antimentalist, meaning-fearing ribbons. From Bloomfield’s hands, it passed to several influential successors—most notably, Bernard Bloch, George Trager, Zellig Harris, and Charles Hockett—some of whom were considerably more dogmatic than their inspiring leader. The approach, in an epitome which does some violence to its flexibility, began with a large collection of recorded utterances from some language, a corpus. The corpus was subjected to a clear, stepwise, bottom-up strategy of analysis which began by breaking acoustic streams into discrete sounds, like the puff of air released when the lips are unsprung to form the first sound in pin or the stream of air forced through a channel formed by the tongue against the teeth as the last sound in both. These sounds were classified into various phonemes, each with a small range of acoustic realizations. Next were the small units like per- and -vert, classified into various morphemes, each with a small range of realizations. Next came words, classified into such categories as nouns and verbs, each with its realizations. Then there were utterances themselves—like Oh my! and Where did I leave the dental floss?—and further than that Bloomfieldians did not care to go. The enterprise surely seems dull and tedious to anyone who has not engaged in it, but it is a very demanding, intellectually challenging job to confront an alien stream of noises and uncover the structure in those noises that allows people to get one another to pass the pemmican.

事实上，美国结构主义比我们在这里真正欣赏的更加多样化和有趣（例如，参见 Hymes 和 Fought，1981 [1974]）。有几种可识别的流派——包括萨丕尔风格的语言方法，这种方法不禁止心理考虑，以及基督教方法，这种方法仍然主要将语言作为传教手段——以及少数独立主义者、多元主义者和怪人。他们是一群活跃的人，他们之间争执不休，攻击他们的欧洲同行，追求文化帝国主义。但他们在方法和信仰上也相当有凝聚力，其中大部分都遵循布卢姆菲尔德建立的理论结构。他的影响无处不在，首先是亲自和他的教科书，然后越来越多地通过他的学生和他们的学生，特别是通过 LSA、其出版机构Language和语言研究所。

American structuralism, in fact, was more diverse, and more interesting, than we really have time to appreciate here (see, for instance, Hymes and Fought, 1981 [1974]). There were several identifiable strains—including Sapir-tinged approaches to language, which did not outlaw mental considerations, and Christian approaches, which still studied languages primarily as means to missionary ends—along with a smattering of indépendistes, pluralists, and cranks. And they were a lively bunch, feuding among themselves, attacking their European counterparts, and pursuing cultural imperialism. But they were also quite cohesive, in methods and beliefs, the bulk of which followed from the theoretical structure erected by Bloomfield. His influence was everywhere, at first in person and through his textbook, then, increasingly, through his students and their students, especially by way of the LSA, its publishing arm, Language, and the Linguistic Institute.

布卢姆菲尔德的思想定义了语言时代的气质：它主要是描述性和分类性科学，如动物学、地质学和天文学；心理推测等同于神秘主义，是对科学的抛弃；所有相关的心理学问题（学习、了解和使用语言）都将由行为主义来回答；意义超出了科学探究的范围。这个项目在方法论上是严谨的，而且非常成功。

Bloomfield’s ideas defined the temper of the linguistic times: that it was primarily a descriptive and taxonomic science, like zoology, geology, and astronomy; that mental speculations were tantamount to mysticism, an abandonment of science; that all the relevant psychological questions (learning, knowing, and using a language) would be answered by behaviorism; that meaning was outside the scope of scientific inquiry. This program was methodologically rigorous, and very successful.

空气中弥漫着信心和乐观的气氛。结构主义被证明是如此成功，以至于语言学被广泛誉为原型科学之外最严格、最富有成果的知识收集活动，就像上个世纪比较语言学受到的赞誉一样。社会学家、人类学家甚至民俗学家都明确采用了它的分类方法（其中最著名的是列维-斯特劳斯的结构主义人类学），而心理语言学这门混合学科也迈出了一些有希望的步伐。语言学家在第二次世界大战期间也证明了他们的爱国精神（设计课程、写书、制作音频材料来教士兵学习欧洲、太平洋和亚洲语言；设计和分析密码；担任翻译），因此该领域参与了战后的金融繁荣。主要项目正在进行中：加拿大和美国的语言地图集、牛津英语词典的美式英语补充，以及记录世界上所有已知语言的项目。布鲁姆菲尔德派的一位主要理论家亨利·李·史密斯甚至主持了一档颇受欢迎的广播节目，他的节目是“你来自哪里？”史密斯与乔治·特雷格一起建立了一个有望完备的模型，1953 年 LSA 年会上，史密斯发表了关于该模型的扩展论文，“这是迄今为止对向上看技术的最全面介绍 [从声音开始，‘向上’进入词素和句法]” (Hill, 1991:34)。语言学家有理由感到有点自鸣得意。

There was a good deal of confidence and optimism in the air. Structuralism had proven so successful that linguistics was widely hailed as the most rigorous and fruitful knowledge-gathering activity outside the prototypical sciences, much as comparative linguistics had been hailed in the previous century. Sociologists, anthropologists, even folklorists were explicitly adopting its classificatory methods (the most famous of these adoptions being Levi-Strauss’s structuralist anthropology), and the hybrid discipline of psycholinguistics was taking a few promising steps. Linguists had also proven their patriotic mettle during the Second World War (designing courses, writing books, and preparing audio materials to teach soldiers European, Pacific, and Asian languages; designing and analyzing secret codes; working as translators), and the field was therefore partaking in the postwar financial boom. Major projects were under way: language atlases of Canada and the U.S., an American English supplement to the great Oxford English Dictionary, and a project to document all the known languages of the world. There was even a popular radio show by one of the leading Bloomfieldian theorists, Henry Lee Smith’s “Where Are You From?” With George Trager, Smith had also built a model with the promise of completeness, and the 1953 LSA Annual Meeting saw his extended paper on that model, “the fullest presentation ever made of the upward-looking technique [beginning with sound and moving ‘upward’ into morphemes and syntax]” (Hill, 1991:34). Linguists had reason to be a little smug.

然而，在所有这些希望之中，坏消息是这项工作存在明显的差距——思想、意义、思考；简而言之，就是好东西。

The bad news amid all this promise, however, was the pronounced gaps in this work—the mind, meaning, thought; in short, the good stuff.

瞧，在东方，乔姆斯基崛起了。

Lo, in the east, Chomsky arose.

乔姆斯基语言学19

Chomskyan Linguistics19

我对意义很感兴趣，并希望找到一种方法来获得它。

I am interested in meaning and I would like to find a way to get at it.

诺姆·乔姆斯基

Noam Chomsky

乔姆斯基在重建语言学方面取得了迅速而彻底的成功——在科学界，毫无保留地使用“革命”这个被滥用的术语是完全恰当的；乔姆斯基将语言学转向了它的轴线，甚至是它的颠倒——几乎一切都与将好的东西带回语言学有关，而他的革命所引发的生成-解释争论很大程度上取决于语言学能够处理多少好的东西，以及以何种方式处理，同时仍然负责任地完成其主要工作，即解释语言结构。

Chomsky’s rapid and radical success in restructuring linguistics—and this is one of those places in science where the unqualified use of the abused term, revolution, is wholly appropriate; Chomsky spun linguistics on its axis, if not its head—has almost everything to do with bringing the good stuff back into linguistics, and much of the generative-interpretive debate which flowed out of his revolution hinged on how much of the good stuff linguistics can handle, and in what ways, and still responsibly do its main job, accounting for the structure of language.

不过，好东西来得很慢。乔姆斯基在早期的出版物中对思想和意义非常谨慎，以温和的语气和有节制的扩张来提供他的工作。科学家通常有两种方式来呈现创新的理论建议可以应用于其领域：作为现有理论的扩展，就像牛顿提出光学建议那样；或者作为现有理论的替代，就像拉瓦锡提出化学建议那样。两者都是极端，只部分地与这些创新与该领域流行观念之间的距离有关，而乔姆斯基的建议最好被视为修订，就像牛顿和拉瓦锡的建议一样——在这里扩展，在那里替代，在其他地方重新解释或删除。但两者都很有效，乔姆斯基很好地运用了这两种策略，从扩展策略开始。

The good stuff came slowly, though. Chomsky was quite circumspect about mind and meaning in his early publications, offering his work in the conciliatory tones of measured expansion. There are two general ways scientists can present innovative theoretical proposals to their field: as an extension of existing theory, the way Newton framed his optical proposals; or as a replacement of existing theory, the way Lavoisier framed his chemical proposals. Both are extremes, only partially connected to the distance between those innovations and the prevailing notions of the field, and Chomsky’s proposals are best seen, like Newton’s and Lavoisier’s, as revisions—an extension here, a replacement there, a reinterpretation or a deletion somewhere else. But both are effective, and Chomsky has used both well, starting with the extension strategy.

布隆菲尔德派毫不费力地将乔姆斯基的修订视为他们所关注问题的方法论附录。首先，众所周知，乔姆斯基是泽利格·哈里斯的学生，哈里斯是一位才华横溢、略显古怪但完全是布隆菲尔德派的语言学家，也是一位备受推崇的语言学家——“也许是 [那个时期] 最有技巧、最富想象力的预言家” (Bar-Hillel, 1967:537)——哈里斯已经开发出一套分析和程序，乔姆斯基从中大量借鉴。事实上，哈里斯在 1955 年发表了 LSA 主席演讲“语言结构的转变”，当时乔姆斯基刚刚登上布隆菲尔德派的舞台；同年，乔姆斯基的第一篇重要论文，也是一篇非常布隆菲尔德派的论文，在乔治城语言学圆桌会议上发表。乔姆斯基的第一本重要的转型著作《句法结构》也与哈里斯的重要论文《语言结构的共现和转换》同时出版（Chomsky, 1957a, Harris, 1957）。这一场景再合适不过了。

Bloomfieldians had very little difficulty in seeing Chomsky’s revisions as a methodological appendix to their concerns. For one thing, he was known to be the student of Zellig Harris, a brilliant, somewhat eccentric, but thoroughly Bloomfieldian, and very highly regarded linguist—“perhaps the most skillful and imaginative prophet [of the period]” (Bar-Hillel, 1967:537)—and Harris had developed a body of analyses and procedures from which Chomsky borrowed liberally. Harris, in fact, gave the 1955 LSA presidential address, “Transformation in Linguistic Structures,” just as Chomsky was breaking onto the Bloomfieldian stage; Chomsky’s first important paper, and a very Bloomfieldian one at that, was given the same year at the Georgetown Round Table on Linguistics. Chomsky’s first important transformational book, Syntactic Structures, also coincided with an important Harris Paper, “Co-occurrence and Transformation in Linguistic Structure” (Chomsky, 1957a, Harris, 1957). The scene couldn’t have been better set.

但更重要的是，当时美国语言学最明显的缺陷之一是它从新语法学家那里继承下来的，而新语法学家又从比较语言学家那里继承下来了，这是语言学研究中的一个巨大漏洞，自莫迪斯泰及其文艺复兴追随者以来一直被忽视，而哈里斯的研究试图填补这个漏洞。句法缺失了。

More importantly, though, among the most obvious lacunae in American linguistics of the period was one it had inherited from the neogrammarians, and they from the comparativists, a gaping hole in linguistic coverage which had been ignored since the Modistae and their Renaissance followers, a hole which Harris’s research was trying to fill in. Syntax was AWOL.

这种缺失有很多原因。部分原因是惰性。部分原因是布隆菲尔德自己对句法的处理令人困惑；他曾勇敢地与之搏斗，但却留给他的追随者们的只有很少的可利用的空间。部分原因是索绪尔的观点的体现，索绪尔认为句法原子，即句子，是“言语的典型单位”（Wells，1947a：15）；也就是说，句子不在语言学的真正主题语言中。部分原因是布隆菲尔德语言学中发展起来的方法论禁止“混合层次”——实际上，坚持语言学家首先研究语言的声音（音系层次），然后研究单词（形态层次），然后研究短语和句子（句法层次）。由于声音和单词存在如此多的问题，因此很难公正地对待句法。

The absence has many sources. In part, it was inertia. In part, it was Bloomfield’s own confusing treatment of syntax; he had wrestled with it valiantly, but left his followers very little into which they could sink their methodical teeth. In part it was a reflection of Saussure’s view, which saw the syntactic atom, the sentence, as “the typical unit of parole” (Wells, 1947a:15); that is, as outside the true subject matter of linguistics, langue. In part, it was the result of a methodological proscription which developed in Bloomfieldian linguistics against “mixing levels”—in effect, the insistence that a linguist first work out the sounds of a language (the level of phonology), then the words (the level of morphology), then the phrases and sentences (the level of syntax). Since the sounds and the words presented so many problems, it was tough to do the syntax justice.

但这种缺失很大程度上也与原始数据库有关。任何两个语言分析层次之间的分界线都不是特别清晰，在推动布卢姆菲尔德研究的许多美洲印第安语言中，形态学和句法之间的界限尤其难以辨别。以下是形态学和句法领域的标准划分，借用自布卢姆菲尔德的重要文本，布洛赫和特雷格的《语言分析大纲》（1942:53）：20

But much of this absence also had to do with the primary data base. The dividing line between any two levels of linguistic analysis is not especially clear, and in many of the Amerindian languages that fueled Bloomfieldian research, the line between morphology and syntax is especially difficult to make out. Here is a standard delineation of the provinces of morphology and syntax, borrowed from an important Bloomfieldian text, Bloch and Trager’s Outline of Linguistic Analysis (1942:53):20

形态学涉及词语的结构；句法涉及词语组合成短语和句子。

MORPHOLOGY Deals with the structure of words; SYNTAX deals with the combinations of words into phrases and sentences.

那么，请问，语言学家该如何将这些概念应用到像 1 这样的话语中呢？

Now how, in Manitou’s name, is a linguist to apply these notions to an utterance like 1?

1 a:wlisautiss?arsiniarpŋa

1 a:wlisautiss?arsiniarpŋa

这句话来自爱斯基摩方言，翻译成英语大致是“我在找一些适合用作钓鱼线的东西”，但它既不是词，属于形态学的范畴，也不是句子，属于句法的范畴；既不是爬行动物，也不是哺乳动物；或者，它既是爬行动物，也不是哺乳动物，就像鸭嘴兽一样，一只蹼足属于爬行动物，一只蹼足属于哺乳动物。但布卢姆菲尔德派的立场就像生物学家一样，他们非常擅长研究鱼类和爬行动物，但对乳汁分泌、毛皮和温血动物感到不舒服，因此把它们放在一边，留到以后再研究。他们可以将形态学工具应用于像 1 这样的话语，但请考虑一下来自更接近家乡的语言的话语：

From an Eskimo dialect, this expression translates into English roughly as “I am looking for something suitable to use as a fishing line,” but it is neither word, the province of morphology, nor sentence, the province of syntax; neither reptile nor mammal; or, rather, it is both, like a platypus, one webbed foot in the reptilian class, one in the mammalian. But the Bloomfieldians were in the position of biologists who are really good at fish and reptiles, but uncomfortable over milk secretion, fur, and warm-bloodedness, leaving them aside as problems for another day. They could get a long way applying their morphological tools to an utterance like 1, but consider one from a language closer to home:

2 垫子上有一只猫。

2 A cat is on the mat.

这句话有些非典型，因为哲学家们的话语往往如此，但它无疑是一个毛茸茸的、热血的句子，每个句子都有一个单独的位置，每个位置都有它的位置。这句话有六个小词，从形态学上讲，每个词几乎都是独立的。这些词组合在一起，构成了对世界的断言，这些词的小组合构成了断言的组成部分——a和cat自然搭配，就像the和mat搭配在一起一样； is和on不能自然搭配（例如， a cat可用于回答“什么东西坐在垫子上？”这样的问题，但is on只会在非常特殊的情况下说出）。简而言之，英语句子充满了可供句法采摘的李子，成熟而诱人。爱斯基摩人的句子虽然也不能免受句法分析的影响，但为形态学收割者提供了更有启发性的果实。21

This utterance is somewhat atypical, as the utterances of philosophers tend to be, but it is unambiguously a sentence, furry and warm-blooded, with an individual slot for everything, and everything in its slot. There are six little words, each pretty much on its own, morphologically speaking. In concert, the words comprise an assertion about the world, and smaller groups of these words form components of the assertion—a and cat go naturally together, in the same way that the and mat go together; is and on don’t go naturally together (a cat, for instance, can be used to answer a question like “What is sitting on the mat?” but is on would only be uttered in very unusual circumstances). In short, the English sentence is full of plums for the syntactic picking, ripe and inviting. The Eskimo sentence, while not immune to syntactic analysis, yields much more revealing fruits to morphological harvesters.21

布隆菲尔德派一旦掌握了形态学知识，通常就会离开果园，因此几乎没有什么有趣的话题可以谈论短语和句子大小的语言集群。布隆菲尔德派并非忽视了句法，或将其定义为语言学范围之外。据说，布隆菲尔德派语言学涉及三个核心主题——音系学、形态学和句法——这些主题从未被排除在教科书之外，在布隆菲尔德派的支柱——实地考察中也从未被忽略。语言学家在撰写教科书或概述时，总会有一章关于句法的内容。当他们去研究一种语言时，他们的描述性语法总是会尽职尽责地包含一两章关于句法（通常称为语法）的内容。但这些章节往往暴露出一种与布隆菲尔德派计划格格不入的非正式性。音系学和形态学分析是丰富、详细、具有启发性的研究；方法论是探索性的。句法分析是随机的、凭感觉进行的概述，包含了更多关于语言学家现在称之为形态学的现象的讨论，而不是他们称之为句法的讨论；这些方法是切片和切块、声音和词语程序的无力延伸。

The Bloomfieldians, once they had their morphological crop, usually left the orchard, and therefore had almost nothing of interest to say about linguistic clusters the size of phrases and sentences. It’s not that the Bloomfieldians ignored syntax, or, with meaning, defined it as outside the scope of linguistics. Bloomfieldian linguistics was said to concern three core topics—phonology, morphology, and syntax—none of which was ever left out of a textbook, and none of which was ever ignored in the Bloomfieldian mainstay, fieldwork. When linguists wrote textbooks or overviews, there was always a chapter on syntax. When they went out to bag a language, their descriptive grammars always dutifully included a chapter or two on syntax (usually called grammar). But such chapters often betray an informality that was anathema to the Bloomfieldian program. The phonological and morphological analyses were rich, detailed, revealing investigations; the methodologies were probing. Syntactic analyses were haphazard, seat-of-the-pants outlines, and contained far more discussion of phenomena linguists would now call morphological than they would call syntactic; the methodologies were limp extensions of slice-and-dice, sounds-and-words procedures.

缺少的是方法，而方法正是布卢姆菲尔德对科学的定义，因此句法工作通常伴随着一种尴尬的气氛。查尔斯·弗里斯在他的《美国英语语法》一书中以序言开头，向那些“受过语言科学方法训练”的读者（1940:viii）对他的随意处理表示赞赏。特雷格和史密斯并不以谦逊著称，他们只注意到“句法才刚刚开始（这一点将变得显而易见），因此必然是粗略的处理”（1957 [1951]:8）。特雷格和史密斯的句法程序——根据适当的基于声音的标签，它是一个音系句法程序——实际上被广泛认为是布卢姆菲尔德工具棚中最有前途的方法。

What was missing was method, and since method was the defining notion of science for Bloomfield, syntactic work usually came with an air of embarrassment. Charles Fries begins his American English Grammar with a preface apologizing to those readers “who are well trained in the scientific approach to language” (1940:viii) for the casualness of his treatment. Trager and Smith, not known for humility, note only that “syntax, as yet only begun (as will become evident) is necessarily treated sketchily” (1957 [1951]:8). Trager and Smith’s syntactic program—and it was a program, going by the suitably sound-based label, phonological syntax—was in fact widely considered to be the most promising approach in the Bloomfieldian tool shed.

简言之，美国结构主义者在句法方面的成果与他们在音系学和形态学方面的进步相比相形见绌，甚至与乔姆斯基的第一本书《句法结构》处于同一水平，更不用说像麦考利 (1988) 的两卷本杰作《英语句法现象》这样的后乔姆斯基著作了。22

In brief, American structuralists’ results in syntax are dwarfed by their advances in phonology and morphology, and not even in the same league with Chomsky’s first book, Syntactic Structures, let alone such post-Chomskyan works as McCawley’s (1988) masterful two-volume Syntactic Phenomena of English.22

不过，句法贫乏并没有引起太多的担忧。布卢姆菲尔德的世界正在按其应有的方式展开，一旦解决了声音和词语的最终复杂性，这一空白就会适时填补。霍克特 (1987:81) 将布卢姆菲尔德的《语言》问世后的十年左右称为“音素的十年”；再后的十年称为“形态素的十年”，有理由相信句子的十年即将到来。事实上，布卢姆菲尔德在声音和词语方面的成功是如此令人印象深刻，以至于空气中弥漫着一种悲观的乐观情绪，至少在乔姆斯基在哈里斯手下工作的宾夕法尼亚州是如此。正如乔姆斯基回忆的那样，

Still, syntactic poverty didn’t cause too much anxiety. The Bloomfieldian universe was unfolding as it should, and the gap would be filled in due course, once the final intricacies of sounds and words had been worked out. Hockett (1987:81) calls the ten or so years after Bloomfield’s Language, “the Decade of the Phoneme;” the ten years after that, “the Decade of the Morpheme,” and there was reason to believe the Decade of the Sentence was impending. Indeed, Bloomfieldian successes with sounds and words were so impressive that there was a kind of gloomy optimism in the air, at least in Pennsylvania, where Chomsky was working under Harris. As Chomsky recalls,

20 世纪 40 年代末，哈里斯和大多数结构语言学家一样，认为语言学领域基本上已经完蛋了。他们已经做完了一切。他们已经解决了所有问题。你也许需要做一些补充，但从本质上讲，语言学领域已经完蛋了。（类似评论请参见 Chomsky 1991a [1989]:11。）

In the late 1940s, Harris, like most structural linguists, had concluded that the field was essentially finished, that linguistics was finished. They had already done everything. They had solved all the problems. You maybe had to dot a couple of i’s or something, but essentially the field was over. (See Chomsky 1991a [1989]:11 for similar comments.)

“完成领域的主题”是科学变革故事中的一个常见主题，预示着暴风雨前的宁静，乔姆斯基的故事很容易成为马克斯·普朗克的故事：

The finished-field theme is a common one in the story of scientific shake-ups, signaling the calm before the storm, and Chomsky’s story could easily be Max Planck’s:

当他 17 岁准备进入大学时，普朗克找到物理系主任，告诉教授他的志向。教授的回答并不令人鼓舞：“物理学是一门几乎已经完成的知识分支，”教授沉闷地说道。“所有重要的发现都已经完成了。现在几乎不值得再进入物理学领域了。”（Cline，1987：34）23

When he was seventeen years old and ready to enter the university, Planck sought out the head of the physics department and told the professor of his ambition. The response was not encouraging: “Physics is a branch of knowledge that is just about complete,” the professor said drearily. “The important discoveries, all of them, have been made. It is hardly worth entering physics anymore.” (Cline, 1987:34).23

普朗克继续发现了他著名的常数，这是点燃量子革命的火花。哈里斯发展了变换，这是点燃乔姆斯基的火花。而且，就在普朗克认真地阐述牛顿范式的同时，哈里斯也在努力扩展布隆菲尔德范式。他着手寻找将句法归结为一组足够小、足够一致的模式的方法，以便结构主义方法可以对它们进行研究，他从数学中引入了一个概念，即变换。一些布隆菲尔德主义者可能认为哈里斯在句法方面的工作有点为时过早，但仍然是结构主义的一个可接受的延伸，他并不是唯一一个开始研究句法的理论家。尤其是年轻的语言学家，他们发现句法的前景很诱人；事实上，这是不可避免的。上一代人已经征服了音系学和形态学。在通往意义的无情征程中，下一个要征服的领域是句法，到 50 年代初，已经取得了一些小的突破。特别是，一种称为直接成分分析的方法引起了相当多的关注。24

Planck went on to discover his famous constant, the spark that ignited the quantum revolution. Harris developed the transformation, the spark that set Chomsky alight. And, just as Planck was working conscientiously to elaborate the Newtonian paradigm, Harris was working to expand the Bloomfieldian paradigm. He set out to find methods for boiling down syntax to a set of patterns small enough and consistent enough that structuralist methods could go to work on them, and he imported a concept from mathematics to get him there, the transformation. Some Bloomfieldians may have found Harris’s work in syntax a little premature, but still a palatable extension of structuralism, and he was not the only theorist beginning to scratch around in syntax. Younger linguists, in particular, found the prospect of syntax inviting; indeed, inevitable. The previous generation had conquered phonology and morphology. The next domain for conquest in the inexorable march toward meaning was syntax, and some small incursions had been made by the early fifties. In particular, an approach called Immediate Constituent analysis was generating a fair amount of attention.24

乔姆斯基的句法方法有两个关键组成部分，这两个组成部分都由他的程序最常见的术语“转换生成语法”来表示。他最广泛的创新在于这个复合词的后半部分。生成语法是一种形式机制，它生成语言中句子的结构描述，在数学意义上是生成的。生成语法是一组规则，它定义语言的声音、单词、短语和句子，就像几何是一组规则的集合，它定义圆形和正方形一样。这两个系统的要点也相同 - 几何代表有关空间的知识；生成语法代表有关语言的知识 - 这就是转换的用武之地。

Chomsky’s approach to syntax has two critical components, both signalled by the most common term for his program, transformational-generative grammar. The most wide-reaching of his innovations is in the second half of the compound. A generative grammar is a formal mechanism which generates structural descriptions of the sentences in a language, in the mathematical sense of generate. A generative grammar is a collection of rules which define the sounds, words, phrases, and sentences of a language in the same way that geometry is a collection of rules which define circles and squares. And the point of both systems is also the same—geometry represents knowledge about space; generative grammar represents knowledge about language—which is where the transformation comes in.

这两个领域都存在着强烈的经验约束。某些概念对于空间知识建模必不可少，某些概念对于语言知识建模必不可少。从乔姆斯基的角度来看，这些概念之一在复合词的前半部分给出：哈里斯的结构关联装置，即变换。同样，与数学的类比很重要，数学中存在大量将数据结构转换为其他数据结构、将坐标转换为形状、将圆转换为球体的程序。事实上，克莱因曾说过“几何学实际上并不是关于点、线、角和平行线；而是关于变换”（Stewart，1990：31）。在语言学中，变换包括添加、删除和置换——例如，将下面的 a 句子转换为 b 句子。

There are strong empirical constraints in both domains. Certain concepts are necessary to model knowledge of space, and certain concepts are necessary to model knowledge of language. One of these concepts, from Chomsky’s perspective, is given in the first half of the compound: Harris’s structure-relating device, the transformation. Again, the analogy with mathematics is important, where a wealth of procedures exists for transforming data structures into other data structures, coordinates into shapes, circles into spheres. In fact, Klein has said “geometry is not really about points, lines, angles and parallels; it is about transformations” (Stewart, 1990:31). In linguistics, the transformation adds, deletes, and permutes—for instance, transforming the a-sentences below into the b-sentences.

3

3

a 猫身上有一张垫子。

a A mat is on the cat.

 

 

b 猫身上有垫子。

b There is a mat on the cat.

4

4

a 土豚喜欢蚂蚁，它们也喜欢吉尼斯啤酒。

a Aardvarks like ants, and they like Guinness too.

 

 

b 土豚喜欢蚂蚁，吉尼斯也喜欢。

b Aardvarks like ants, and Guinness too.

5

5

弗洛伊德打破了玻璃。

a Floyd broke the glass.

 

 

b 玻璃被弗洛伊德打破了。

b The glass was broken by Floyd.

哈里斯希望这种转变有助于控制句法多样性。这是一种简单明了的工具，除了扩大范围、使第三级（也是最高级）语言分析井然有序之外，对一般的布隆菲尔德计划没有特别的影响。乔姆斯基希望这种转变的目的在他早期的著作中并不清楚，但他的精彩第一本书《句法结构》给人留下了这样的印象：他正在实现导师布隆菲尔德的意图。一开始，乔姆斯基就说

Harris wanted the transformation to help tame syntactic diversity. It was a tool, plain and simple, with no particular implications for the general Bloomfieldian program beyond a welcome increase in scope, bringing order to the third, and highest, level of linguistic analysis. What Chomsky wanted the transformation for isn’t at all clear in his earliest writings, but his brilliant first book, Syntactic Structures, leaves the impression that he is carrying out his mentor’s Bloomfieldian intentions. Right at the outset, Chomsky says

在整个研究期间，我受益匪浅，与泽利格·S·哈里斯进行了频繁而漫长的交谈。他的许多想法和建议都融入了下文及其所基于的研究中，因此我不会试图通过特别引用来指出它们。（1957a：6）

During the entire period of this research I have had the benefit of very frequent and lengthy conversations with Zellig S. Harris. So many of his ideas and suggestions are incorporated into the text below and in the research on which it is based that I will make no attempt to indicate them by special reference. (1957a:6)

乔姆斯基在承认这一点之后，又评论道：“哈里斯关于转换结构的研究……从一种略有不同的角度出发，哈里斯的观点与他自己的观点“略有不同”，书中也暗示了这种差异可能相当深刻。但“观点略有不同”是温和的，大多数语言学家认为《句法结构》 ——一个清晰、引人入胜、有说服力的论点，即转换是最有前途的句法工具——在很大程度上是对哈里斯理论的普及。（哈里斯可能是一位非常令人生畏的作家。）

Chomsky followed this acknowledgment with the observation that “Harris’ work on transformational structure … proceeds from a somewhat different point of view” than his own, and there are some hints in the book that the differences might run fairly deep. But “somewhat different point of view” is mild, and most linguists took Syntactic Structures—a lucid, engaging, persuasive argument that transformations are the most promising syntactic tool—largely as a popularization of Harris’s theories. (Harris can be a very forbidding author.)

乔姆斯基的贡献被认为是深远的，甚至是对布隆菲尔德语言学的革新——一篇评论称句法结构的目标在范围上是“哥白尼式的”（Voegelin，1958:229），而布洛赫“确信转换理论（或无论你想叫它什么）是语法思维的一个极其重要的进步”25 — 但并不具有威胁性。然而，短短几年内，语言学实际上就被冠上了一个新的名称兼形容词，即乔姆斯基主义，而那些被剥夺了权利的布鲁姆菲尔德派强烈谴责这种“科学的扭曲”、“英国化的束缚”、“毒蛇窝里滋生的理论”。一位布鲁姆菲尔德派恳求疲惫不堪的部队：“让我们停止客气，拒绝对异端的任何让步，回到语言学作为一门科学、一门人类学科学的立场上来。”二十六

Chomsky’s contributions were recognized as far-ranging, even renovating, for Bloomfieldian linguistics—one review called the goals of Syntactic Structures “Copernican” in scope (Voegelin, 1958:229), and Bloch was “convinced that transformational theory (or whatever you want to call it) is a tremendously important advance in grammatical thinking”25—but not threatening. Yet, in a few short years, linguistics effectively wore a new name-cum-adjective, Chomskyan, and the dispossessed Bloomfieldians were vehemently denouncing this “perversion of science,” this “Anglicizing straitjacket,” this “theory spawned by a nest of vipers.” “Let’s stop being polite,” one Bloomfieldian implored the flagging troops, “reject any concession to the heresy, and get back to linguistics as a science, an anthropological science.”26

他们确实不再客气了（事实上，在劝诫之前就已经这样做了），但为时已晚。异端已经成为正统。

They did stop being polite (in fact, somewhat before the exhortation), but it was too late. The heresy had become orthodoxy.

但是，在哈里斯的倡导、布洛赫的培育和豪斯霍尔德的采纳下，它是如何成为异端的呢？答案很简单，也是最全面的，那就是乔姆斯基改变了他对神圣的布隆菲尔德教会的修辞立场，从延伸到拒绝和取代。他不再只是大胆地将美国语言学带入句法领域，而美国语言学曾经不敢涉足这个领域，或者说，他非常胆怯地涉足这个领域；他系统地拆解了布隆菲尔德的纲领，并建立了自己的纲领来取而代之。他一个接一个地攻击了最近美国语言学的基础：行为主义、实证主义和描述性要求。他一个接一个地攻击了其具体理论的基石：不仅是其直接成分句法，还有其音系学、形态学和语言概念本身。他对布卢姆菲尔德主义架构的一些反对意见隐含在《句法结构》中——生成理论毕竟是一种知识理论、一种心智理论和一种心理结构理论——但许多反对意见是在该书出版后获得初步成功之后发展起来或揭示出来的。

But—sponsored by Harris, nurtured by Bloch, adopted by Householder—how did it become heresy in the first place? The simple answer, and the fullest one, is that Chomsky changed his rhetorical stance to the holy Bloomfieldian church from extension to rejection and replacement. He was no longer just taking American linguistics boldly into syntax, where it had once feared to tread, or had trod very timidly; he was systematically dismantling the Bloomfieldian program and erecting his own in its place. One by one, he attacked the foundations of recent American linguistics: behaviorism, positivism, and the descriptive mandate. One by one, he attacked the cornerstones of its specific theories: not just its Immediate Constituent syntax, but also its phonology, its morphology, and its very conception of language. Some of his opposition to the architecture of Bloomfieldianism was implicit in Syntactic Structures—a generative theory, after all, is a theory of knowledge; a theory of mind; a theory of mental structure—but many developed, or were revealed, after the first flushes of success that followed its publication.

这些新潮，正如新潮所常有的那样，出现在年轻人中，在布洛赫看来，“尤其是”那些“最聪明的人”（Murray，1980:79）。他们发现乔姆斯基具有电磁性，老一辈的语言学家因异端邪说而失去了他们的继承人。年轻的语言学家抛弃了布卢姆菲尔德的支柱——声音、词语和土著语言的描述——转而研究句法，甚至语义学，并深入研究一种语言，而不是广泛研究多种语言。保罗·波斯特尔就是一个典型的例子，他在布卢姆菲尔德的堡垒耶鲁大学对莫霍克语进行了博士研究，但他对此越来越不安：

Those flushes, as flushes are wont to do, came among the young, “especially,” in Bloch’s estimation, with “the most brilliant among them” (Murray, 1980:79). They found Chomsky electromagnetic and the older linguists lost their heirs to the heresy. Younger linguists deserted the Bloomfieldian mainstays—sounds, words, and the description of indigenous languages—to work on syntax, even on semantics, and to plunge deeply into one language, rather than looking broadly at many. The classic example is Paul Postal, who did his doctoral research on Mohawk in the Bloomfieldian citadel of Yale, but did it with a growing unease:

我心里一直有一种奇怪的感觉。我想我对所谓的语言学非常不满，但我不知道为什么，也不知道哪里错了，或者什么才是替代方案。在我看来，它可能是基于一些错误的假设，但我说不上来。

In the back of my mind had been this sense of strangeness. I guess I was pretty unhappy about what passed for linguistics, but I had no sense of why, or what was wrong, or what counted as an alternative. It seemed to me that it was probably based on some wrong assumptions, but I couldn’t put my finger on them.

然而，当乔姆斯基指出某些问题时，“似乎完全正确”。

When Chomsky put his finger on certain issues, though, “it seemed exactly right.”

布卢姆菲尔德派的普遍观点非常原始和愚蠢——包括严格收集数据和编目等想法。他们把这些当成科学，非常真诚，但又有点可悲。而且，据我们所知，这与现代科学毫无关联。

The general views [Bloomfieldians held] were very primitive and silly—ideas involving rigorous collection of data and cataloging, and all that kind of stuff. They took this to be science, very genuinely and kind of sadly. And, as far as one could see, this had no connection with what modern science was like.

乔姆斯基的科学观与当代科学哲学（现在几乎完全以实证主义为替罪羊）非常契合，这是他的计划最吸引人的特征之一。承诺了解意义是另一个。承诺了解思想也是另一个。这杯酒令人陶醉，顾客们排满了吧台。

Chomsky’s conception of science, which was closely in tune with contemporary philosophy of science (now invoking positivism almost exclusively as a whipping boy), was one of the most attractive features of his program. The promise of getting at meaning was another. The promise of getting at mind was another. The brew was intoxicating, and customers were lining the bar.

第三章

乔姆斯基革命

CHAPTER 3

The Chomskyan Revolution

在四十年代末期……在很多人看来，句法的征服终于摆在了这个职业的面前。

In the late forties … it seemed to many that the conquest of syntax finally lay open before the profession.

五十年代初，人们信心高涨。许多语言学家认为，需要对这一学科进行新的综合，而合适的时机很快就要到来了。考虑到过去二十年取得的成果，这将延续布卢姆菲尔德的传统。事实上，有人谈到需要“修订布卢姆菲尔德”，不是替代，而是更新。然而，没有人觉得能够承担这项任务。

At the beginning of the fifties confidence was running high. Many linguists felt that a new synthesis of the discipline was needed and that a suitable time was rapidly approaching. This would continue the Bloomfield tradition taking into account the results achieved in two decades. Indeed, some spoke of the need for a “revision of Bloomfield,” not a replacement but an updating. No one, however, felt able to undertake the task.

H.艾伦·格里森

H. Allan Gleason

我们必须将句法结构理论拓展到我们熟悉的范围之外。

We shall have to carry the theory of syntactic structure a good deal beyond its familiar limits.

诺姆·乔姆斯基

Noam Chomsky

寻找好结构先生

Looking for Mr. Goodstructure

在阅读语言史时，20 世纪 50 年代的布隆菲尔德派一直在等待某种令人信服的完整模型来取代他们的语言图景。布隆菲尔德语法构造的“最辉煌”之作是特雷格和史密斯的《英语结构大纲》（Stark，1972：414）。它既是特雷格早期经典著作（与布洛赫合著）《语言分析大纲》的重写版，又是其实际应用。由于该书应用于英语，因此具有巨大的教育优势，并且是该计划的自觉典范，通过实例说明了“一种我们认为代表科学方法应用于社会科学——语言学的分析和表达方法”（特雷格和史密斯，1957 [1951]：7）。这本书很简短。它有望在句法方面取得重大进展；即使——这被归入一个标记为元语言学的关注领域——在意义方面。布卢姆菲尔德学派的成立反映了该领域日益增长的信心，同时也是布卢姆菲尔德学派在学术界展现其最佳一面的一次刻意尝试：“教育家、外交官、人类学家和其他人被承诺将形成一门严谨、核心、广泛且实用的语言学。”（Hymes and Fought，1981 [1974]：138）但正如每个人都看到的，布卢姆菲尔德学派的这一承诺被泄露了。

In one reading of linguistic history, the Bloomfieldians of the 1950s were biding their time for some convincingly complete model to displace their picture of language. The “fullest flowering” of Bloomfieldian grammar-construction was Trager and Smith’s Outline of English Structure (Stark, 1972:414). It was at once a reworking and a practical application of Trager’s earlier classic (with Bloch), Outline of Linguistic Analysis. Since the application was to English, it had enormous educational advantages, and it was a self-conscious exemplar of the program, illustrating by example “a methodology of analysis and presentation that we believe to be representative of the scientific method as applied to a social science—linguistics” (Trager and Smith, 1957 [1951]:7). It was brief. It promised significant inroads into syntax; even—though this was relegated to an area of concern labeled metalinguistics—into meaning. Reflecting the growing confidence of the field, it was also a deliberate attempt to put the best Bloomfieldian foot forward into the scholarly world at large: “Educators, diplomats, anthropologists, and others were presented with a promise of a linguistics that was rigorous, central, expanding, and useful” (Hymes and Fought, 1981 [1974]:138). But, as everyone could see, it leaked.

在德克萨斯州举行的第一届英语语言分析问题会议上，与会者就科学进步展开了讨论，其中就提到了其一些缺点。范式转变突然出现，阿奇博尔德·希尔向同事们讲述了科学在这种情况下是如何运作的：

Some of its weaknesses came up for discussion at the first Texas Conference on Problems of Linguistic Analysis in English, when the participants fell into a discussion about scientific progress. Paradigm shifts cropped up, and Archibald Hill told his colleagues how science works in such circumstances:

当事物不合适时，科学家会努力通过添加、移除或重新排列来修补系统。只有当一个完整的新系统出现，一个比旧系统更完整、更一致、整体更简单的系统出现时，才会产生真正的改变。（1962a [1956]：17）

When things don’t fit, scientists labor to patch up the system by adding things, taking them away, or rearranging. It is only when a complete new system is presented, a system more complete, more consistent, and simpler in its totality than the old system, that any real change is made. (1962a [1956]:17)

显而易见的类比出现了——托勒密到哥白尼的宇宙学转变——特拉格和史密斯处于托勒密的困境之中。詹姆斯·斯莱德是讨论者之一，也是特拉格和史密斯的《大纲》的直言不讳的批评者，他只能对他们的模型进行讽刺性的称赞：

The obvious analogy surfaced—the Ptolemaic-to-Copernican cosmological shift—with Trager and Smith in Ptolemy’s hot seat. James Sledd, one of the discussants and an outspoken critic of Trager and Smith’s Outline, could only manage a backhanded compliment for their model:

特雷格-史密斯体系的最大优势在于它具有完整性要求，希尔先生说得对，如果我们想推翻特雷格-史密斯体系，我们只能采用一个更合理的完整性要求体系。（希尔 1962a [1956]：17）

The great strength of the Trager-Smith system is that it has pretensions to completeness, and Mr. Hill is right that if we want to overthrow the Trager-Smith system we can do it only with a system which has more justifiable pretensions to completeness. (Hill 1962a [1956]:17)

这种交流看起来似乎是科学发展历史阶段的一种症状，托马斯·库恩称之为危机，即科学经历“一段明显的专业不安全时期”，这是革命的前奏（1970:67f）。库恩说，危机中的科学是一门试图摆脱引起其不安全感的任何程序的科学，寻求一种新的、比旧系统更完整、更一致、更简单的系统，以恢复一些信心，在许多方面，寻求救世主。

This exchange looks for all the world like a symptom of the historical stage in the growth of a science that Thomas Kuhn calls a crisis, when the science goes through “a period of pronounced professional insecurity,” the prelude to a revolution (1970:67f). A science in crisis, says Kuhn, is a science looking to shuck whatever program gave rise to its insecurity, looking for a new, more complete, more consistent, more simple system than the old one, to give it back some confidence, looking, in many ways, for a messiah.

也许语言学作为一个抽象的集体实体，正在寻找救世主。随后发生的事件也表明了这一点——特别是，它们表明存在一些代际不满，年轻成员急于获得被搁置了 25 年的好东西，即意义和思想。但这段时期的文献中几乎没有迹象表明任何方面都存在危机，而德克萨斯州的这次交流肯定不是救世主渴望的表现。除了斯莱德（他把想要推翻特雷格和史密斯的话塞进希尔的嘴里），会议上没有人认真谈论要废除特雷格和史密斯的模型——评论更多的是修补它——也没有丝毫对支持他们模型的布卢姆菲尔德计划感到沮丧的迹象。事实上，刚刚与特雷格交谈过的罗伯特·斯托克韦尔 (Robert Stockwell) 传递了一个好消息，即在德克萨斯州讨论者发言的同时，大纲正在朝着有望满足该系统部分要求的方向进行全面修改。特雷格和史密斯的目标是更加完整。词形过程（形态学）将得到更多关注，而且“语法将得到彻底重做和大幅扩展。”这种语法，即音系语法，在 50 年代早期和中期的会议上大获成功，吸引了许多追随者，尤其是渴望获得新材料的年轻语言学家。顾名思义，它系统地建立在非常有吸引力的布卢姆菲尔德音系学基础上，代表了该领域自然而理想的扩展：最好的渐进式科学。

And perhaps linguistics, as an abstract and collective entity, was looking for a savior. Subsequent events suggest as much—in particular, they suggest there was some generational discontent, with younger members impatient to get at the good stuff that had been kept at bay for twenty-five years, meaning and mind. But there is little indication in the literature of the period that there was a crisis on any front, and this exchange in Texas is certainly not a symptom of messianic longings. Aside from Sledd (who was putting words in Hill’s mouth about wanting to overthrow Trager and Smith), there was no serious talk of doing away with Trager and Smith’s model at the conference—the comments are more on the order of patching it up—and not the slightest hint of frustration at the Bloomfieldian program underwriting their model. Indeed, Robert Stockwell, who had just been talking with Trager, passed on the good news that the Outline was, even as the Texas discussants spoke, being overhauled in a direction which promised to satisfy some of the system’s pretensions. Trager and Smith were aiming for a good deal more completeness. Wordformation processes (morphology) were to get increased attention, and “the syntax, further, will be completely redone and much expanded.” This syntax, phonological syntax, played very well at conferences in the early and mid-fifties, attracting a good many adherents, especially among younger linguists eager to get at new material. As the name implies, it built systematically on the very attractive base of Bloomfieldian phonology, representing the natural and desired expansion of the field: incremental science at its best.

20 世纪 50 年代，语言学发生了变化，发展迅速，对核心原则的异议时有发生，对其他方法的容忍度增加，在心理学这个禁忌领域也有些调情。但至少在这种情况下，适度的异议、多元化和探索与库恩对危机的定义完全相反。它们是强烈的职业安全感的症状。早先对欧洲、意义和思想的敌意，对方法的过度崇敬，以及“我是科学家而你不是”的豪言壮语：这些都是不安全感的迹象。到了 50 年代，偏执的攻击性已经让位于一种平静的满足和乐观（在某些方面，正如我们所见，甚至让位于一种几乎悲观的乐观，认为所有真正的问题都已得到解决）。布卢姆菲尔德的另一部重要法典是泽利格·哈里斯（Zellig Harris，1951 [1947]）的《结构语言学方法》，出版时间与特拉格和史密斯相差无几，该书被誉为“双重意义上的划时代著作：首先，它标志着语言学方法论的发展已达到顶峰，摆脱了直觉主义的阶段，而直觉主义往往受文化的束缚；其次，它标志着一个新时代的开始，在这个新时代，新方法将更加严格地应用于越来越广泛的领域”（McQuown，1952：495）。辉煌的进步时期可能已经结束，但建立在这些进步之上的新的、更辉煌的进步时期才刚刚开始。

Linguistics was changing and expanding in the fifties, showing sporadic dissent over the central tenets, increased tolerance for other approaches, and some dalliance in the banned domain of psychology. But measured dissent, pluralism, and exploration, at least in this case, represent the exact opposite of Kuhn’s definition of crisis. They were symptoms of a pronounced sense of professional security. The earlier hostility toward Europe, and meaning, and mind, and the undue reverence for method, and the chest-thumping war cries of “I’m a scientist and you’re not”: these were the signs of insecurity. By the fifties, paranoid aggressiveness had given way to a quiet satisfaction and optimism (in some quarters, as we have seen, to an almost gloomy optimism that all the real problems had been solved). The other major Bloomfieldian codification published in the fifties, off the presses almost in a dead heat with Trager and Smith, was Zellig Harris’s (1951 [1947]) Methods in Structural Linguistics and it was hailed as “epoch-marking in a double sense: first in that it marks the culmination of a development of linguistic methodology away from a stage of intuitionism, frequently culture-bound; and second in that it marks the beginning of a new period, in which the new methods will be applied ever more rigorously to ever widening areas” (McQuown, 1952:495). A glorious period of advancement may have been over, but a new and more glorious one, building on those advances, was just beginning.

在这种氛围下，《句法结构》问世了，该书于第一届德克萨斯会议后一年出版。这本书再适合不过了。它冷静而坚定地呼吁一种新的科学观念。它承诺彻底改造句法。它优雅地走在所指的钢丝上——支持布卢姆菲尔德的论点，即不能让它们玷污对能指的分析，但提供了有说服力的建议，即语言学家无论如何都可以理解其含义。

Into this atmosphere came Syntactic Structures, published the year after the First Texas Conference. It couldn’t have fit the mood better. It appeals calmly and insistently to a new conception of science. It promises the transformational taming of syntax. And it elegantly walks the tightrope of the signified—supporting Bloomfield’s argument that they couldn’t be allowed to taint the analysis of signifiers, but offering persuasive suggestions that linguists could get at meaning anyway.

乔姆斯基的书受到了欢迎。但它并没有被视为一个全新的、更一致、更简单的、将彻底改变语言学的体系的到来——这一点在那个时期的历史中经常被忽略。乔姆斯基并没有被誉为救世主，至少不是立刻。首先，《句法结构》几乎没有提到旧体系的堡垒、声音和词语。但更重要的是，它对布隆菲尔德上层建筑的影响几乎完全被淹没了。乔姆斯基的计划看起来更像是布隆菲尔德主义的稳步扩张，越来越严格，领域也越来越广；更何况乔姆斯基是哈里斯最宠爱的儿子，哈里斯是划时代的《方法》一书的作者。1

Chomsky’s book was welcomed. But it was not—and this point is often missed in histories of the period—taken to herald the arrival of a complete new system, more consistent and simpler, that would revolutionize linguistics. Chomsky was not hailed as the messiah, not immediately. For one thing, Syntactic Structures had virtually nothing to say about the old system’s strongholds, sounds and words. But more importantly, its implications for the Bloomfieldian superstructure were almost entirely submerged. Chomsky’s program looked much more like the projected steady expansion of Bloomfieldianism, ever more rigorous, to ever-widening areas; all the more so as Chomsky was the favored son of Harris, author of the double-epoch-marking Methods.1

不久，乔姆斯基和他的同事们开始谈论探索心理结构；然后出现了一种新的音系学；然后该领域又有了一套明确的新目标，现在它已经完全脱离了人类学的根源，与一种新的心理学紧密相连。到了 60 年代初，很明显，旧事物必须被新事物取代。这些最新的发展——大部分伴随着对布卢姆菲尔德派的一个或多个神圣不可侵犯的事物的一致打击——让大多数老派语言学家有些措手不及。他们对此的反应是困惑、痛苦和无效的愤怒。很快，乔姆斯基的整套思想席卷了整个领域。根深蒂固的布卢姆菲尔德派并不在寻找救世主，但显然，他们的许多学生在寻找。一场革命来了。

Soon there was talk from Chomsky and his associates about plumbing mental structure; then there was a new phonology; then there was an explicitly new set of goals for the field, cut off now completely from its anthropological roots and hitched to a new brand of psychology.
