By this point, in the early sixties, it was clear that the old would have to be scrapped for the new. These last developments—accompanied for the most part with concerted beatings of one or more of the Bloomfieldians’ sacred cows—caught most of the old-line linguists somewhat unawares. They reacted with confusion, bitterness, and ineffective rage. Rapidly, the whole kit and kaboodle of Chomsky’s ideas swept the field. The entrenched Bloomfieldians were not looking for a messiah, but, apparently, many of their students were. There was a revolution.

句法结构

Syntactic Structures

乔姆斯基的《句法结构》是一本引人注目、独具匠心的书，它迫使读者从新的角度看待熟悉的事物。但在采取这种观点时，他并没有摧毁前辈对语言结构的基本概念。相反，他赋予了它新的生命。

Chomsky’s Syntactic Structures is a striking and original book, which forced its readers to look at familiar things from a fresh angle. But in taking this view, he did not destroy his predecessors’ basic concept of the structure of language. Rather he gave new life to it.

PH 马修斯

P. H. Matthews

在 20 世纪 50 年代，用一位过气的布隆菲尔德学派成员的话来说，乔姆斯基是“一位非常反常的年轻语言学家”（Gleason，1988：59）。他有点像局外人，总是能看出既定计划的局限性和弱点。他几乎完全是通过哈里斯接触这个领域的，哈里斯是布隆菲尔德学派的正式成员，但在极端情况下，他在许多方面代表了该计划的最好和最坏。他对深奥的（如果不是边缘的话）问题很执着，对方法论的关注甚至远远超过了他的同时代人。作为布卢姆菲尔德派的代表，他的背景也有些不寻常 — — 他并非来自撸起袖子、松开衣领的人类学世界，而是来自书生气十足、逻辑性极强的闪族语言学世界 — — 而且，除了霍克特，他是当时唯一一位追求索绪尔将语言视为“刚性系统”的自然但基本上被忽视的影响的语言学家，也是当时唯一一位认真探索语言数学的语言学家。 乔姆斯基的教育背景与哈里斯的兴趣非常吻合。他所受的教育涉及哲学、逻辑和数学方面的工作，远远超出了语言学家的正常训练。他在认识论方面读得更深入，在这个领域，对布卢姆菲尔德派的大禁忌——心理结构的推测不仅是合理的，而且是不可避免的。他的荣誉论文和硕士论文是巧妙的、独特的希伯来语语法，而且 — — 在获得博士学位的时候。语言学论文几乎从定义上来说就是某种本土语言的语法，田野调查几乎是进入语言学家群体的入会仪式——他的博士学位是基于对转换语法的高度抽象的讨论而授予的，数据完全来自英语。1955 年夏天，当他的论文在语言研究所流传时，它看起来完全是异类，“其推理比任何被贴上‘语言学’标签的论文都更具数学性”，而且不出所料，它完全没有效果：

For the 1950s, Chomsky was, in the terms of one lapsed Bloomfieldian, “a very aberrant young linguist” (Gleason, 1988:59). He was something of an outsider, always an advantage for seeing the limitations and weaknesses of an established program. His exposure to the field came almost entirely through Harris, and Harris was a card-carrying Bloomfieldian, but in extremis, representing, in many ways, the best and the worst of the program. He had a fixation on esoteric, if not peripheral, issues, and a preoccupation with methodology which far outstripped even that of his contemporaries. He, too, had a somewhat unusual background for a Bloomfieldian—coming not from the rolled-up-sleeves-and-loosened-collar world of anthropology, but the bookish, intensely logical world of Semitic philology—and, except for Hockett, he was the only linguist of the period pursuing the natural, but largely ignored, ramifications of the Saussurean conception of langue as a “rigid system,” the only linguist of the period seriously exploring the mathematics of language. Chomsky’s education reflected Harris’s interests closely. It involved work in philosophy, logic, and mathematics well beyond the normal training for a linguist. He read more deeply in epistemology, an area where speculation about the great Bloomfieldian taboo, mental structure, is not only legitimate, but inescapable. His honors and master’s theses were clever, idiosyncratic grammars of Hebrew, and—at a time when a Ph.D. thesis in linguistics was almost by definition a grammar of some indigenous language, fieldwork virtually an initiation rite into the community of linguists—his doctorate was granted on the basis of a highly abstract discussion of transformational grammar, with data drawn exclusively from English. When his thesis made the rounds at the Linguistic Institute in the summer of 1955, it looked completely alien, “far more mathematical in its reasoning than anyone there had ever seen labeled as ‘linguistics’,” and, predictably, it fell utterly flat:

一些语言学家认为这非常困难；大多数认为这完全不可能。少数人认为其中的一些观点可能很有趣；大多数人根本不知道它与他们所知道的语言学有什么关系。（Gleason，1988：59，60）

A few linguists found it very difficult; most found it quite impossible. A few thought some of the points were possibly interesting; most simply had no idea as to how it might relate to what they knew as linguistics. (Gleason, 1988:59, 60)

当然，这就是阻碍他思想被接受的障碍，也是语言学家们难以接受的障碍：如何使他的著作为语言学家所接受。他的论文《转换分析》不仅技术性极强，而且与布卢姆菲尔德派语言学家的日常活动完全无关。而且，这只是他 50 年代早期在哈佛大学攻读奖学金期间，狂热地撰写的巨作《语言理论的逻辑结构》中的一章。 《逻辑结构》的几份油印本随处可见，但这本书大多是靠传闻而为人所知，带有斯宾诺莎、皮尔斯或维特根斯坦的气息。或者是其他富有创造力、数学性强、极其理性但又与世隔绝的思想。乔姆斯基的思想，如果真的被人看待，一定和克里克回忆起他 DNA 结构合作者的感觉一样：“在大多数圈子里，沃森被认为太聪明了，不太可靠”（1988:76）。

That was, of course, the rub, the dragging friction on any acceptance of his ideas: how to make his work palatable to linguists. His thesis—“Transformational Analysis”—was not only forbiddingly technical, but completely unrelated to the daily activities of Bloomfieldian linguists. And it was only one chapter of a massive manuscript—The Logical Structure of Linguistic Theory—he had feverishly worked up while on a fellowship to Harvard in the early fifties. A few copies of Logical Structure were available here and there in mimeograph, but it was known mostly by rumor, and had the whiff of Spinoza or Pierce or Wittgenstein about it, or some other fecund, mathematical, relentlessly rational, but cloistered mind. Chomsky must have been considered, when considered at all, somewhat the way Crick recalls the feeling about his collaborator on the structure of DNA: “Watson was regarded, in most circles, as too bright to be really sound” (1988:76).

凭借这种特殊背景，尽管乔姆斯基才华横溢，但他并不是美国语言学系的理想人选，他最终进入麻省理工学院电子研究实验室工作。他的研究没有固定期限，因此他可以继续进行抽象的语言建模，但这份工作只是部分工作，他必须教授德语、法语、哲学、逻辑学，以及语言学，才能增加收入。由于没有人告诉他其他情况（麻省理工学院没有语言学系），他只教授语言学，这门课程的讲义成为解决《逻辑结构》（为乔姆斯基语言学家编写，当时只有乔姆斯基一人）的读者与该领域其他所有人之间的修辞鸿沟的答案。

With this particular background, Chomsky was not, despite acknowledged brilliance, the ideal candidate for a job in an American linguistics department, and found himself in the Research Laboratory of Electronics of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His research was open-ended, allowing him to continue his abstract modeling of language, but the appointment was only partial and he had to teach to round out his income: German, French, philosophy, logic. And linguistics. Since there was no one there to tell him otherwise (MIT had no linguistics department), he taught his linguistics, and the lecture notes for this course became the answer to the rhetorical gulf between the audience for Logical Structure (written for Chomskyan linguists when there was only one, Chomsky) and everyone else in the field.

这些注释经过修订并作为《句法结构》出版，是语言学的杰作之一。它清晰、令人信服、句法大胆，是理性的冷静之声，来自布卢姆菲尔德驱赶其追随者远离的语义丛林边缘，它直接呼唤着整个领域的想象力和雄心。最雄心勃勃的年轻人（即使不是最有想象力的年轻人）反应最充分，但邀请是向所有人开放的，布卢姆菲尔德人发现它的许多方面都非常吸引人。

These notes, revised and published as Syntactic Structures, constitute one of the masterpieces of linguistics. Lucid, convincing, syntactically daring, the calm voice of reason calling from the edge of a semantic jungle Bloomfield had shooed his followers from, it spoke directly to the imagination and ambition of the entire field. The most ambitious, if not always the most imaginative—the young—responded most fully, but the invitation was open to all and the Bloomfieldians found many aspects of it very appealing.

科学与生成语法

Science and Generative Grammar

我所说的生成语法只是一套规则系统，它以某种明确而明确的方式为句子分配结构描述。……也许可以通过与化学理论中与结构上可能的化合物有关的部分进行类比来澄清这个问题。可以说，该理论生成了所有物理上可能的化合物，就像语法生成了所有语法上“可能”的话语一样。

By a generative grammar I mean simply a system of rules that in some explicit and well-defined way assigns structural descriptions to sentences. … Perhaps the issue can be clarified by an analogy to a part of chemical theory concerned with the structurally possible compounds. This theory might be said to generate all physically possible compounds just as a grammar generates all gramatically ‘possible’ utterances.

诺姆·乔姆斯基

Noam Chomsky

布隆菲尔德学派尤其喜欢乔姆斯基在《句法结构》中提出的科学概念。该书的前几句话提出并捍卫了语言学的概念，即建立“精确构造的模型”的活动（1957a:5），而建立精确构造的模型是布隆菲尔德语言学的支柱（尽管他们更喜欢使用描述这个词而不是模型）。但乔姆斯基也使这种构造背后的动机比以前更加明确。他说，有两个动机。一个动机是消极的：给“模糊和直觉束缚的概念”一个严格的表述可以迅速找出潜在的困难。另一个动机是积极的：“形式化的理论可以自动为许多问题提供解决方案，而不是它明确设计的问题”（1957a:5）。简而言之，语法的清晰和精确的表述具有两个最重要的属性，它们建议一种科学理论优于另一种科学理论，其脆弱性和适用范围都会扩大。如果你能推翻一种科学理论，那么它就是好的理论，因为这意味着它与一些数据有明确且可测试的联系；如果你能在原则上推翻它，但在实践中推翻它，那就更好了，因为它不仅可以用数据来测试，而且测试证明它与数据兼容。你可以通过扔下一支笔并测量它的下落来测试引力定律；如果它向上漂浮，或向侧面飞去，或缓慢落到地面，那么这个定律就有问题了。但笔永远不会这样（除非你在某个奇怪的地方，比如太空舱或离心室，这时赌注必须改变），所以引力在原则上是脆弱的，在实践中是有弹性的。理论覆盖的范围越广，它就越有效。引力定律（或多或少）同样适用于下落的笔和绕轨道运行的行星。针对这些现象的两条定律，而不是一条定律，会把事情搞得一团糟，科学家们喜欢尽可能地保持整洁。

Especially attractive to the Bloomfieldians was the conception of science Chomsky offered in Syntactic Structures. The first few sentences of the book advance and defend the conception of linguistics as an activity which builds “precisely constructed models” (1957a:5), and building precisely constructed models was the mainstay of Bloomfieldian linguistics (though they were happier with the word description than with model). But Chomsky also made the motives behind such construction much more explicit than they previously had been. There are two, he says. One motive is negative: giving “obscure and intuition-bound notions” a strict formulation can quickly ferret out latent difficulties. The other is positive: “a formalized theory may automatically provide solutions for many problems other than those for which it was explicitly designed” (1957a:5). In short, the clear and precise formulation of a grammar has the two most important attributes that recommend one scientific theory over another, greater fragility and increased scope. If you can break a scientific theory, it’s a good one, since that means it has clear and testable connections to some body of data; if you can break it in principle but not in practice, so much the better, since not only can it be tested against data, the testing proves it compatible with that data. The law of gravity you can test by dropping a pen and measuring its descent; if it floats upwards, or zips sideways, or falls slowly to the ground, then the law is in trouble. But the pen never does (unless you’re someplace weird, like a space capsule or a centrifugal chamber, when the bets have to change), so gravity is fragile in principle, resilient in practice. And the more coverage a theory has, the more efficient it is. The law of gravity is (more or less) equally applicable to falling pens and orbiting planets. Two laws for those phenomena, rather than one, mess things up, and scientists like to be tidy whenever they can.

两个定义对于乔姆斯基实现这些科学美德至关重要：语言是“一组（有限的或无限的）句子”，语法是“一种生成[该语言]所有语法序列而不生成任何不合语法序列的装置”（1957a：13）：语法是一种形式模型，它预测哪些词串属于构成一种语言的句子集，哪些词串不属于。2那么，适当的英语语法将生成序列 1，但不会生成序列 2（因此，按照现在的标准语言实践，序列 2 被加上前面的星号）。

Two definitions are crucial for Chomsky to achieve these scientific virtues: a language is “a set (finite or infinite) of sentences” and a grammar is “a device that generates all of the grammatical sequences of [that language] and none of the ungrammatical ones” (1957a:13): a grammar is a formal model that predicts which strings of words belong in the set of sentences constituting a language and which strings do not belong.2 An adequate grammar of English, then, would generate sequence 1, but not sequence 2 (which is therefore stigmatized with a preceding asterisk, following the now-standard linguistic practice).

1 肯尼是一个很酷的家伙。

1 Kenny is one cool guy.

2 *很酷的那个是 Kenny

2 *guy cool one is Kenny

现在，根据乔姆斯基的定义，一种旨在生成一种语言中可能出现的所有句子集的语法——生成语法——是一种科学语法：

Now, a grammar which aspires to generate all and only the set of sentences possible in a language—a generative grammar—by Chomsky’s definition, is a scientific grammar:

L 语言的 [生成] 语法本质上是 L 的理论。任何科学理论都基于有限数量的观察，并试图通过构建假设结构（例如物理学中的“质量”和“电子”）的一般定律来关联观察到的现象。同样，英语语法基于有限的话语语料库（观察），它将包含以英语的特定音素、短语等（假设结构）陈述的某些语法规则（定律）。这些规则表达了我们语料库中的句子与语料库之外的语法生成的无限数量的句子之间的结构关系（预测）。（1957a:49）3

A [generative] grammar of the Language L is essentially a theory of L. Any scientific theory is based on a finite number of observations, and it seeks to relate the observed phenomena by constructing general laws in terms of hypothetical constructs such as (in physics, for example) “mass” and “electron.” Similarly, a grammar of English is based on a finite corpus of utterances (observations), and it will contain certain grammatical rules (laws) stated in terms of the particular phonemes, phrases, etc., of English (hypothetical constructs). These rules express structural relations among the sentences of our corpus and the indefinite number of sentences generated by the grammar beyond the corpus (predictions). (1957a:49)3

除了这种极具吸引力的语法和理论的等同，乔姆斯基还提出了一种新的科学哲学。到 1957 年，科学哲学发生了很大变化，布鲁姆菲尔德支持的实证主义从几乎完全占据主导地位沦落为一种不敢直言不讳的方法——1957 年美国哲学协会主席致辞的主题是“为 L*G*C*LP*S*T*V*SM 辩护”（Rynin，1957 年）。

Beyond this very attractive identification of grammar and theory, Chomsky also offered a new philosophy of science. By 1957 philosophy of science had shifted considerably, and Bloomfield-endorsed positivism had sunk from almost complete dominance to an approach that dared not speak its name—the 1957 presidential address to the American Philosophical Association was “Vindication of L*G*C*L P*S*T*V*SM” (Rynin, 1957).

方法论的烦恼已声名狼藉，现在唯一重要的是结果，不管结果如何。语言学应该通过“直觉、猜测、各种部分方法论提示、对过去经验的依赖等”来继续发展，这是乔姆斯基对这种新的方法论冷漠的阐述。（1957a:56）语言学家作为科学家最关心的问题应该是语法一旦形成是否站得住脚。

Methodological fretting had fallen into disrepute and all that now counted was the results, however obtained. Linguistics should proceed, went Chomsky’s articulation of this new methodological indifference, by way of “intuition, guess-work, all sorts of partial methodological hints, reliance on past experience, etc.” (1957a:56). The crucial interests of linguists qua science should be those revolving around whether the grammar stands up once it has been formulated.

它能生成 L 的句子吗？它能排除 L 的非句子吗？它符合脆弱性、优雅性和普遍性等既定的科学约束吗？

Does it generate the sentences of L? Does it preclude non-sentences of L? Does it fit established scientific constraints like fragility, elegance, and generality?

此举对那些关心此类事情的布隆菲尔德派（比如特雷格和霍尔）来说，有一定的敌意，毫无疑问，有些人认为乔姆斯基在方法论上的冷漠令人反感 — — 甚至用我们熟悉的脏话来说，是不科学的。但大多数语言学家并不太在意这类基础问题。更重要的是，《句法结构》并没有以对抗的口吻来阐述其科学哲学。事实上，它采用的框架不禁迎合了布隆菲尔德派的科学爱好 — — 将他们主要关注的语法定义为与物理或化学理论相提并论。从布隆菲尔德派的角度来看，乔姆斯基是在证实和阐述他们关于什么是好的科学的观点。

There is a measure of antagonism in this move for those Bloomfieldians who cared about such things (Trager and Hall, for instance), and some no doubt found Chomsky’s methodological nonchalance distasteful—even, in the familiar curseword, unscientific. But most linguists weren’t very troubled by foundational issues of this sort. More importantly, Syntactic Structures doesn’t frame its philosophy of science in antagonistic terms. It comes, in fact, in a frame that couldn’t help but appeal to the Bloomfieldians’ scientific fondness—defining their principal concern, grammars, as on a par with physical or chemical theories. Chomsky was, from a Bloomfieldian perspective, confirming and elaborating their notions of what makes for good science.

他们中的大多数人没有注意到（尽管他们的学生注意到了），乔姆斯基彻底改变了语言学的重点——从发现好的语法到证明和评价它们。语言学从一项主要的描述性事业转变为一项旨在探索描述背后的一般原理的理论事业。4

What most of them didn’t notice (though their students did) is that Chomsky changed the focus of linguistics radically—from discovering good grammars to justifying and evaluating them. Linguistics was slipping from a primarily descriptive enterprise into a theoretical enterprise directed toward exploring the general principals underlying descriptions.4

句法和转换语法

Syntax and Transformational Grammar

我发现自己与哈里斯和乔姆斯基的观点主要在一些我认为是次要的观点上存在分歧：我很高兴看到语法在新格式下做得很好。

I find myself differing with Harris and Chomsky chiefly on points that I regard as minor: I am glad to see syntax done well in a new format.

拉尔夫·B·朗

Ralph B. Long

到目前为止，《句法结构》对布卢姆菲尔德派最有吸引力的方面是其名义上承诺将结构主义方案推进到句法领域。乔姆斯基的第一步是将直接成分分析转化为更易于测试的形式。直接成分分析是一套“异质且不完整的方法”（Wells，1947b：81），它已开始固化为更系统的句法结构理论——最有吸引力的是特雷格和史密斯的音系句法——但距离乔姆斯基的生成语法概念所要求的严格形式主义还很远。从相对松散的直接成分程序组中，乔姆斯基提取了一种基于变量和箭头的符号，这样一条简单的规则（如 X → Y + Z）就以一种易于图解的方式定义了变量之间的关系；即，以图 3.1所示的方式。

By far the most attractive aspect of Syntactic Structures for the Bloomfieldians was its titular promise to advance the structuralist program into syntax. Chomsky’s first step was to translate Immediate Constituent analysis into a more testable format. Immediate Constituent analysis was a body of “heterogeneous and incomplete methods” (Wells, 1947b:81), which had begun hardening into a more systematic theory of syntactic structure—most attractively in the phonological syntax of Trager and Smith—but was still a long way from the rigid formalism called for by Chomsky’s notion of generative grammar. Out of the relatively loose group of Immediate Constituent procedures, Chomsky extracted a notation based on variables and arrows such that a simple rule like X → Y + Z defined the relations among the variables in an easily diagrammable way; that is, in the way illustrated by figure 3.1.

根据这种符号，乔姆斯基建立了以下类型的英语规则体系。5

From this notation, Chomsky built a rule system for English of the following sort.5

3

3

一个 S → NP + VP

a S → NP + VP

 

 

b NP → Det + N

b NP → Det + N

 

 

c VP → V + NP

c VP → V + NP

 

 

d 检测→

d Det → the

 

 

e N → {狗，小鸭，三明治，农夫，词缀...}

e N → {dog, duckling, sandwich, farmer, affix…}

 

 

f V → {咬，追，跳，杀，被动…}

f V → {bite, chase, hop, kill, passivize…}

图 3.1 . 由正式规则 x → y + z 生成的抽象层次关系图。

Figure 3.1. A diagram of the abstract, hierarchical relationship generated by the formal rule, x → y + z.

3 中的符号都是助记符：S代表句子，NP代表名词短语，VP代表动词短语，等等。（唯一一个可能无法从小学语言知识中立即看出的符号是Det，它代表限定词，并且对于我们的目的来说并不是特别重要；它在这里的主要功能是帮助识别名词短语的成员之一，即3d所指定的。）那么，这些规则就是对句子、名词短语和动词短语如何组合在一起的描述。它们表达了关于英语句法的概念，例如“句子有名词短语和动词短语，按此顺序”（用更传统的术语来说，句子有主语和谓语），以及“动词是咬和追之类的东西”。

The symbols in 3 are all mnemonic: S stands for sentence, NP for noun phrase, VP for verb phrase, and so on. (The only one that may not be immediately apparent from a grade-school knowledge of language, Det, stands for determiner, and isn’t especially important for our purposes; its main function here is to help identify one of the members of noun phrases—namely, the, as specified by 3d.) The rules, then, are descriptions of how sentences, noun phrases, and verb phrases hang together. They express such notions about the syntax of English as “sentences have noun phrases and verb phrases, in that order” (in more traditional terms, sentences have subjects and predicates), and “verbs are such things as bite and chase.”

当然， 3 规则——短语结构规则——只涵盖了英语句法的极小部分，但它们方便地说明了直接成分分析（或乔姆斯基重新命名为短语结构语法）最有效地处理的表达类型。考虑一下它们是如何工作的。每条规则都是一条指令，要求将箭头左边的符号重写为箭头右边的符号，从而得出一个句子的推导，其含义与微积分中的单词完全相同。以图形方式表示这种推导，我们得到现代语言学中无处不在的树状图（或短语标记），如 PM-1 所示（其中，S 支配 NP 和 VP，如规则 3a 所要求的；NP 支配 Det 和 N，如规则 3b 所要求的；N在一个例子中支配duckling ，在另一个例子中支配farmer，如规则 3e 所允许的；等等）。

The rules of 3—phrase structure rules—cover only the tiniest portion of English syntax, of course, but they illustrate conveniently the type of expressions that Immediate Constituent Analysis (or, in Chomsky’s rechristening, phrase structure grammar) handles most efficiently. Consider how they work. Each rule is an instruction to rewrite the symbol to the left of the arrow as the symbol(s) to the right of the arrow, yielding a derivation of a sentence in exactly the sense that word has in calculus. Representing this derivation graphically, we get a tree diagram (or phrase marker) of the sort that has become ubiquitous in modern linguistics, illustrated by PM–1 (where S dominates NP and VP, as called for by rule 3a; NP dominates Det and N, as called for by 3b; N dominates duckling in one instance, farmer in another, as allowed by 3e; and so on).

乔姆斯基建立起这一机制后，他简要地证明了短语结构语法优于唯一被提议作为语法形式模型的合法候选者——香农和韦弗（1949）的新兴有限状态语法——而后者并非巧合地得到了布鲁姆菲尔德的神童查尔斯·霍克特（1955:2）的认可。然而，直接成分的粉丝们从这一胜利中感受到的任何满足感都转瞬即逝。乔姆斯基将一个好的科学理论所必需的相同原则应用于语法，证明了无论短语结构语法具有什么样的表征优点，它对一些基本现象的处理都是极其丑陋的：“极其复杂、临时和‘不具揭示性’”（1957a:34）。也就是说，它们可能适合作为数据的平面描述，就像随机排序的列表可以充分描述化合物的所有元素一样，但它们缺乏化学式中的简单性和简洁性。

Once Chomsky has this machinery in place, he briefly demonstrates that phrase structure grammars are superior to the only legitimate candidates proposed as formal models of syntax—Shannon and Weaver’s (1949) nascent finite state grammars—which, not coincidentally, had been endorsed by the Bloomfieldian boywonder, Charles Hockett (1955:2). Any satisfaction Immediate Constituent fans might have felt from this triumph, however, was very short lived. Applying to grammar the same principles necessary for a good scientific theory, Chomsky demonstrates that whatever phrase structure grammar’s representational virtues, its treatment of some fundamental phenomena is surpassingly ugly: “extremely complex, ad hoc, and ‘unrevealing’” (1957a:34). That is, they may be adequate as flat descriptions of the data, in the way that randomly ordered lists adequately describe all the elements of a compound, but they lack the simplicity and concision found in a chemical formula.

瞧，东方发生了变化。

Lo, in the east, a transformation.

事实上，有几种转换；数量不多；乔姆斯基展示了它们如何毫不费力地在短语结构分析之后得到清理。其中两种转换分析以后来被称为词缀跳跃和被动（或被动化）的规则为中心，随着转换语法固化为一种范式，它们在接下来的几年里迅速获得了典范地位。

Several transformations, in fact; a small flock; and Chomsky shows how they can, rather effortlessly, clean up after phrase structure analyses. Two of these transformational analyses, centering on rules which became known as Affix-hopping and Passive (or Passivization), rapidly achieved the status of exemplars in the next few years, as transformational grammar solidified into a paradigm.

词缀跳跃依赖于太多关于英语助动词系统的细节，无法在这里得到充分处理，但它极具说服力。布卢姆菲尔德语言学从根本上来说是一种分布追求，从根本上讲是解释声音和单词的分布——什么在什么之前——而当只依靠短语结构规则时，正确分配英语助动词是一个非常复杂的事情。作为问题的一小部分，请考虑进行时（4b，与一般现在时 4a 相反）：

Affix-hopping depends on too much detail about the English auxiliary system to treat very adequately here, but it was extremely persuasive. Bloomfieldian linguistics was fundamentally a distributional pursuit, fundamentally about accounting for the distribution of sounds and words—what comes before what—and getting the distributions right for English auxiliary verbs is a very complicated matter when it is left in the hands of phrase structure rules alone. As one sliver of the problem consider the progressive aspect (4b, in contrast to the simple present, 4a):

4

4

安德鲁玩滑板。

a Andrew skateboards.

 

 

b 安德鲁正在玩滑板。

b Andrew is skateboarding.

4b 的棘手之处在于，进行体显然由两个块编码，中间又隔开一个块：is和-ing都是必需的，但那个该死的滑板却挡在它们之间。为了描述不连续分布is ...-ing ，乔姆斯基对短语结构规则进行了许多创新，但真正具有突破性的举措是他提出的这个优雅的小变换：

The tricky part about 4b is that progressive aspect is clearly coded by two chunks separated by another one: is and -ing are both necessary, but that darn skateboard gets between them. Chomsky made a number of innovations to the phrase structure rules in order to describe the discontinuous distribution, is …-ing, but the really ground-shifting move was his proposal of this elegant little transformation:

5 Af V ⇒ V Af

5 Af V ⇒ V Af

（双箭头左侧的结构“变成”右侧的结构。）

(The structure to the left of the double arrow “becomes” the structure to the right.)

规则 5 只是将动词前面的词缀附加到动词的后端，确保后缀(-ing)实际上出现在它应该出现的位置，紧邻动词的后部。乔姆斯基对短语结构规则所做的修改确保它们产生了类似 6 的内容：

Rule 5 simply attaches the affix preceding a verb to its backend, making sure that the suffix (-ing) in fact shows up where it’s supposed to show up, abutted to the verb’s hindquarters. The modifications Chomsky made to the phrase structure rules ensured that they produced something like 6:

6 Andrew 正在玩滑板

6 Andrew is -ing skateboard

然后词缀跳跃开始发挥作用，跳跃式地，-ing越过滑板，结果是（分布正确的）4b。有什么大不了的？好吧，短语结构规则生成的is和-ing并排出现，捕捉到它们作为一个单位来表示进行时的事实，而词缀跳跃重新分配该单位，捕捉到它们实际上不会在人们的讲话中并排出现的事实。

Then Affix-hopping would kick in, leapingfrogging, the -ing over the skateboard, and the (distributionally correct) 4b was the result. What’s the big deal? Well, the phrase structure rules generate is and -ing side-by-side, capturing the fact that they serve as a unit to signal progressive aspect, and Affix-hopping redistributes that unit, capturing the fact that they don’t in fact occur side-by-side in people’s speech.

如果词缀跳跃法不足以令人信服地证明乔姆斯基系统的优点，那么请考虑一下短语结构对句子（如 7 中的句子）的解释有多糟糕。它完全没有表达主动语态和被动语态具有非常清晰的句法和语义对应性这一重要事实。

If Affix-hopping isn’t very convincing about the merits of Chomsky’s system, consider how badly a phrase structure account of sentences like those in 7 does. It leaves completely unexpressed the important fact that actives and passives have very clear syntactic and semantic parallels.

7

7

a 小鸭子咬了农夫。

a The duckling bit the farmer.

 

 

b 农夫被小鸭子咬了。

b The farmer was bitten by the duckling.

仅使用短语结构规则来处理句法的语法将独立生成 7 中的句子，并带有如下两个句子规则：

A grammar that handles syntax exclusively with phrase structure rules would generate the sentences in 7 independently, with two sentence rules like these ones:

8

8

一个 S → NP + V + NP

a S → NP + V + NP

 

 

b S → NP + be + V + by + NP

b S → NP + be + V + by + NP

两个现象的两个规则（8a 对应 7a，8b 对应 7b）必然意味着主动句和被动句之间的任何联系都是完全偶然的；主动句就是主动句，被动句就是被动句，它们之间唯一的松散联系就是它们都是句子。然而，正如每个以英语为母语的人都知道的那样，这些对应关系有一个明显的模式。例如，9a 和 9b 显然是合法、合理的英语句子；10a 和 10b 显然是不合法和无意义的（或者，只有在奇怪的三明治结构下才是合法的）：

Two rules for two phenonena (8a for 7a, 8b for 7b), necessarily implies that any connection between active sentences and passive sentences is wholly accidental; an active is an active, a passive is a passive, and the only loosely connecting point about them is that they are both sentences. However, as every native speaker of English knows, there is an obvious pattern to these correspondences. For instance, 9a and 9b are clearly legitimate, sensible, English sentences; 10a and 10b are clearly illegitimate and nonsensical (or, legitimate only under a bizarre construal of sandwich):

9

9

a 农夫咬了三明治。

a The farmer bit the sandwich.

 

 

b 三明治被农夫咬了。

b The sandwich was bitten by the farmer.

10

10

a *三明治咬了农夫。

a *The sandwich bit the farmer.

 

 

b *农夫被三明治咬伤了。

b *The farmer was bitten by the sandwich.

因此，一个适当的英语语法——即符合乔姆斯基列举所有合法英语句子的标准的语法——必须生成第一对句子并排除第二对句子；短语结构解释只能以不直观的冗余为代价来做到这一点。例如，它必须独立规定动词bite在主动句中可以接受哪些主语和宾语，以及在被动句中可以接受哪些主语和宾语，尽管这两组是严格相反的（在主动句中，主语必须能够咬，宾语必须是可咬的；在被动句中，主语必须是可咬的，间接宾语必须能够咬）。但是，用以下转换（而不是用 8 中的规则）补充 3 中的短语结构规则，可以更令人满意地解释 7a 和 7b 之间、9a 和 9b 之间，甚至异常 10a 和 10b 之间的明显对应关系。

An adequate grammar of English—that is, one which meets Chomsky’s criterion of enumerating all and only the legitimate sentences of English—must therefore generate the first pair of sentences and preclude the second; the phrase structure account can only do so at the expense of unintuitive redundancy. For instance, it must stipulate independently what subjects and objects the verb bite can take in an active sentence and what it can take in a passive sentence, although the two sets are strictly inverse (the subject must be able to bite and the object must be biteable in actives; the subject must be biteable and the indirect object must be able to bite in passives). But supplementing the phrase structure rules of 3 with the following transformation (rather than with the rules of 8) gives a much more satisfactory account of the obvious correspondences between 7a and 7b, between 9a and 9b, and even between the anomalous 10a and 10b.

11 NP 1 V NP 2 ⇒ NP 2 被NP 1变为V

11 NP1 V NP2 ⇒ NP2 be-en V by NP1

（下标只是标记双箭头两边相同的 NP。）

(The subscripts simply mark NPs which are identical on either side of the double arrow.)

在按照这些思路组织的语法（转换语法）中，短语结构规则生成 7a（或 9a），然后它可以成为转换“被动”（规则 11）的输入，以 7b（或 9b）作为输出，或者它可以完全不参与 11 而“浮现”。

In a grammar organized along these lines—a transformational grammar—the phrase structure rules generate 7a (or 9a), which can then become the input for the transformation, Passive (rule 11), with 7b (or 9b) as the output, or it can “surface” without engaging 11 at all.

简而言之，转换语法通过从同一来源推导出主动语态和被动语态之间的系统对应关系来解释它们之间的系统对应关系。6

In short, a transformational grammar explains the systematic correspondences between actives and passives by deriving them from the same source.6

但是规则 11 不能单独完成这项工作：因为该规则同时引入了be和-en，并且被动句中有一个动词，所以在派生过程中也需要应用词缀跳跃，将-en粘在主动词的末尾。乔姆斯基的转换是串联发生的。它们是有序的；在这种情况下，被动句先于词缀跳跃应用。那么请注意，我们还有另一个——就该领域后续历史而言，更重要的——“派生”概念的应用需要考虑。我们之前谈到了从短语结构规则中派生出来的树（或短语标记）。现在我们讨论句子的派生，即句子的转换派生。事实上，在规则 9a 和 9b 中我们讨论的是两种转换派生，一种适用被动句，一种不适用。对于 9a，只适用一条规则，即词缀跳跃，因此其推导相对简单 — 尽管相当抽象，因为词缀跳跃将时态标记 PAST 移到咬合之上，最终结果实际上根本没有词缀。对于 9b，适用两条规则，即被动和词缀跳跃，按此顺序，使推导稍微复杂一些。

But 11 can’t do the job on its own: since the rule introduces be and -en side-by-side and since passive sentences have a verb in between them, Affix-hopping also needs to apply in the derivation, gluing the -en onto the butt of the main verb. Chomsky’s transformations occur in tandem. They are ordered; in this case, Passive applying before Affix-hopping. Notice, then, that we have another—and in terms of the subsequent history of the field, a much more important—application of the notion, “derive,” to consider. We spoke earlier of a tree (or phrase marker) as derived from phrase structure rules. Now we are talking about the derivation of a sentence, the transformational derivation of a sentence. In fact, with 9a and 9b we are talking about two transformational derivations, one in which Passive applies, one in which it doesn’t. For 9a, only one rule applies, Affix-hopping, so its derivation is relatively simple—though quite abstract, since Affix-hopping moves the tense marker, PAST, over bite and the final result doesn’t really have an affix at all. For 9b, two rules apply, Passive and Affix-hopping, in that order, making for a slightly more complicated derivation.

将抽象级别提升至短语标记，以图形方式考虑此过程，如 PM-2 至 PM-5 所示。

Moving up a level of abstraction to phrase markers, consider this process graphically, as shown in PM–2 through PM–5.

在第一个推导（PM-2 ⇒ PM-3）中，只适用词缀跳跃；在第二个推导（PM-2 ⇒ PM-4 ⇒ PM-5）中，适用两个规则，被动和词缀跳跃。这里的工作还没有完成——后面的基于声音的规则必须应用才能从bite + PAST中得到bit ，从be + PAST中得到was，从bite + - en中得到bitten——但这些在布卢姆菲尔德的声音和单词体系中都相当简单。

In the first derivation (PM–2 ⇒ PM–3), only Affix-hopping applies; in the second derivation (PM–2 ⇒ PM–4 ⇒ PM–5), two rules apply, Passive and Affix-hopping. The job isn’t complete here—later sound-based rules have to apply in order to get bit out of bite + PAST, to get was out of be + PAST, and to get bitten out of bite + -en—but these were all quite straightforward in the Bloomfieldian sound-and-word scheme of things.

在这两种情况下，这些规则都确保了布卢姆菲尔德的典型目标，即获得正确的分布，但对许多人来说，这两种推导方法最重要的特点是它们从同一个地方开始（PM-2）：从共同来源进行两次推导，得出两个不同但明显相关的句子，纠正了“现代语言理论的一个严重不足，即它无法解释句子之间的系统关系，如主动-被动关系”（Chomsky，1962a[1958]：124）。

In both cases, the rules ensure the quintessential Bloomfieldian goal of getting the distributions right, but the most important feature of these two derivations for many people is that they start from the same place (PM–2): two derivations from a common source, yielding two distinct but clearly related sentences corrects “a serious inadequacy of modern linguistic theory, namely, its inability to account for such systematic relations between sentences as the active-passive relation” (Chomsky, 1962a [1958]:124).

总之，短语结构规则建立了基本模式并引入了单词；它们会说诸如“限定词后跟名词是合法的名词短语”（规则 3b，NP → Det + N）”和“小鸭子是该模式的合法例子”（规则 3d，Det → the，和 3e，N → {… duckling ,…}）。转换会改变这些基本模式以解释更广泛的句子和短语类型；它们会说诸如“如果农夫杀了小鸭子是合法的英语句子，那么小鸭子被农夫杀了也是合法的英语句子”（规则 11，被动化，NP 1 V NP 2 ⇒ NP 2 be-en V by NP l，以及规则 5，词缀跳跃，Af V ⇒ V Af，有助于正确确定词缀和动词的顺序）。

In sum, phrase structure rules establish basic patterns and introduce words; they say such things as “a determiner followed by a noun is a legitimate noun phrase” (rule 3b, NP → Det + N),” and “the duckling is a legitimate example of that pattern” (rules 3d, Det → the, and 3e, N → {… duckling,…}). Transformations alter those basic patterns to account for a wider range of sentences and phrase types; they say such things as “if the farmer killed the duckling is a legitimate English sentence, then so is the duckling was killed by the farmer” (rule 11, Passivization, NP1 V NP2 ⇒ NP2 be-en V by NPl, along with rule 5, Affix-hopping, Af V ⇒ V Af, which helps get the affix-and-verb order right).

乔姆斯基的讨论中浮现出的语法非常简陋，只占英语的极小一部分。乔姆斯基概述了许多提出了其他转换方法解决句法问题的方法，并概述了单数转换和广义转换的分工；前者针对词缀位置和主动-被动关系等现象，后者针对关系从句和连接从句等现象，抓住了句子 12a（带有关系从句）和 12b（两个连接从句）“由”13a 和 13b“组成”的直觉。

The grammar that emerges from Chomsky’s discussion is extremely rudimentary, accounting for only the tiniest fragment of English. Chomsky sketches a number of other transformational solutions to syntactic problems, and outlines a division of labor into singulary and generalized transformations; the former for such phenomena as affix-placement and active-passive relations, the latter for such phenomena as relative clauses and conjoined clauses, capturing the intuition that sentences 12a (with a relative clause) and 12b (two conjoined clauses) are “made up of” 13a and 13b.

12

12

洛根德拉辱骂了那只骚扰他的鸭子。

a Logendra abused the duck which had buzzed him.

 

 

b 鸭子朝洛根德拉嗡嗡叫，他虐待它。

b The duck buzzed Logendra and he abused it.

十三

13

Logendra 虐待鸭子，

a Logendra abused the duck,

 

 

b 鸭子向洛根德拉嗡嗡叫。

b The duck buzzed Logendra.

但即使乔姆斯基已经列出了一系列同样有吸引力的解决方案， 《句法结构》中转换语法的案例仍然严重不足；请记住，这本书在很多方面都是他庞大的《逻辑结构》的总结。然而，当乔姆斯基读完时：（1）唯一明确提出的其他生成语法（霍克特认可的有限状态语法）已被否定；（2）短语结构规则独立运作的案例（因此，直接成分分析）被剔除；（3）一个非常强大、新颖的句法方法的轮廓被用几句简短、引人注目的笔触勾勒出来。这种方法（图 3.2中图示）7 ) 主要的布隆菲尔德句法模型比之前的任何句法模型都表现得更好，并且还能完成一些额外的工作。

But even after Chomsky has laid out a nice sample of equally appealing solutions, the case for transformational grammar in Syntactic Structures is grossly underdetermined; the book is in many ways, remember, a summary of his massive Logical Structure. Still, by the time Chomsky is through: (1) the only other explicitly proposed generative grammar (the Hockett-endorsed finite state grammar) is disconfirmed; (2) the case for phrase structure rules working on their own (therefore, Immediate Constituent analysis) is eviscerated; and (3) the outline of a very powerful, novel approach to syntax is served up in a few, short, compelling strokes. This approach (schematized in Figure 3.27) does the main Bloomfieldian work better than any previous syntactic model and does a few additional jobs to boot.

一组短语结构规则会生成底层短语标记的核心，这些标记会经过一组转换，变成最终可观察的形状，也就是我们说话和书写时的形状（例如，带有所有词缀）：系统和谐地生成特定语言的所有且仅是符合语法的句子。

A set of phrase structure rules generates a core of underlying phrase markers, which feed into a set of transformations that massage them into their final, observable shapes, the ones we talk and write with (with all the affixes in place, for instance): the system purring harmoniously to generate all and only the grammatical sentences of a specific language.

图 3.2 .句法结构中概述的转换语法。

Figure 3.2. The transformational grammar sketched in Syntactic Structures.

然而，这幅图景中仍然缺少了一些东西：乔姆斯基从哈里斯那里继承并巧妙改变的特权概念，即核心句子。对于乔姆斯基来说，核心句子取决于这样一个事实：转换有两种形式，强制性的（如词缀跳跃）和可选的（如被动）。强制性转换只要满足其结构要求就会起作用（即，只要箭头左侧的条件出现；对于词缀跳跃，只要序列“Af + V”出现在推导中）。可选转换只是有时才会起作用，没有任何真正的指导机制（因此，被动会在某些满足其结构要求的时候应用，在某些短语结构规则生成序列“NP V NP”的时候应用）。

There is still something missing from this picture, however: a privileged notion that Chomsky inherited from Harris and subtly altered, the kernel sentence. For Chomsky, the kernel sentence hinges on the fact that transformations come in two flavors, obligatory (like Affix-hopping) and optional (like Passive). Obligatory transformations go to work whenever their structural requirements are met (that is, whenever the conditions on the left of the arrow occur; for Affix hopping, whenever the sequence “Af + V” shows up in a derivation). Optional transformations only go to work sometimes, without any real guiding mechanism (so, Passive would apply some of the times that its structural requirements are met, some of the times that the phrase structure rules generated the sequence “NP V NP”).

所有广义变换都是可选的。

All generalized transformations are optional.

可选/强制的区分可能看起来特别不必要，但请考虑另一种情况。例如，如果被动和词缀跳跃在这方面没有区别，那么模型就会陷入各种麻烦——生成一些不是英语的序列，而无法生成一些英语序列。如果词缀跳跃是可选的，那么语法就会产生像“Andrew is -ing skidboard”这样的胡言乱语，因为词缀无法移动。如果被动是强制的，那么语法就会无法产生像“The dog bit the mailman”这样的序列，因为每次短语结构规则生成这样的序列时，被动都会将其变成被动语态。

The optional/obligatory distinction may look peculiarly unnecessary, but consider the alternative. If Passive and Affix-hopping, for instance, weren’t different in this regard, the model would be in all kinds of trouble—generating some sequences that aren’t English, and failing to generate some that are. If Affix-hopping were optional, then the grammar would produce gibberish like “Andrew is -ing skateboard,” since the affix would fail to be moved. If Passive were obligatory, then the grammar would fail to produce sequences like “The dog bit the mailman,” since every time the phrase structure rules generated such a sequence, Passive would turn it into a passive.

如果广义的转换（将简单句子变成复杂句子的转换）是强制性的，那么语法将再次无法生成某些句子（即所有简单句子，因为相关的转换必然会将它们所有结合在一起）。8

If the generalized transformations (the ones which made complex sentences out of simple ones) were obligatory, then the grammer would again fail to produce some sentences (namely, all simple ones, since the relevant transformations would necessarily combine them all).8

这种区别至关重要，这也是内核发挥作用的地方。

The distinction was crucial, which is where the kernel comes in.

句法结构模型中的核心句子是那些只经历了强制性转换的派生句子。它们不仅仅是核心，也被称为其他句子的核心——经历了可选转换的平行句子。因此，派生主动句是派生被动句的核心句（例如，7a 是 7b 的核心句，9a 是 9b 的核心句）。两个或多个派生简单句是派生复杂句的核心（例如，13a 和 13b 是 12a 的核心句，也是 12b 的核心句）。所有这些听起来可能过于复杂；重点只是语法生成了两类句子，即核心句子和其他句子，并且核心句子更受尊崇。

Kernel sentences in the Syntactic Structures model are those derived sentences which had only undergone obligatory transformations. More than just kernels, they were also said to be the kernels of other sentences—parallel ones which had undergone optional transformations. A derived active sentence, then, was the kernel sentence of a derived passive (7a for 7b, for instance, and 9a for 9b). Two or more derived simple sentences were the kernels of a derived complex sentence (13a and 13b for 12a, for instance, and also for 12b). All of this probably sounds unduly complicated; the important point is simply that the grammar generated two classes of sentences, kernels and everything else, and that kernels had more cachet.

内核是转换语法中意义的种子。

The kernel was the seed of meaning in transformational grammar.

意义的吸引力

The Appeal of Meaning

我们希望由语法孤立出来并展现出来的语言的句法框架能够支持语义描述，并且我们应该更加重视能够产生符合这一要求的语法的形式结构理论。

We should like the syntactic framework of the language that is isolated and exhibited by the grammar to be able to support semantic description, and we shall rate more highly a theory of formal structure that leads to grammars that meet this requirement.

诺姆·乔姆斯基

Noam Chomsky

乔姆斯基的分配利益——在哈里斯的指导下几乎不可避免——并不是他布鲁姆菲尔德传统的唯一元素。他还对方法论上对意义的厌恶，他的工作强化了布卢姆菲尔德意义政策的一个关键要素：在形式分析中必须避免意义。

Chomsky’s distributional interests—virtually inevitable under the tutelage of Harris—were not the only elements of his Bloomfieldian heritage. He also had a deep methodological aversion to meaning, and his work reinforced one of the key elements of the Bloomfieldian policy toward meaning: it had to be avoided in formal analysis.

但《句法结构》有助于扭转布卢姆菲尔德语言学中一个更加成问题的趋势：意义无法研究。在某种程度上，乔姆斯基赶上了这股潮流。正如句法在 50 年代得到越来越多的关注一样，意义也正从边缘试探性地卷土重来。人类学语言学家 Floyd Lounsbury 开始了他即将产生影响的成分分析工作（1956, 1964 [1962]）。传教士语言学家 Eugene Nida 在欧洲流亡杂志Word上发表了他的“语义元素描述系统”（1951） 。德怀特博林格甚至认为（也在Word上）意义厌恶在音系学中可能有理有据或可取之处，但它却是更高层次分析的障碍。他说：“意义是词素的标准”，因此语言学家有责任“发展一种意义理论并始终如一地应用它”（1950:120）。马丁·乔斯甚至称赞哈里斯的转换分析是“结构语义学的开端”，称其为“语言学多年来最令人兴奋的事情”（1957:356）。

But Syntactic Structures was instrumental in reversing a far more problematic trend in Bloomfieldian linguistics: that meaning was unavailable for study. To some extent, Chomsky was catching a wave. Just as syntax saw increased action in the fifties, meaning was making a tentative comeback from the periphery. The anthropological linguist, Floyd Lounsbury, was beginning his soon-to-be influential work on componential analysis (1956, 1964 [1962]). The missionary linguist, Eugene Nida, had published his “System for the Description of Semantic Elements” (1951), in the European emigré journal, Word. Dwight Bolinger had even argued (also in Word) that, as defensible or desirable as meaning-aversion might be in phonology, it was a handicap for higher levels of analysis. “Meaning is the criterion of the morpheme,” he said, and, therefore linguists have a duty to “develop a theory of meaning and apply it consistently” (1950:120). Martin Joos had even hailed Harris’s transformational analysis as “a beginning … on a structural semantics,” calling it “the most exciting thing that has happened in linguistics for quite a few years” (1957:356).

乔斯对哈里斯的描述偏离了主题，但乔姆斯基对哈里斯的延伸可以看作是这样的开始。乔姆斯基说，他的工作从一开始就是“努力构建一种语义上负责任的语言理论”，而对他来说，解决意义的方法是通过结构：

Joos’s characterization is off the mark for Harris, but Chomsky’s extension of Harris can be viewed as such a beginning. Chomsky says his work was, from the outset, “an effort to construct a semantically responsible theory of language,” and the way to tackle meaning for him is through structure:

LSLT [语言理论的逻辑结构]和句法结构的重点都是试图弄清楚语言必须具有哪些形式结构才能解释我们理解句子的方式。除了了解它们的含义之外，试图弄清楚结构必须是什么还有什么意义？证据都是语义证据。事实是：看，我们以这种方式、那种方式、另一种方式理解句子。那么语言必须如何运作才能产生这些结果？9

The focus in both LSLT [Logical Structure of Linguistic Theory] and Syntactic Structures is on trying to figure out what formal structures languages must have in order to account for the way we understand sentences. What’s the point of trying to figure out what the structures must be, except to see how they mean? The evidence is all semantic evidence. The facts are: Look, we understand the sentences this way, that way, the other way. Now how must language be working so as to yield those results?9

话语的结构——句法——长期以来一直被视为研究意义的方法。例如，莫迪斯泰人以及本世纪大多数语言哲学家都采取了这种途径。理由很充分：无论声音和词语做什么，无论它们在语言中如何运作，都需要句法来对世界做出断言和主张，才能真正产生某种意义。苹果是一个代表某类水果的正字法符号，但它并没有真正参与意义，直到它参与到“约翰吃了一个苹果”或“约翰吃了一个苹果吗？”或“谁吃了一个苹果？”这样的结构中——借用乔姆斯基在《句法结构》（1957a:71）中的一些例子。换句话说，将主席短暂地交给有史以来最有成就的句法学家之一奥托·耶斯珀森，布卢姆菲尔德的音系学和形态学堡垒从外部看待语言；而不是句法。句法“从语法内部，也就是从其意义或含义的角度来看待语法事实”（Jespersen，1954.2：1）。

The structure of utterances—syntax—has long looked like the way to study meaning. That was the route taken by the Modistae, for instance, and by most philosophers of language in this century. For good reason: whatever sounds and words do, however they function in language, it takes syntax to make assertions and claims about the world, to really mean something. Apple is an orthographic symbol which stands in for a certain class of fruit, but it doesn’t get seriously involved in meaning until it participates in a structure like “John ate an apple” or “Did John eat an apple?” or “Who ate an apple?”—to borrow some of Chomsky’s examples in Syntactic Structures (1957a:71). In other terms, turning the chair briefly over to one of the most accomplished syntacticians ever, Otto Jespersen, the Bloomfieldian strongholds of phonology and morphology look at language from the outside; not syntax. Syntax “looks at grammatical facts from within, that is to say from the side of their meaning or signification” (Jespersen, 1954.2:1).

回到乔姆斯基：“这种对语言结构的纯形式研究（在句法结构中）对于语义研究具有某些有趣的意义” (1957a:12)。10在确定了句法价值之后，乔姆斯基继续从明确的语义角度论证转换。例如，他请读者思考 14 中的短语。

Back to Chomsky: “This purely formal investigation [in Syntactic Structures] of the structure of language has certain interesting implications for semantic studies” (1957a:12).10 And, after he has established their syntactic worth, Chomsky proceeds to argue for transformations in explicitly semantic terms. For instance, he asked his readers to consider the phrases in 14.

14

14

猎人的射击

a the shooting of the hunters

 

 

b 飞机的飞行

b the flying of the planes

这两个短语在名词作为动词宾语（猎人正在被射击，飞机正在飞行）和名词作为动词主语（猎人正在射击，飞机正在飞行）的读法中都存在歧义。我们再次面临一个问题，布卢姆菲尔德方案对此几乎没有什么可说的，但它反映了英语的明确事实，而转换语法再次给出了答案。直接成分方法对此类短语所能做的最好的事情是——使用乔姆斯基提供的短语结构工具——将它们视为同一类的成员，其结构在 15 中给出。

Both of these phrases are ambiguous between readings where the nouns are objects of the verbs (the hunters are being shot, the planes are being flown) and where they are subjects (the hunters are shooting, the planes are flying). Again, we are faced with a problem about which the Bloomfieldian program has little to say, but which reflects clear facts of English, and again, transformational grammar has an answer. The best the Immediate Constituent approach can do with phrases like this is—using the phrase structure apparatus Chomsky supplies—to treat them as members of the same class, with the structure given in 15.

15 NP 的 V -ing

15 the V -ing of NP

但是转换语法可以很容易地制定出以下类型的规则：

But transformational grammar can easily formulate rules of the following sort:

16

16

NP V ⇒ NP 的 V 形式

a NP V ⇒ the V -ing of NP

 

 

b NP 1 V NP 2 ⇒ NP 2的V形式

b NP1 V NP2 ⇒ the V -ing of the NP2

转换 16a 将“猎人”之类的 NP 后接“shoot”之类的 V 词，转换为类似 14a 的结构；转换 16b 将“某人向猎人开枪”之类的结构转换为相同结构。也就是说，14a 的两种含义各自具有不同的转换历史——相同的转换后结构，但两个不同的转换前结构——为歧义提供了一种解释。

Transformation 16a changes an NP like “the hunters” followed by a V like “shoot” into structures like 14a; transformation 16b changes structures like “someone shoots the hunters” into the same structure. That is, the two senses of 14a each have a distinct transformational history—the same post-transformational structures, but two different pre-transformational structures—offering an explanation for the ambiguity.

乔姆斯基的目标是绘制出庞大而令人生畏的语义雨林中的一小部分，构建一种“语言结构理论，它或许能够涵盖意义问题这一广阔而错综复杂的丛林的一部分”（1957b:290）。这个野心当然是谨慎的，但比布卢姆菲尔德试图完全背弃意义、将其甩给其他学科要大胆得多。《句法结构》为语言学家如何开始有意义地谈论意义提供了一个令人印象深刻的总体概述，回想起来，很明显，许多语言学家认为这个概述是乔姆斯基计划中最引人注目的特征。他招募的三位最杰出的人员，特别是保罗·波斯特尔 (Paul Postal)、杰罗德·卡茨 (Jerrold Katz) 和杰里·福多 (Jerry Fodor)，很快着手将语义明确地纳入句法结构模型，正是这项工作启发了更彻底的意义纳入，从而定义了生成语义的出现。

Chomsky’s goal is to chart a small part of the huge and daunting semantic rainforest, to construct a “theory of linguistic structure [which] may be able to incorporate a part of the vast and tangled jungle that is the problem of meaning” (1957b:290). The ambition is a guarded one to be sure, but far more enterprising than Bloomfield’s attempt to turn his back on meaning altogether, shucking it off on other disciplines. Syntactic Structures offers an impressive general outline of how linguists could begin to talk meaningfully about meaning, and it is clear in retrospect that many linguists found this outline to be the single most compelling feature of Chomsky’s program. Three of his most prominent recruits, in particular—Paul Postal, Jerrold Katz, and Jerry Fodor—soon set to work on an explicit incorporation of semantics into the Syntactic Structures model, and it was this work which inspired the more thorough incorporation of meaning that defined the appearance of generative semantics.

布隆菲尔德派已经做好了迎接乔姆斯基的准备。他们已经做好了迎接他的科学观念的准备——明确地将一种语言的语法定义为该语言的一种理论，并服从于任何理论的标准：简单性、普遍性、可测试性。事实上，霍克特几年前也说过几乎同样的话（1954:232-3）。他们已经做好了迎接他在句法方面的进步的准备。语言学中没有哪个领域比这个领域更成熟——事实上，已经过于成熟——值得研究，每个人都知道这一点。他们甚至不顾他们伟大的、具有决定性意义的科学恩人伦纳德·布隆菲尔德的禁令，准备跟随乔姆斯基（或者在他们心中是哈里斯）进入未知的意义丛林——好吧，进入丛林的边缘。希尔说，当时大多数领先的语言学家，尽管都是布隆菲尔德的追随者，但他们仍然所有人都“在觉得可能的时候，渴望突破语义学”（1991:79），11布洛赫 50 年代的一名学生回忆说，即使是布洛赫，一个老顽固，如果真有这样的人的话，也“准备接受语义学”，至少是在符号逻辑的严密可控的形式化方法中。只是他，以及也许大多数布鲁姆菲尔德理论家，“自己不想做这件事。他说，当逻辑学家们开始行动时，他会挥手鼓励他们。”当然，当乔姆斯基开始行动时，他挥手鼓励他们。

The Bloomfieldians were ready for Chomsky. They were ready for his notions of science—explicitly defining a grammar of a language as a theory of that language, subject to the criteria for any theory: simplicity, generality, testability. In fact, Hockett had said pretty much the same thing a few years earlier (1954:232–3). They were ready for his advances in syntax. No area of linguistics was more ripe—indeed, overripe—for investigation, and everyone knew it. They were even ready, despite the injunctions of their great, defining, scientific benefactor, Leonard Bloomfield, to follow Chomsky’s (or, in their minds, Harris’s) transformations into the uncharted jungle of meaning—well, into the edges of that jungle. Hill says that most of the leading linguists of the period, while all followers of Bloomfield, were nevertheless all “eager to break into semantics when they felt it possible” (1991:79),11 and one of Bloch’s students in the fifties recalls that even Bloch, an old wouldn’t-touch-meaning-with-a-ten-foot-pole hardliner if there ever was one, “was poised to accept semantics,” at least in the tightly manageable, formal methods of symbolic logic. It’s just that he, along with perhaps most of the defining Bloomfieldian theorists, “didn’t feel up to doing it himself. He said he would wave encouragement as the logicians took off.” Certainly, he waved encouragement as Chomsky took off.

布卢姆菲尔德主义者已经准备好对他们的计划进行一些完善、一些修订和扩展。他们已经为句法结构做好了准备。但他们还没有准备好进行替换。他们还没有准备好迎接句法结构的后续内容。

The Bloomfieldians were ready for some elaboration of their program, some revisions and extensions. They were ready for Syntactic Structures. They weren’t ready for a replacement. They weren’t ready for what followed Syntactic Structures.

乔姆斯基《动力者》

Chomsky Agonistes

有人告诉我，如果我不总是将转换语法的介绍与对经验主义者、行为主义者和其他语言学家的全面攻击结合起来，我的工作将会引起更少的对抗。许多对我怀有好感的善良的老年人告诉我，我应该坚持自己的工作，不要打扰其他人。但我觉得这是一种反智主义的建议。

I was told that my work would arouse much less antagonism if I didn’t always couple my presentation of transformational grammar with a sweeping attack on empiricists and behaviorists and on other linguists. A lot of kind older people who were well disposed toward me told me I should stick to my own work and leave other people alone. But that struck me as an anti-intellectual counsel.

诺姆·乔姆斯基

Noam Chomsky

如今，语言学界关于乔姆斯基崛起的神话层出不穷，人们赞美他的才华和先见之明，赞美他的前辈的愚钝和教条主义。我们已经看到了“完成领域的神话”，如果我们让哈里斯取代普朗克，那么乔姆斯基就取代了爱因斯坦。科学突破故事中还有一个反复出现的特征，即“尤里卡时刻”，乔姆斯基的时刻对阿基米德的原型进行了巧妙的改编，阿基米德更直白地躺在浴缸里：

There are myths aplenty in linguistics these days surrounding Chomsky’s spectacular rise, celebrating his brilliance and prescience, his predecessors’ obtuseness and dogmatism. We have already seen the finished-field myth, which, if we take Harris to fill Planck’s shoes, puts Chomsky in Einstein’s. There is also that recurrent feature of scientific breakthrough stories, the Eureka Moment, Chomsky’s moment putting a nice twist on the archetypical Archimedes in his more literal tub:

我清楚地记得我确信的那一刻。在大西洋中部的一艘船上，一阵晕船，坐在一个明显倾斜的摇摇晃晃的木桶里——它被德国人击沉了，现在正在被打捞上来后进行第一次航行。（Chomsky，1979 [1976]：131）

I remember exactly the moment when I felt convinced. On board ship in mid-Atlantic, aided by a bout of seasickness, on a rickety tub that was listing noticeably—it had been sunk by the Germans and was now making its first voyage after having been salvaged. (Chomsky, 1979 [1976]:131)

不那么戏剧性——没有恶心也没有纳粹——但仍是一部好书。据说乔姆斯基是通过阅读哈里斯的《结构语言学方法》 （1951 [1947]）的校样才进入语言学领域的，这本书大致类似于通过阅读罗素和怀特海的《自然哲学的数学原理》来进入数学领域的。据说，在突然沉浸其中之后，他默默无闻地辛勤工作，写出了杰作，先是为冷漠的泽利格·哈里斯服务，然后为冷漠的出版界服务，他一直坚信自己的工作只不过是一种私人爱好。然而，对科学来说幸运的是，头脑清醒、强有力的支持者说服他，他的工作归功于世界，就像哥白尼的支持者说服他、达尔文的支持者说服他一样，在最极端的情况下，索绪尔的支持者也说服了他。当他听从这一建议时，他面对的是一群盲目反对的布卢姆菲尔德派，他轻而易举地击败了他们，削弱了他们的论点，让辩论者哑口无言。简而言之，据说他把语言学从混乱的长夜中拯救出来，拉开了布卢姆菲尔德的帷幕错误地笼罩了思想；最终——我们可以预见到这一点即将发生——使语言学成为一门科学。

Less dramatically—with neither nausea nor Nazis—but still good copy, Chomsky’s introduction to linguistics is said to have come by way of reading the proofs to Harris’s dense, highly technical Methods in Structural Linguistics (1951 [1947]), which is roughly akin to an introduction to mathematics by way of Russell and Whitehead’s Principia. After this abrupt immersion, the stories go, he toiled in virtual obscurity, turning out masterpieces, first for the uncaring eye of Zellig Harris, then for the indifferent publishing world, convinced all the while that his work would never amount to more than a private hobby. Fortunately for science, however, clear-eyed and forceful supporters persuaded him that he owed his work to the world, as Copernicus’s supporters had persuaded him, and Darwin’s supporters, and, in the most extreme case of reluctance overcome, Saussure’s exhuming supporters. When he followed this advice, he was confronted by phalanxes of blindly opposed Bloomfieldians, whom he demolished effortlessly, enfeebling the arguments and dumbfounding the arguers. He is said, in short, to have rescued linguistics from a long dark night of confusion, to have pulled back the curtain Bloomfield mistakenly drew over the mind; to have finally—and we could see this one coming for some time—made linguistics a science.

就像所有美好的神话一样，这些都是真实的，当然，也是虚假的。

Like all good myths, these ones are true, and, of course, false.

为了消除此类评论通常会带来的令人不快的气味：这些起源神话的虚假性并不涉及具体细节。这里，无论是神话还是虚假，都并不意味着有人是骗子。哈里斯可能有过这样的感觉，即语言学过于成功，以至于作为一门科学即将消亡（哈里斯是一个高深莫测的人物），但乔姆斯基在哈里斯手下工作时肯定自己形成了这种印象。而且这种印象并非乔姆斯基和（可能）哈里斯独有；例如，约翰·卡罗尔 (John Carroll) 在 50 年代早期对语言学的概述的定论让人想起开尔文勋爵 (Lord Kelvin) 的言论，即物理学除了越来越精确的测量之外，别无所求——“自从 1933 年布卢姆菲尔德的著作发表以来，语言学的理论讨论主要集中在精细化问题上”（1953：30）。而且，如果哈里斯方法的证明不是乔姆斯基第一次接触语言学（他的父亲威廉是一位受人尊敬的闪族语言学家；小诺姆十岁时就开始阅读历史语言学，十几岁时开始学习阿拉伯语），那它们肯定是他第一次认真接触布卢姆菲尔德主义的主题、技巧和动力；例如，他甚至没有选修过大学一年级的结构语言学课程。

To fan away the unpleasant smell that usually attends such comments: the falseness of these origin myths doesn’t involve specifics. There is no implication here, in the word myth or even the word false, that anyone is a liar. Harris may or may not have had the feeling that linguistics was so successful it was about to go out of business as a science (Harris was an inscrutable character), but Chomsky certainly developed that impression himself, working under Harris. Nor was the impression exclusive to him and (possibly) Harris; the finality of John Carroll’s early fifties overview of linguistics, for instance, recalls Lord Kelvin’s remarks that physics had little more to look forward to than increasingly precise measurements—“Since the publication of Bloomfield’s work in 1933, theoretical discussions among linguistics have been largely on matters of refinement” (1953:30). And if the proofs of Harris’s Methods did not constitute Chomsky’s first exposure to linguistics (his father, William, was a respected Semitic philologist; little Noam was reading historical linguistics by the age of ten and studying Arabic in his teens), they were certainly his first serious exposure to the themes, techniques, and motive forces of Bloomfieldianism; he had not, for instance, taken so much as a first-year college course in structural linguistics.

他的转换生成研究相对默默无闻：他是哈佛大学的著名研究员，是 50 年代早期剑桥知识界活跃、早熟、有影响力的成员，其中包括 WVO Quine、Nelson Goodman 和 JL Austin 等哲学家，George Miller、Jerome Bruner 和 John Carroll 等心理学家，以及 Benoit Mandelbrot 和 Marvin Minsky 等流动知识分子；但他与语言学家的联系有限且非正统。他与布卢姆菲尔德学派社区的距离至少与日内瓦的索绪尔与新语法学家的距离，或渥太华的萨丕尔与博厄斯学派社区的距离一样。他无疑在这种默默无闻中创作出了杰作——最著名的是巨著《语言理论的逻辑结构》。（尚不清楚哈里斯或出版界对他的努力有多么漠不关心，但《逻辑结构》直到二十年后才出版；参见 Chomsky，1975a[1973]:lff，1988b:78n2；Newmeyer，1980a:33–35，1986a:28–31；Murray，1980。）

And his transformational-generative research was carried out in relative obscurity: Holding a prestigious fellowship at Harvard, he was a lively, precocious, influential member of an early fifties intellectual scene in Cambridge that included philosophers like W.V.O. Quine, Nelson Goodman, and J. L. Austin, psychologists like George Miller, Jerome Bruner, and John Carroll, and itinerant intellectuals like Benoit Mandelbrot and Marvin Minsky; but his ties with linguists were limited and unorthodox. He was at least as isolated from the Bloomfieldian community as, say, Saussure in Geneva was from the neogrammarians, or Sapir in Ottawa was from the Boasian community. And he certainly produced masterworks in this obscurity—most notably, the massive Logical Structure of Linguistic Theory.(It isn’t clear how indifferent either Harris or the publishing world was to his efforts, but Logical Structure wasn’t published for another twenty years; see Chomsky, 1975a[1973]:lff, 1988b:78n2; Newmeyer, 1980a:33–35, 1986a:28–31; Murray, 1980.)

一小部分支持者（最著名的是莫里斯·哈勒和哲学家耶霍舒亚·巴尔-希勒尔）无疑说服了他​​，他的想法是有价值的，不仅仅是作为他自己的智力玩具，而且对整个领域都是有价值的。而他那颗创造性的灯泡肯定在他记忆中点亮的地方，在大西洋中部摇摇晃晃、颠簸不已的海绿色面孔上方。除了布洛赫和其他人的迁就之外，乔姆斯基还遇到了阻力，随着他发展并阐明他的思想对布卢姆菲尔德基础设施的影响，阻力越来越大。乔姆斯基非常有效地处理了抵抗者，即使没有让所有对手都满意，也肯定让辩论中（在任何辩论中）更重要的因素——听众满意；乔姆斯基是现代思想中最强硬的辩论者之一。保守派中的支持者、抵抗者和支持者兼抵抗者被不加区别地扫地出门，即使没有乔姆斯基，当然还有听众中迅速壮大的转型主义者。尽管语言学在乔姆斯基出现之前是一门科学——就像在琼斯、索绪尔和布鲁姆菲尔德出现之前一样——但在他的思想扎根之后，语言学也和这些人一样，成为一门截然不同的科学。

And a small group of supporters (most notably, Morris Halle and philosopher Yehoshua Bar-Hillel) undoubtedly convinced him that his ideas were valuable, not just as his own cerebral toy, but for the entire field. And the generative light bulb surely clicked on for him exactly where he remembers it clicking on, above a sea green face, reeling and listing in mid-Atlantic. And, along with the accommodation of Bloch and others, Chomsky also encountered resistance, increasingly vociferous resistance as he developed and spelled out the implications of his thought for the Bloomfieldian infrastructure. And Chomsky dealt with the resisters very effectively, if not to the satisfaction of all his opponents, certainly to the satisfaction of a far more crucial element in the debate (in any debate), its audience; Chomsky is one of the hardest arguers in modern thought. The supporters and resisters and supporters-cum-resisters among the old guard were swept aside indiscriminately, if not by Chomsky, certainly by the quickly growing cadre of transformationalists in the audience. And, while linguistics was a science before he came along—as it was before Jones, and Saussure, and Bloomfield came along—it was, also as with those men, a much different science once his ideas took root.

不，错误并不在于细节。错误在于绝大多数革命后的语言学家对这些细节的惯常极端解释：语言研究真正始于乔姆斯基；在他之前的所有语言学家“都是无可救药的误入歧途的笨蛋，乔姆斯基英勇地从他们的魔爪中拯救了语言学领域”（Lamb，1967：414）。听听霍克特的苦涩哀叹：

No, the falseness is not in details. It is in the routinely extreme interpretations put on these details by the great majority of post-revolutionary linguists: that the study of language begins in real terms with Chomsky; that all linguists before him “were hopelessly misguided bumblers, from whose clutches Chomsky has heroically rescued the field of linguistics” (Lamb, 1967:414). Listen to Hockett’s bitter lament:

我……认为 [乔姆斯基语言学] 的“黯然失色立场”的成功是真正的悲剧。我们队伍中目前有大量年轻人，其中许多人非常聪明，从初学者到一些全职教授，他们对 1957 年之前语言学领域发生的事情一无所知，他们（其中一些人）实际上相信什么都没有发生。（霍克特，1980：105）12

I … view as genuinely tragic the success of the “eclipsing stance” of [Chomskyan linguistics.] We have currently in our ranks a large number of young people, many of them very bright, from beginning students up to and including a few full professors, who know nothing of what happened in linguistics before 1957, and who actually believe (some of them) that nothing did happen. (Hockett, 1980:105)12

霍克特有理由抱怨——尤其是因为他是布卢姆菲尔德派——最有可能是已故大师的宠儿，而他与奈达、豪斯霍尔德、希尔（甚至哈里斯，除了在语言民间传说中扮演施洗约翰的角色）——几乎在职业生涯的巅峰时期被抛在一边。当然，这些都不是新鲜事，也不是科学所特有的。普里西拉·罗伯逊在巧妙地折射托克维尔对 1848 年法国大革命的火山形象时说：“第一次喷发不仅摧毁了国王，而且还摧毁了那些希望改革君主制并通过批评帮助为革命做准备的上层人士”（1952:14），这一观察几乎适用于每一次突然的社会或科学转变。在本世纪出现的最引人注目的政治例子中，最容易让人想到的两个例子是俄罗斯的克伦斯基和戈尔巴乔夫。

Hockett has reason to complain—not least because he was the Bloomfieldian-most-likely, the late master’s favored son, and he was, along with Nida, Householder, Hill (even, aside from a sort of John-the-Baptist role in linguistic folklore, Harris)—pretty much swept aside in the prime of his career. None of this is new, of course, nor peculiar to science. “The first eruption,” Priscilla Robertson says, in her nice refraction of Tocqueville’s volcano image for the 1848 French revolution, blew off “not only the King but also, indifferently, the top layer of men who had hoped to reform the monarchy and who had by their criticism helped prepare for the revolution” (1952:14), an observation which generalizes to almost every abrupt social or scientific shift. Among the more spectacular political examples this century has provided, two from Russia spring most readily to mind, Kerensky and Gorbachev.

如果许多语言学家对历史的看法并不完全是悲剧性的，那么，用一个更适合于日常生活的词来形容那些比学术走廊里的生活更加严酷的生活，比如革命时期的法国，以及东欧和洛杉矶中南部各种革命带来的动荡和压迫，那么他们的看法肯定是错误的。乔姆斯基神话的虚假性再次存在于一种普遍的情绪中，这种情绪笼罩着他们例行公事地重述，即在 1933 年布卢姆菲尔德出版的《语言》和 1957 年乔姆斯基出版的《句法结构》之间一切都是徒劳的。

If many linguists’ view of history is not exactly tragic, then, a word more appropriate for the daily curses of lives much harsher than the ones lived out in academic hallways—in revolutionary France, for instance, and in the turbulence and oppression surrounding the various revolutions in Eastern Europe, and in South-Central Los Angeles—it is certainly wrong. The falseness of the Chomskyan myths, again, resides in the general mood enveloping their ritual retellings that all was for naught between the 1933 publication of Bloomfield’s Language and the 1957 publication of Chomsky’s Syntactic Structures.

但他们的部分真相也在于此。布卢姆菲尔德及其后人并没有迎来语言学的“活死人之夜”，他们并没有像语法僵尸一样蹒跚地从一个长屋走到另一个长屋，僵硬地记录一种又一种语言的音素、词素和基本句法模式。但事情变得有点机械化了。更重要的是，语言最引人注目的方面不仅被降级到一项长期议程的底部，而且已经完全交给了其他学科。意义和思想只能在遥远的未来才能得到处理，而且只能由社会学家、心理学家和民族学家来处理；似乎除了语言学家之外，每个人都被布卢姆菲尔德授予了在思想的鹿园中追寻意义的许可。语言学家必须坚持他们的声音和词语。

But part of their truth resides here as well. Bloomfield and his progeny had not ushered in a linguistic night of the living dead, grammar-zombies lurching from longhouse to longhouse, stiffly cataloging the phomemes, morphemes, and rudimentary syntactic patterns of language after language after language after language. But things were getting a little mechanical. And, more crucially, the most compelling aspects of language had not only been relegated to the bottom of a very longterm agenda, they had been given over to other disciplines altogether. Meaning and mind could be treated only in the distant future, and only by sociologists, psychologists, ethnologists; seemingly, everyone but linguists were given Bloomfield’s license to hunt down meaning in the deer park of the mind. Linguists had to stick to their sounds and words.

乔姆斯基——神话真相的另一个方面就在于此——几乎凭一己之力将语言学从描述性麻木中解放出来，让语言学家有机会谈论意义和思想；事实上，乔姆斯基关于后一点的论证是如此有力，以至于语言学家几乎是唯一有资格谈论思想的人。几乎是凭一己之力。他并非没有同事和信徒——最著名的是莫里斯·哈勒和罗伯特·李斯——他们支持他的理论，从中榨取利润，并将他的商品推向市场。我们也不应该忘记市场的存在；索绪尔、布卢姆菲尔德和哈里斯使语言学的数学化成为可能；哈里斯、韦尔斯、特雷格和史密斯在句法方面取得了一些进展；奈达、朗斯伯里和博林格都在为意义而呐喊助威。谈论公元前（乔姆斯基之前）的语言研究当然有一定意义，但语言学日历，即使是生成性、转换性和语义性概念，也并非始于 1957 年。

Chomsky—and here another aspect of the myths’ truth resides—almost singlehandedly shook linguistics free of its description-sodden stupor, and gave linguists leave to talk about meaning, and to talk about mind; indeed, the force of Chomsky’s argument on the latter point was such that linguists were virtually the only ones with leave to talk about mind. Almost single-handedly. He was not without coworkers and proselytes—most notably, Morris Halle and Robert Lees—who fed his theories, and milked them, and brought his wares to market. Nor would it do to forget that there was a market; that Saussure and Bloomfield and Harris had made the mathematicization of linguistics possible; that Harris and Wells and Trager and Smith were making some headway with syntax; that Nida and Lounsbury and Bolinger were clamoring about meaning. It certainly makes some sense to talk of language studies BC, Before Chomsky, but the linguistic calendar, even for generative and transformational and semantic notions, does not begin in 1957.

抛开日历不谈，乔姆斯基是这个故事的英雄。他是一位荷马式的英雄，稳居本世纪最杰出的思想家之列，拥有所有相关能力和品质。首先，最重要的是，他非常聪明。他的智力速度、广度和综合能力都是传奇。一位同事说：“我们大多数人在其他环境中都会非常聪明，但在诺姆面前却感到羞愧。”他致力于自己的事业，工作时间长、精力充沛；事实上，他致力于语言、心理和哲学（以及社会；像罗素和爱因斯坦一样，乔姆斯基有坚定的政治信念，他也为此不知疲倦地工作）等一系列事业。他也是一位天生的领导者，能够为自己发展或采取的立场争取支持，强烈而坚定的支持。 （相反，他是许多语言学家眼中的大恶魔，几乎他说的或做的任何事情都会招致激烈、不妥协的反对。）他似乎常常凭借着意志力来塑造语言学。而且——这是典型的英雄特质——他在战斗中无所畏惧。

Calendars aside, Chomsky is the hero of the story. He is a hero of Homeric proportions, belonging solidly in the pantheon of our century’s finest minds, with all the powers and qualities thereof. First, foremost, and initially, he is staggeringly smart. The speed, scope, and synthetic abilities of his intellect are legendary. “Most of us guys who in any other environment would be absolutely brilliant,” one colleague says, “are put to shame by Noam.” He is dedicated to his cause, working long, full hours; in fact, he is dedicated to a constellation of causes, linguistic, psychological, and philosophical (and social; like Russell and Einstein, Chomsky has deep political convictions, for which he also labors tirelessly). He is, too, a born leader, able to marshal support, fierce, uncompromising support, for positions he develops or adopts. (Inversely, he is many linguists’ Great Satan, certain to marshal fierce, uncompromising opposition to almost anything he says or does.) Often, it seems, he shapes linguistics by sheer force of will. And—the quintessential heroic trait—he is fearless in battle.

揭开心灵论者的眼罩

Peeling Off the Mentalist Blinders

希尔：如果我从字面上理解您的某些陈述，我会说您根本就不是在研究语言，而是在研究某种形式的心理学，即母语人士的直觉。

HILL: If I took some of your statements literally, I would say that you are not studying language at all, but some form of psychology, the intuitions of native speakers.

乔姆斯基：那就是研究语言。

CHOMSKY: That is studying language.

第三届德克萨斯大会交流

Exchange at the Third Texas Conference

从布卢姆菲尔德到乔姆斯基的更替中，第一个明显的战场是心灵主义，尽管只有在事后看来才明显。心灵主义面临的生成性挑战在后视镜中如此显眼，以至于很难看出老派是如何忽视了这一点的。但他们确实忽视了。

The first unmistakable battleground of the Bloomfield-to-Chomsky changing of the guard was mentalism, though it is unmistakable only in retrospect. The generative challenge to mentalism looms so large in the rearview mirror that it is difficult to see how the old guard missed it. But they did.

尽管布隆菲尔德派的兴趣普遍扩大，但心灵论仍然是禁忌。例如，莫里斯·斯瓦德什发表了一篇尖锐的批评文章，批评“任何与心灵有关的东西都必须被排除在科学之外的迷信”（1948 年；引自 Hymes and Fought，1981：159）。斯瓦德什是萨丕尔最受尊敬的学生之一。他在实地考察方面享有盛誉，发表了几篇有影响力的论文，包括最早的音素分布讨论之一（1934 年）。然而，他的批评甚至没能登上语言学杂志（它发表在主流之外的《科学与社会》杂志上），而且对语言学领域没有任何影响。即使是 20 世纪 50 年代早期至中期心理学对语言学的兴趣日益浓厚，催生了“心理语言学”一词，也明显是行为主义的，是没有思想的心理学。

Despite a general expansion of Bloomfieldian interests, mentalism was still taboo. Morris Swadesh, for instance, published a stinging attack on “the fetish that anything related to the mind must be ruled out of science” (1948; cited in Hymes and Fought, 1981:159). Swadesh was one of Sapir’s most respected students. He had a formidable reputation in fieldwork and several influential papers, including one of the earliest distributional discussions of the phoneme (1934). Yet his critique couldn’t even make it into a linguistics journal (it was published way out of the mainstream, in Science and Society), and had absolutely no impact on the field. Even the increased linguistic interest in psychology that marked the early-to-midfifties, spawning the term psycholinguistics, was distinctly behaviorist, psychology without the mind.

乔姆斯基认为，任何不关注语言心理触角的语言研究都是毫无意义的，因此他开始提倡将语言学作为一门从根本上来说属于心理学的事业，同时对行为主义进行了猛烈的抨击。13这两个方面的胜利都是惊人的。行为主义是布卢姆菲尔德对一种新的、改进的语言科学的启发，几年之内，行为主义作为语言学的一股力量几乎消失了，人们只在嘲笑它。它在国内也迅速衰落，心理学家们称赞乔姆斯基是前途光明的新兴学科认知心理学的拥护者（这个术语太复杂，无法在这里得到适当的处理，但粗略地说，认知心理学是围绕人类行为背后的知识系统而展开的；原则上，它与行为主义完全相反）。

Chomsky came to see any study of language that didn’t attend to its mental tentacles as completely sterile, and began promoting linguistics as a fundamentally psychological enterprise, coupling this promotion with a crushing attack on behaviorism.13 The triumph on both fronts was staggering. Within a few years, behaviorism, Bloomfield’s inspiration for a new and improved science of language, was virtually extinguished as a force in linguistics, invoked only in derision. It was also in rapid retreat at home, where psychologists hailed Chomsky as a champion in the promising emergent program, cognitive psychology (the term is too complex for proper treatment here, but, very roughly, cognitive psychology is oriented around the systems of knowledge behind human behavior; in principle, it is completely the inverse of behaviorism).

五十年代中期，心理学界出现了一些反对行为主义的声音，尤其是在剑桥，新方法正是从那里诞生的。根据乔治·米勒的说法，这种方法的诞生日是 1956 年 9 月 11 日，即哈佛大学研讨会的第二天，研讨会结束时乔姆斯基概述了《句法结构》背后的论点。我们不确定乔姆斯基在那次演讲中说了什么，但他当时对行为主义的态度体现在《句法结构》明确拒绝“将‘意义’[布卢姆菲尔德在其奠基性著作—1933：22-32 中提出的观点]等同于‘对语言的反应’”(1957a：100)。乔姆斯基对认知心理学的出现至关重要。尤其是，他反对行为主义的论点（几年后发表在对斯金纳的《言语行为》的评论中）被认为具有绝对的毁灭性。14和乔姆斯基大多数最精彩的论证一样，他反对斯金纳的论证在情感上和在智力上都同样有效。认知心理学运动的创始人之一杰罗姆·布鲁纳的反应很有代表性。他以非常激烈的言辞回忆了这篇评论：“令人震撼：诺姆处于最佳状态，毫不留情地杀戮，大胆、聪明，站在天使一边……与圣乔治屠龙属于同一类别”（1983：159-60）。

There were some murmurs of dissent toward behaviorism in mid-fifties psychology, especially in Cambridge, out of which the new approach was emerging, an approach whose birthday, according to George Miller, is 11 September 1956, the second day of a symposium at Harvard which ended with Chomsky outlining the arguments behind Syntactic Structures. We can’t be sure what Chomsky said in that lecture, but his attitude to behaviorism at the time is apparent in Syntactic Structures’ unambiguous rejection of “the identification of ‘meaning’ [that Bloomfield effects in his foundational tome—1933:22–32] with ‘response to language’” (1957a:100). Chomsky was in fact extremely important to the emergence of cognitive psychology. In particular, his arguments against behaviorism (published a few years later in a review of Skinner’s Verbal Behavior) were considered absolutely devastating.14 Like most of Chomsky’s finest arguments, his case against Skinner is as effective emotionally as it is intellectually. The reaction of Jerome Bruner, one of the founding voices of the cognitive psychology movement, is representative. He recalls the review in very charged terms: “Electric: Noam at his best, mercilessly out for the kill, daring, brilliant, on the side of the angels … in the same category as St. George slaying the dragon” (1983:159–60).

Dragon并没有夸大其词。行为主义与一些伦理观点紧密相连，五十年代的许多知识分子开始认为这些观点是不可救药的邪恶。在本世纪初的血腥和疯狂之后，人们对人类科学产生了浓厚的兴趣，即对个人和群体的控制。其中一些兴趣显然是邪恶的，控制意味着培养更好的士兵或让公民更温顺，但大部分兴趣都是出于好意，目的是让人们更快乐、更少攻击性、更有成就感，无论是个人还是集体：在这两种情况下，无论是邪恶还是善良，行为主义心理学、刺激反应心理学都是这些兴趣的闪光点。它提出了一个机械的承诺，即让人们表现良好只是找出要按哪些按钮，然后按下它们的问题。如果你想要某种反应，行为主义者会为你找到合适的刺激。而语言学家，因为语言是最便宜、最普遍的刺激，是非常关注这一现象的观察者项目。例如，布鲁姆菲尔德在 1929 年的 LSA 演讲中用这样的预言鼓舞了军队：

Dragon does not overstate the case. Behaviorism was tied up with some ethical perspectives that many intellectuals in the fifties were beginning to see as irredeemably vicious. There was, in the wake of the bloodshed and madness early in this century, a great deal of interest in the human sciences about the control of individuals and groups. Some of this interest was manifestly evil, where control meant building better soldiers or making citizens more docile, but much of it was very well intentioned, with the goal of happier, less aggressive, more fulfilled people, individually and collectively: in both cases, evil and good, behaviorist psychology, stimulus-response psychology, was the shining light of these interests. It held out the mechanical promise that getting people to behave would just be a matter of finding out which buttons to push, and pushing them. If you wanted a certain response, behaviorists would find the right stimulus for you. And linguists, since language is the cheapest, most omnipresent stimulus, were very concerned observers of this project. Bloomfield, for instance, heartened the troops in his 1929 LSA address with this prediction:

我相信在不久的将来——比如说在未来几代人的时间里——语言学将成为科学进步的主要领域之一，并且科学将在这一领域取得对人类行为的理解和控制。（1970[1929]：227）

I believe that in the near future—in the next few generations, let us say—linguistics will be one of the main sectors of scientific advance, and that in this sector science will win through to the understanding and control of human conduct. (1970 [1929]:227)

随着第二次世界大战的惨烈程度令人震惊——欧洲数百万人丧生，亚洲发生世界末日般的爆炸——逐渐发展为冷战时期对世界范围生存的震动，以及伴随这些事件而来的对科学的日益高涨的敬畏，一些语言学家对其领域强大未来的信心与日俱增，直到他们发现“我们国家的存在——甚至可能是人类的存在——可能取决于语言学的发展及其在人类问题中的应用”（McDavid，1954：32）。15

With the stunningly bad behavior of the Second World War—millions dead in Europe, apocalyptic explosions over Asia—segueing into the worldwide existential trembling of the cold war, and with the ever-growing reverence for science that accompanied these events, some linguists’ faith in the powerful future of their field increased until they found themselves “at a time when our national existence—and possibly the existence of the human race—may depend on the development of linguistics and its application to human problems” (McDavid, 1954:32).15

如今，这种说法听起来令人不安，甚至出于好意。理解人类行为固然很好，而且确实值得追求，但控制在 50 年代开始掀起一股令人不寒而栗的风潮（部分原因是《一九八四》的出版）。因此，控制及其各种同义词（操纵、导致）在乔姆斯基的评论中占据了重要地位，斯金纳的主要权威来源——他的啮齿动物压杆实验也是如此。第一次提到斯金纳，尴尬地（因此，突出地）插入了更一般的讨论中，这句话是：“斯金纳因其对动物行为研究的贡献而闻名”（1959 [1957]：26）。此后，动物，尤其是老鼠，不断出现，乔姆斯基反复强调老鼠在迷宫中寻找食物颗粒与最基本的言语行为之间的巨大鸿沟。

Nowadays, there is a disturbingly Orwellian ring to such talk, even in its bestintentioned varieties. Understanding human conduct is fine, desirable in fact, but control had begun to stir a chilling breeze in the fifties (cued, in part, by the publication of Nineteen Eighty-Four). Control and its various synonyms (manipulate, cause) therefore play a large role in Chomsky’s review, as does Skinner’s principal source of authority, his bar-pressing rodent experiments. The first mention of Skinner, stuck awkwardly (therefore, prominently) into a more general discussion, is this sentence: “Skinner is noted for his contributions to the study of animal behavior” (1959 [1957]:26). Animals, especially rats, recur incessantly thereafter, Chomsky repeatedly stressing the vastness of the gulf between a rat navigating a maze for a food pellet and even the most elementary verbal acts.

即使是行为主义早期的布鲁姆菲尔德也意识到，从语言学的角度来看，刺激和反应之间的距离非常大；这是他禁止意义（本质上被认为是对某种刺激的反应）和思维（刺激和反应之间的中介器官）的主要原因。但乔姆斯基强调了这一点，即这种鸿沟使得语言的刺激-反应、台球模型完全空洞：

Even Bloomfield, in the heady early days of behaviorism, realized the distance between a stimulus and a response in linguistic terms was formidably wide; that was the chief reason he outlawed meaning (considered, essentially, as the response to some stimulus) and mind (the mediative organ between stimulus and response). But Chomsky tattoos home the point that this gulf renders a stimulus-response, billiard-ball model of language completely vacuous:

在斯金纳看来，刺激控制的一个典型例子是对一段音乐做出反应说“莫扎特”，或者对一幅画做出反应说“荷兰”。这些反应被认为“受到物理对象或事件的极其微妙的属性的控制”[Skinner, 1957:108]。假设我们不说“荷兰” ，而是说“与墙纸不协调”，“我以为你喜欢抽象作品”，“以前从没见过”，“倾斜的”，“挂得太低的”，“美丽”，“丑陋的”，“还记得我们去年夏天的露营之旅吗？”，或者看画时可能想到的其他任何词……斯金纳只能说，这些反应都受到物理对象其他一些刺激属性的控制。（1959 [1957]:31；斜体为乔姆斯基所加；插值代替了他的脚注）

A typical example of a stimulus control for Skinner would be the response to a piece of music with the utterance Mozart or to a painting with the response Dutch. These responses are asserted to be “under the control of extremely subtle properties” of the physical object or event [Skinner, 1957:108]. Suppose instead of saying Dutch we had said Clashes with the wallpaper, I thought you liked abstract work, Never saw it before, Tilted, Hanging too low, Beautiful, Hideous, Remember our camping trip last summer?, or whatever else might come into our mind when looking at a picture. … Skinner could only say that each of these responses is under the control of some other stimulus property of the physical object. (1959 [1957]:31; Chomsky’s italics; the interpolation replaces his footnote)

乔姆斯基在这里站在天使一边，没错，就像斯金纳的龙一样，是圣乔治，但他也站在自由、有尊严、有创造力的个人一边，这些人属于包括莫扎特和伦勃朗在内的传统，他们是无法控制的人：他的观众。16

Chomsky is on the side of the angels here, all right, St. George to Skinner’s dragon, but he is also on the side of free, dignified, creative individuals, people who belong to a tradition that includes Mozart and Rembrandt, people who cannot be controlled: his audience.16

乔姆斯基的论证在理性方面与情感方面相辅相成，内容广泛，批判性十足。这篇长篇评论有稳定的评论脚注中充满了引人深思的内容，有些甚至言辞尖刻（“同样，‘一部文学作品的普遍性是指倾向于说同一件事的潜在读者的数量’……也就是说，最‘普遍’的作品是一本陈词滥调和问候语的词典。”—52n42），但大多数内容详细说明了乔姆斯基从浩如烟海的学习理论文献中收集到的反证、资格和可疑主张；读者永远不会忘记，乔姆斯基已经做足了功课。然而，对几乎所有读者来说，乔姆斯基攻击的最有效的部分不是他所列举的反证的范围，而是他针对行为主义提出的两个简短而有力的论据。一个论点基于创造力的概念。另一个论点被称为（大概是受龙自己的术语启发）刺激贫乏论据。

The intellectual aspects of Chomsky’s case, complementing the emotional aspects, are wide-ranging and damning. The long review has a steady commentary bulging from its footnotes, some of it bitingly glib (“Similarly, ‘the universality of a literary work refers to the number of potential readers inclined to say the same thing’… i.e., the most ‘universal’ work is a dictionary of clichés and greetings.”—52n42), but most of it detailing the counter-evidence, qualifications, and questionable claims Chomsky has gleaned from the vast literature of learning theory; Chomsky, the reader can never forget, has done his homework. The most effective part of Chomsky’s attack for almost every reader, however, is not the extent of the counterevidence he marshals, but the two brief and devastating arguments he levels at behaviorism. One argument is based on the notion of creativity. The other goes by the name (presumably inspired by the dragon’s own terminology), the poverty of stimulus argument.

乔姆斯基在评论中坚定地提倡创造力，这个概念本身就足以让人联想到莫扎特和荷兰大师，但在他的作品中，它具有非常具体、狭隘和技术性的含义，与生成语法密切相关。稍加思考（正如乔姆斯基语言学入门课程中的传统论点），就会发现有无数潜在的言语行为的语法片段从未被执行过，无数的语言语法片段从未被说出过，从未成为刺激，从未成为反应；例如，

Chomsky is a steadfast champion of creativity in the review, a notion broad enough to evoke Mozart and the Dutch Masters in its own right, but which has a very specific, narrow, and technical meaning in his work, coupled intimately with generative grammar. With a moment’s reflection (as the conventional argument in an introductory course in Chomskyan linguistics now runs), it is clear that there are innumerable grammatical pieces of potential verbal behavior which have never been performed before, innumerable grammatical pieces of language which have never been uttered, never been a stimulus, never been a response; for instance,

17

17

纳努克把一撮黄雪放在他的脸颊和牙龈之间。

Nanook put a pinch of yellow snow between his cheek and gums.

简单的行为主义模型很难解释这些事实。这句话不仅仅是“还记得我们去年夏天的露营之旅吗？”这种不可预测的句子，它是独一无二的。然而，英语使用者可以毫不费力地将 17 句识别为他们语言中合法的句子，尽管它令人讨厌。他们立刻就理解了这句话，而且，如果情况变得合适，他们自己也会毫不费力地说出这句话。总之，句子 17 说明了人类语法是创造性的：它们产生的输出不是输入的一部分。

A simple behaviorist model has huge difficulties accounting for such facts. The sentence is not just unpredictable, in the sense of “Remember our camping trip last summer?” It is unique. Yet speakers of English have no trouble recognizing 17 as a legitimate, if unsavory, sentence of their language. They understand it immediately, and they would have no trouble, in the unlikely event that the circumstances become appropriate, producing it themselves. In a word, sentence 17 illustrates that human grammars are creative: they produce output which is not part of their input.

输出和输入对乔姆斯基来说很重要，因为他认为人类语言最重要的因素是儿童能够迅速地从他们听到的语言输入数据转变为完全掌握该语言，再到受控且符合语法的输出。从这篇评论开始（李斯 1957 年的预测，霍克特 1948 年的预测也在一定程度上预测了这一点），语言习得成为乔姆斯基论证的重要组成部分：乔姆斯基坚持认为，语言学要解决的核心问题是这种创造能力如何在儿童的大脑中如此迅速地建立起来。这个问题是他最成功地抨击斯金纳以及斯金纳的所有事物的问题。

Output and input are important for Chomsky because he came to see the single most important factor about human language to be the ability children have to move rapidly from the input data of language they hear to a full command of that language, to a controlled and grammatical output. From this review on (anticipated by Lees, 1957, and to some degree by Hockett, 1948), language acquisition becomes an essential component of Chomsky’s argumentation: the central problem for linguistics to solve, Chomsky insists, is how this creative ability establishes itself so quickly in the brain of a child. This problem is the one with which he most successfully flays not only Skinner but all things Skinnerian.

乔姆斯基说，行为主义学习理论基于“精心安排的强化条件”和行为主义者认为“儿童学习单词含义和句法模式所必需的”的“细致训练”（1959 [1957]：39）。他赶紧补充说，这一立场“不是基于实际观察，而是基于与低等生物的类比”，所以我们应该看看这些成分是否是必需的。它们不是。正如刺激贫乏论证所说，人类语言是高度抽象、非常复杂、无限的现象，最引人注目的事实之一是，尽管数据杂乱无章且退化（数据来源：刺激是学习英语的主要方式。对于大多数句子类型，儿童听到的例子相对较少，除了发音之外，他们几乎得不到任何纠正（通常连发音都没有），而且他们会接触到令人眼花缭乱的错误开头、未标记的错误、半句等等。声音和单词是布卢姆菲尔德关注的主要单位，它们易于通过刺激-反应习得；孩子说“冰淇淋”，​​就会得到一些冰淇淋。句法，即乔姆斯基的自然媒介，却并非如此。句子变化太多、太动态、太有创意，以至于无法与老鼠和它的酒吧建立任何有意义的对应关系。

Behaviorist learning theory, Chomsky says, is based on a “careful arrangement of contingencies of reinforcement” and on the “meticulous training” behaviorists regard as “necessary for a child to learn the meanings of words and syntactic patterns” (1959 [1957]:39). This position, he hastens to add, “is based not on actual observation, but on analogies to lower organisms,” so we are behooved to see if in fact these ingredients are necessary. They aren’t. As the poverty of stimulus argument goes, one of the most remarkable facts about human languages—which are highly abstract, very complex, infinite phenomena—is that children acquire them in an astonishingly short period of time, despite haphazard and degenerate data (the “stimulus”). Children hear relatively few examples of most sentence types, they get little or no correction beyond pronunciation (often not even that), and they are exposed to a bewildering array of false starts, unlabeled mistakes, half sentences, and the like. Sounds and words, the principal Bloomfieldian units of focus, are amenable to stimulus-response acquisition; the child says “ice cream” and gets some ice cream. Syntax, Chomsky’s natural medium, is not. Sentences are too variable, too dynamic, too creative, to have any significant correspondences to a rat and its bar.
