简而言之，他们是一对天才组合。他们的表演建立在对“弗洛伊德打破了玻璃”的夸张分析之上，不知疲倦，鼓舞人心。1967 年德克萨斯州环球音乐大会（他们受邀担任评论员）的会议记录前言在一定程度上表明了他们给人留下的印象：

They were, in short, a gifted duo. Their performances, built on their extravagant analysis of “Floyd broke the glass,” were tireless and inspiring. The preface to the proceedings of the 1967 Texas Conference on Universals, for which they were invited commentators, gives some indication of the impression they were cutting:

如果我们不提及罗斯和莱考夫的贡献，我们将对研讨会产生完全错误的印象。他们不仅扮演了讨论者的角色，而且还非常友善地留在奥斯汀，花了大约六个小时介绍他们最近的一些工作[随后是“弗洛伊德”分析的概要]。（Bach and Harms，1968：viif）

We would give a totally false picture of the symposium if we did not mention the contribution of Ross and Lakoff, who not only played a role as discussants but were kind enough to remain in Austin to devote approximately six hours to a presentation of some of their recent work [followed by an epitome of the “Floyd” analysis]. (Bach and Harms, 1968:viif)

生成语义学正在顺利发展；瞧，在东方，乔姆斯基。

Generative semantics was well on its way; lo, in the east, Chomsky.

反弹

The Backlash

他们是否应该煽动听众的思想走向错误，热情地劝诫他们，用言语感动他们，使他们感到恐惧、悲伤和兴奋，而捍卫真理的人却变得迟钝、冷漠和昏昏欲睡？

Should they, urging the minds of their listeners into error, ardently exhort them, moving them by speech so that they terrify, sadden, and exhilarate them, while the defenders of the truth are sluggish, cold and somnolent?

奥古斯丁

Augustine

拉科夫在谈到他第一次涉足生成语义学时说：“乔姆斯基从一开始就不喜欢它”（这在一定程度上损害了他关于罗斯-拉科夫研讨会都是关于成为优秀的乔姆斯基主义者的言论；拉科夫知道乔姆斯基的布隆菲尔德的“从一开始就”是一个相当明确的立场，虽然他这句话只是想说明乔姆斯基的反感可以追溯到他 1963 年的论文，但是“从一开始就”一词对乔姆斯基来说更为广泛，可以追溯到他职业生涯的开始。早在 1955 年，斯莱德（1962 [1958]）认为布隆菲尔德对意义持最强硬立场的一篇论文中，乔姆斯基就非常明确地阐述了这一点——“如果能够表明意义和相关概念在语言分析中确实发挥了作用，那么……语言理论的基础就会受到严重打击”（1955a: 141）——而且他很少软化这一立场，从未放弃过它。事实上，乔姆斯基的立场可以追溯到更早，可以追溯到乔姆斯基的老师古德曼和哈里斯，当然也可以追溯到对哈里斯影响深远的布隆菲尔德，也可以追溯到对布隆菲尔德有影响的惠特尼，甚至更早。确实，当乔姆斯基将深层结构描述为“纯粹的精神性的东西，传达句子的语义内容”（1966a:35）时，他似乎已经接近了笛卡尔语言学中的生成语义学的边缘，但他小心翼翼地与这种描述保持距离。他只是将其作为对 Port-Royal 立场的解释，并附上了“据说如此”之类的短语。乔姆斯基一直对意义有着浓厚的兴趣，但他是一位深刻而坚定的句法原教旨主义者。

Of his first venture into generative semantics, Lakoff says “Chomsky didn’t like it from the beginning” (compromising, to some degree, his remarks that the Ross-Lakoff seminars were all about being good little Chomskyans; Lakoff knew Chomsky’s position), and although he means in this remark only to date Chomsky’s antipathy from his 1963 paper, “from the beginning” holds more widely of Chomsky, all the way back to the start of his career. As early as 1955, in a paper that Sledd (1962 [1958]) takes to represent the hardest Bloomfieldian hard line on meaning, Chomsky was very explicit on this point—“if it can be shown that meaning and related notions do play a role in linguistic analysis, then … a serious blow is struck at the foundations of linguistic theory” (1955a:141)—and he has only rarely softened this position, never abandoned it. Indeed, Chomsky’s position can be traced even earlier, to Goodman and Harris, Chomsky’s teachers, certainly to Bloomfield, who had a deep influence on Harris, back to Whitney, an influence on Bloomfield, and earlier. Chomsky comes to what looks like the brink of generative semantics in Cartesian Linguistics, true, when he describes deep structure as something “that is purely mental, that conveys the semantic content of the sentence” (1966a:35), but he is careful to distance himself from the characterization. He offers it only as his interpretation of the Port-Royal stance, and accompanies it with phrases like “so it is claimed.” Chomsky has always had a sidelong interest in meaning, but he is a deep and abiding syntactic fundamentalist.

在笛卡尔语言学和乔姆斯基 60 年代中期的其他著作中，意义和心理主义的混合体很容易被忽略，尤其是因为这些著作紧随卡茨和福多尔、波斯特尔和乔姆斯基本人的有前途的著作之后，这些著作似乎驯服了意义。同样，他早期关于保持结构和意义分离的极端布鲁姆菲尔德主义论点的阅读频率远低于提出新的语义扩展性的作品。因此，用雷·杰肯多夫的话来说，当乔姆斯基 1967 年从伯克利休假回到麻省理工学院并开始举办一系列讲座时，这“令人大吃一惊”，这些讲座完全扭转了深化深层结构的抽象语法趋势。2他的学生在最初的震惊和疑惑之后，发现这些讲座令人振奋；二年级博士生杰肯多夫尤其激动，因为他最近的研究与生成语义学毫无关系，并且严重损害了Aspects模型，但却与乔姆斯基产生了共鸣。

Phrases like “so it is claimed” were easily overlooked in all the commingle of meaning and mentalism in Cartesian Linguistics and Chomsky’s other works of the mid-sixties, especially since they came hard on the heels of the promising work of Katz and Fodor, and Postal, and Chomsky himself, that seemed to tame meaning. Too, his early hyper-Bloomfieldian arguments about keeping structure and meaning separate were read much less frequently than works suggesting a new semantic expansiveness. So it was, in Ray Jackendoff’s phrase, “a dreadful surprise” when Chomsky returned to MIT from his Berkeley sabbatical in 1967, and launched a series of lectures that completely reversed the abstract syntax trend of deepening deep structure.2 His students, after some initial shock and puzzlement, found these lectures invigorating; Jackendoff, a second-year doctoral student, was particularly thrilled that his own recent research, research which had no home at all in generative semantics and compromised the Aspects model considerably, was resonating with Chomsky.

这些讲座——“评论”讲座，以其中的著名论文“名词化评论”（1972b [1967]）命名——的目的并不令人费解。每个人都立即认为它们是对生成语义学的攻击，是一种试图从新兴模型中切断抽象腿的反动尝试。纽梅尔对这些讲座的最好称呼是。他称它们是“反攻”（1980a：114；1986a：107），这捕捉到了它们受到的反应、攻击和提高赌注的气氛。然而，乔姆斯基——这里的故事变得特别奇怪——说他当时对生成语义学或抽象语法不太感兴趣，他“几乎对它们一无所知”，他几乎没有注意到波斯特尔、拉科夫、罗斯和麦考利正在从事的工作。他说，他 1967 年在麻省理工学院的演讲只是对李氏的《英语名词化语法》（该书于五十年代末期写成，乔姆斯基贡献颇多）的延迟反应。

There was no puzzlement about where these lectures—the “Remarks” lectures, named after the famous paper that came out of them, “Remarks on Nominalization”(1972b [1967])—were aimed. Everyone immediately perceived them as an attack on generative semantics, a reactionary attempt to cut the abstract legs out from underneath the upstart model. The best term for the lectures is Newmeyer’s. He calls them a “counteroffensive” (1980a:114; 1986a:107), which captures the air of reaction, assault, and upping-the-ante in which they were received. Chomsky, though—here the story gets particularly bizarre—says he wasn’t much interested in generative semantics or in abstract syntax at the time, that he “knew virtually nothing about” either, that he barely noticed the work Postal, Lakoff, Ross, and McCawley were up to. His 1967 MIT lectures, he says, were just a delayed reaction to Lees’s Grammar of English Nominalizations (written in the very late fifties with considerable input from Chomsky).

我曾将李氏语法描述为生成语义学发展的一个反面例子，而这种发展的各个方面无疑是对过于具体的转换和句法范畴的混乱的反应。在 20 世纪 60 年代早期，Lees 的工作是这一领域的典范。但生成语义学发展的另一个方面延续了 Lees 开创的趋势。Lees 项目的一个关键部分是用较少的基础范畴来解释大量名词化，例如，从动词transgress中转化派生出名词transgressor、transgression和transgressing (动名词) 。抽象语法强势接管了这种范畴减少工作，将深层词汇范畴精简为名词和动词，通过转化派生出其他所有词汇（以及大量名词）。俗话说，对于只有锤子的人来说，所有东西看起来都像钉子。对于只有转化能力的 Lees 来说，所有东西看起来都像是运动的例子。

I have depicted Lees’s Grammar as something of a negative example in the growth of generative semantics, and aspects of that growth were certainly a reaction to the welter of overly specific transformations and the panoply of syntactic categories in the early sixties work Lees epitomizes. But another aspect in the growth of generative semantics continued a trend that Lees was pioneering. A key part of Lees’s project was to account for a wide number of nominalizations with a smaller number of underlying categories, transformationally deriving, for instance, the nouns transgressor, transgression, and transgressing (the gerundive) from the verb, transgress. Abstract syntax took over this category-reduction work with a vengeance, thinning out the deep lexical categories to just nouns and verbs, deriving everything else (and a good many of the nouns to boot) transformationally. To the man who has only a hammer, runs the adage, everything looks like a nail. To Lees, who had only the transformation, everything must have looked like a case of movement.

乔姆斯基现在回忆说，他当时认为李斯“过度使用了变换”，这种担心是可以理解的，尽管李斯严格遵循乔姆斯基自己作品中列出的程序（特别是 1975a [1955]、1957a、1962a [1958]）。乔姆斯基说，对李斯使用变换的这种担忧困扰了他好几年，在大脑皮层中酝酿了七八年，最后爆发到他的工作中，巧合的是，他采用了一种与抽象语法完全相反的方法，巧合的是，就在几个月前，莱科夫和罗斯宣布生成语义学开始流行。

Chomsky now recalls thinking that Lees “was way overdoing the use of transformations,” an understandable concern, though Lees was religiously following the program laid out in Chomsky’s own work (in particular, 1975a [1955], 1957a, 1962a [1958]). This concern with Lees’s use of transformations, Chomsky says, preyed on him for several years, simmering on some cortical back burner for seven or eight years, when it boiled over into his work, coincidentally taking a completely inverse approach to the one that abstract syntax had adopted and coincidentally coming just months after Lakoff and Ross had declared generative semantics open for business.

“评论”讲座最大的困惑，也就是杰肯多夫提到的可怕惊喜，是它们的理论方向。转换方案的旗舰之一一直是句法结构所称的“非常有趣和分支的名词化转换集”（1957a:72）。名词化的转换分析可以追溯到哈里斯最早的作品，而李斯的《语法》被广泛认为是转换语法的入门课（已经印刷了五次）。但乔姆斯基围绕这一建议组织了他在 1967 年麻省理工学院的讲座，即一些名词化最好不经过转换处理。特别是，早期的作品从 lb 中衍生出 la，而乔姆斯基现在认为，像refusal这样的词应该在词典中得到充分体现。

The big puzzle of the “Remarks” lectures, the dreadful surprise Jackendoff mentions, was their theoretical direction. One of the flagships of the transformational program had always been what Syntactic Structures called the “very interesting and ramified set of nominalizing transformations” (1957a:72). The transformational analysis of nominalizations dated back to Harris’s earliest work, and Lees’s Grammar was widely regarded as a how-to lesson in transformational grammar (it had already been through five printings). But Chomsky organized his 1967 MIT lectures around the proposal that some nominalizations are better treated without transformations. In particular, where earlier work had derived la from lb transformationally, Chomsky now argued that words like refusal should be represented fully in the lexicon.

1

1

乔治拒绝敲打他的地毯。

a George’s refusal to beat his rug.

 

 

b 乔治拒绝让乔治打他的地毯。

b George refused for George to beat his rug.

对于每个旁听讲座或阅读摘要论文的人来说，这种方法的直接动机似乎很明确：乔姆斯基的提议直击生成语义学的核心。

For everyone who sat in on the lectures, or read the paper abstracted from them, the immediate motive of this approach seemed clear: Chomsky’s proposal struck squarely at the kidneys of generative semantics.

他的论证意义远远超出了如何解释名词化的程序问题。他提出了一种称为词汇学假说的方法，这种方法大大削弱了迄今为止转换改变句法类别的神圣权利，这种权利实际上定义了生成语义学背后的抽象句法程序，他系统地将这种方法与转换主义方法直接对立起来，尽管转换主义方法实际上是唯一的方法（无论如何，李斯是其最明显的支持者），但他与乔治·莱考夫未发表的论文密切相关，并反复与之联系在一起。

The implications of his arguments went considerably beyond the procedural matter of how to account for nominalization. He proposed an approach—called the lexicalist hypothesis—which greatly reduced the heretofore divine right of transformations to change syntactic categories, a right which virtually defined the abstract syntax program underlying generative semantics, and he systematically stood this approach in direct opposition to the transformationalist approach, which, although it was really the only approach around (and, in any case, Lees was its most obvious proponent), he connected closely and repeatedly with George Lakoff’s unpublished thesis.

乔姆斯基的词汇主义假设认为，“很多词条出现在词汇表中时，带有固定的选择和严格的子范畴化特征，但可以选择与词汇范畴名词、动词、形容词相关的特征”（1972b [1967]:22），但在拉科夫 (Lakoff) 的实际表述中，它很快就意味着词汇条项“在转换派生过程中不得改变范畴”（1967:8）。3一旦成为范畴，就永远是范畴。这一举措宣告了抽象语法程序的大部分不合法性。它的一个旗舰成果是将词汇变异归结为几个基本范畴——这种提炼在很大程度上取决于既定的转换机制改变范畴的能力；例如，将深层动词变成表层形容词。

Chomsky’s formulation of the lexicalist hypothesis proposes that “a great many items appear in the lexicon with fixed selectional and strict subcategorization features, but with a choice as to the features associated with the lexical categories noun, verb, adjective” (1972b [1967]:22), but it rapidly came to mean, in Lakoff’s practical rephrasing, that lexical items “may not change category in the course of a transformational derivation” (1967:8).3 Once a category, that is, always a category. This move declares much of the abstract syntax program illegitimate. One of its flagships was the boiling down of lexical variation to just a few underlying categories—a distillation that depended heavily on the ability of established transformational mechanisms to change categories; to, for instance, change a deep verb into a surface adjective.

现在，该领域的创始人宣称所有这些派生背后的论据都是错误的。在此过程中，他否认了在他特别支持下所阐述的大部分工作（他实际上指导了李斯关于名词化的论文）。他支持他在《新约》中明确驳斥的立场：“显然，破坏、拒绝等词不会以这样的方式进入词典。相反，破坏和拒绝将进入词典……[并且]名词化转换将在派生的适当阶段应用”（1965 [1964]：184）。在交易中——也许是所有交易中最可怕的意外——他对Aspects模型的基石之一，即 KatzPostal 假设表示怀疑。4乔姆斯基的学生苏珊·菲舍尔回忆起这些讲座时说：“这完全是句法上的失误。”

Now the founder of the field proclaimed the arguments behind all such derivations misguided. In the process, he disowned much of the work elaborated under his specific endorsement (he had virtually directed Lees’s thesis on nominalizations). He advocated a position he specifically dismissed in the New Testament: “Clearly, the words destruction, refusal, etc., will not be entered into the lexicon as such. Rather, destroy and refuse will be entered into the lexicon … [and] a nominalization transformation will apply at the appropriate stage in the derivation” (1965 [1964]:184). In the bargain—perhaps the most dreadful surprise of them all—he cast suspicion on one of the cornerstones of the Aspects model, the KatzPostal hypothesis.4 As Chomsky’s student Susan Fischer recalls these lectures, “the shit hit the syntactic fan.”

词汇学家的争论

Lexicalist Wranglings

人们在阅读《关于名词化的评论》时，根本不会想到那里对词汇和深层结构的描述以前并不存在，而只是因为 GS [生成语义学] 推动乔姆斯基重新定义他的立场而发展起来的——相当彻底地。

One reads “Remarks on Nominalization” without a clue that the description there of the lexicon and of deep structure existed nowhere before and was developed only because GS [generative semantics] pushed Chomsky to redefine his position—quite radically.

罗宾·莱考夫

Robin Lakoff

几乎所有麻省理工学院以外的人，以及麻省理工学院内部的一些人，都认为“评论”讲座不过是疯狂的修正主义。事实上，《Aspects》中有一些迹象表明词汇主义假设是乔姆斯基的一个潜在未来，而罗宾·莱考夫不愿承认这一点，《名词化评论》中也有一些线索表明，这是对抽象语法和生成语义学的一种反应，而罗宾·莱考夫不愿承认这一点。但总的来说，她的评价是正确的：《Aspects》肯定更倾向于支持抽象语法而不是词汇主义，而《评论》则非常谨慎。它将令人惊讶的新提议包装成《Aspects》模型的自然延伸，并将“转型主义者”追求的自然延伸描述为误入歧途。

Almost everyone outside of MIT, and some inside, took the “Remarks” lectures to be little more than crackpot revisionism. There are actually a few more indications in Aspects that the lexicalist hypothesis is one potential future for Chomsky than Robin Lakoff prefers to admit, and there are a few more clues in “Remarks on Nominalization” that it is a reaction to abstract syntax and generative semantics than she admits. But, in general, her assessment is right on the mark: Aspects certainly looks to endorse abstract syntax much more than lexicalism, and “Remarks” plays its cards pretty close to the vest. It dresses up surprising new proposals as natural extensions of the Aspects model, and characterizes the natural extensions pursued by the “transformationalists” as a misguided detour.

为了支持这些部分保守、部分激进的举措，乔姆斯基的论据是模糊、不成熟和临时的。例如，为了摆脱困境，他诉诸类比——一个常识性的概念，演讲者可能会创造“优先考虑”这个词来类比现有的词，如“文明”或“氧化” ——据说这是表现而不是能力的属性。你可能会说这很好，但他对类比作用的轻蔑观点是众所周知的，5，除了他使用这个词来支持词汇主义这一点相当特殊。出于某些原因，我们无需深究，以下两个语法性主张可以支持乔姆斯基的词汇主义假设：

In support of these partly conservative, partly radical, moves Chomsky’s arguments are vague, half-baked, and ad hoc. To get out of one pickle, for instance, he appealed to analogy—the common-sense notion that a speaker might coin the word prioritize on analogy to an existing word like civilize, or oxidize—said to be a property of performance rather than competence. Well and good, you might say, except that his dismissive views on the role of analogy were well known,5 and except that the use he puts it to, supporting lexicalism, is rather peculiar. For reasons we needn’t go into, the following two grammaticality claims serve Chomsky’s argument for the lexicalist hypothesis:

2

2

a 他还没读完这本书就对它提出批评，这让我很恼火。

a His criticizing the book before he read it annoyed me.

 

 

b * 他在阅读这本书之前对这本书的批评非常有见地。

b *His criticism of the book before he read it was strangely insightful.

乔姆斯基补充道：“然而，假设我们发现有些说话者认为 [2b 这样的表达] 完全可以接受”（确实，有些人确实这么认为），那么“我们可能会认为 [2b] 是通过类比动名词名词而形成的（2a 中对此进行了批评），比如说，在某些情况下，通过将X-ing转换为名词 X nom（其中nom是决定派生名词的形态形式的元素）”（1972b [1967]：27-8）。他接着说，如果这种分析是正确的，那么它“表明未能区分 [2b] 和 [2a] 的说话者没有意识到他们内化的语法的一个特性”（1972b [1967]：28）；简而言之，对于不符合词汇学假设所要求的语法性判断的说话者来说，2b仍然是不合语法的，但由于类比的表现规则，它是可以接受的。

“Suppose that we discover, however, that some speakers find [expressions like 2b] quite acceptable,” Chomsky adds (and, indeed, some people do), then “we might propose that [2b is] formed by analogy to the gerundive nominals [criticizing in 2a], say by a rule that converts X-ing to the noun X nom (where nom is the element that determines the morphological form of the derived nominal) in certain cases” (1972b [1967]:27–8). If this analysis is correct, he goes on, then it “indicates that speakers who fail to distinguish [2b] from [2a] are not aware of a property of their internalized grammar” (1972b [1967]:28); in short, for speakers who do not conform to the grammaticality judgments required by the lexicalist hypothesis, 2b is still ungrammatical, but acceptable due to analogic rules of performance.

当时比这种随意的呼吁更成问题的是他为短语结构规则提出的模式，即后来的-syntax（读作“x-bar syntax”）。它完全重新定位了短语结构成分，迫切需要一个无定形且不受保护的实体，即specifier，这以某种未经调查的方式让人回想起哈里斯早期的工作——它在论文中的唯一作用是解释某些对应关系（像乔姆斯基批评拉科夫这样的句子与像乔姆斯基对拉科夫的批评这样的名词短语之间的结构相似性），这些对应关系已经在转换论中得到解释，但在新词汇主义假说中却没有得到解释。也就是说，-syntax 的唯一目的似乎是支持词汇主义假说，而词汇主义假说的唯一目的似乎是破坏抽象句法。

Even more problematic at the time than such offhand appeals was the schema he proposed for phrase structure rules which has become known as -syntax (pronounced “x-bar syntax”). It completely reoriented the phrase-structure component, critically required an amorphous and undefended entity called specifier, harkened back in some uninvestigated way to earlier work by Harris—and its only role in the paper is to explain certain correspondences (the structural similarities between sentences like Chomsky criticized Lakoff and noun phrases like Chomsky’s criticism of Lakoff) that were already explained under the transformational account but not under the new lexicalist hypothesis. That is, the only purpose of -syntax seemed to be to prop up the lexicalist hypothesis, and the only purpose of the lexicalist hypothesis seemed to be to undermine abstract syntax.

乔姆斯基否定了早期的成功工作，建议对Aspects模型进行彻底的修改，并为这些修改开辟了临时的逃避渠道——所有这一切都是基于相当薄弱的证据——而任何人都可以看出，其动机只不过是削弱他最有成效的同事以及他们共同培养的一些最有前途的学生的工作。

Chomsky repudiated successful early work, proposed radical changes to the Aspects model, and opened ad hoc escape channels for those changes—all on the basis of quite meager evidence—with no more motivation, as far as anyone could see, than to cripple the work of his most productive colleague and of some of the most promising former students they shared.

莱科夫和罗斯大为震惊。他们原本以为乔姆斯基回来后会引发一些骚动，但结果却出乎所有人的意料，而且从他们的角度来看，这是一条非常奇怪的道路。他们旁听了讲座（其中包括对莱科夫论文中提出的许多抽象分析的具体攻击），并一路与乔姆斯基争论。他们还试图在课外与乔姆斯基讨论这些问题，但收效甚微。当时，乔姆斯基正积极参与政治活动，他的声望在学术界内外迅速传播。他的时间安排非常紧张。莱科夫尤其感到被冷落了，但波斯特尔说，乔姆斯基可能只是没有看到会议的任何潜在利益：

Lakoff and Ross were shaken to the bone. They were expecting some sort of brouhaha when Chomsky returned, but it was taking a completely different route than anyone could have predicted, and, from their perspective, a very peculiar one. They sat in on the lectures (which included specific attacks on many of the abstract analyses presented in Lakoff’s dissertation), and argued with Chomsky every step of the way. They also tried to talk about these issues with Chomsky outside of class, but had very little success. Chomsky was getting thickly involved in political activism at the time, and his popularity was spreading rapidly inside and outside of academia. He had very little free room in his schedule. Lakoff, in particular, felt snubbed, but Postal says that Chomsky probably just didn’t see any potential profit in the meetings:

从他的角度来看，我认为他并不急于和他们交谈。对他来说这当然不是什么紧急的事情。他们对此感到有些紧迫。他们觉得他们可能有重要的事情要告诉他，但我怀疑他是否觉得他们有什么重要的事情要告诉他。

Viewed from his perspective, I don’t think he had any great desire to talk to them. It certainly was no urgent matter for him. They viewed it with some urgency. They felt that they probably had something important to tell him, but I doubt if he felt they had anything important to tell him.

我怀疑他是否真的回避他们。我怀疑他不在乎这些，如果他有更紧迫的事情要做，他就会去做。他当然更愿意和《时代》杂志的某个人交谈，而不是他们，所以他们可能被推开了，生气了，然后放弃了。6

I doubt that he really avoided them. I suspect he didn’t care one way or the other, and if he had more pressing things to do, he would do them. He would certainly much rather talk to some guy from Time magazine than them, so they probably got shunted off, and got pissed, and gave up.6

莱考夫的解释远没有那么宽容，他认为此后十年的大部分时间里双方的敌意都是从这一时刻开始的：“[由于我们无法私下与他交谈] 我们认为与他交谈的唯一方法就是在课堂上提出反例，这让他非常愤怒。” 乔姆斯基的课堂变得越来越有争议，激烈的争论频繁爆发，而莱考夫通常处于风暴的中心。7但乔姆斯基是一位辩论高手，他处理莱考夫的反对意见的方式几乎让所有听众都满意。他自己的研究生尤其印象深刻。除了讲座中明显的反生成语义学倾向外，他们的理论也非常丰富，并在他的学生中引发了一阵活动，这些活动迅速发展成为解释语义学模型。

Lakoff’s interpretation is far less generous, and he dates the animosity that characterized much of the next ten years from exactly this point: “[Since we couldn’t talk to him in private] we figured that the only way to talk to him was to start bringing up counter-examples in class, and that infuriated him.” Chomsky’s classes became increasingly contentious, heated arguments breaking out frequently, and Lakoff was usually at the center of the storm.7 But Chomsky is a virtuoso debater, and he handled Lakoff’s objections to the satisfaction of virtually the entire audience. His own graduate students were especially impressed. In addition to the distinctively anti-generative semantics bent of the lectures, they were also incredibly rich theoretically, and set off a flurry of activity among his students, activity which rapidly bloomed into the interpretive semantics model.

但这仅仅是个开始。在“评论”讲座之后，乔姆斯基进入了一段绝对史无前例的时期：几年来，他几乎只发表负面言论，记录在两篇长文中（1972b [1968]：62-119，[1969]：120-202），其明确目的是要摧毁生成语义学。乔姆斯基确实投入了大量的时间和精力来攻击他人的工作。他在麻省理工学院语言学分水岭时期开设的“坏人”课程臭名昭著，他很少让批评逃脱他的严厉批评，即使只是谴责它不值得他关注。例如，以下是典型的驳斥：

But this was only the beginning. Chomsky followed the “Remarks” lectures with an absolutely unprecedented period: several years of almost exclusively negative rhetoric, documented in two long papers (1972b [1968]:62–119, [1969]:120–202), whose express aim was to eviscerate generative semantics. Chomsky has certainly devoted considerable time and energy to assaulting other people’s work. His “Bad Guys” courses in the watershed years of MIT linguistics are notorious, and he lets very little criticism escape his withering notice, if only to condemn it as beneath his notice. Take, for instance, this typical dismissal:

我不会在这里考虑赖希林对生成语法的批评。引用的评论只是他完全不理解他所讨论的作品的目标、关注点和具体内容的一个例证，他的讨论是基于对这部作品的严重歪曲，几乎不需要评论。（1966b [1964]：9）

I will not consider Reichling’s criticisms of generative grammar here. The cited remark is just one illustration of his complete lack of comprehension of the goals, concerns, and specific content of the work he was discussing, and his discussion is based on such gross misrepresentations of this work that comment is hardly called for. (1966b [1964]:9)

但是，即使考虑到他回击批评者并攻击他认为在思想上危险的观点的倾向，这段时期也是异常的。除了提交给第九届国际代表大会的论文外，他反对布隆菲尔德计划的大部分论据都分散在原始提案中。而 BF 斯金纳，乔姆斯基认为 20 世纪心理学中所有邪恶事物的倡导者，只收到了两篇论文，相隔十多年（1959 [1957]；1970），他对《言语行为》的评论，以及《纽约书评》中更一般、更明显的意识形态攻击。攻击同事和前学生在他自己的框架内发展的生成语义学，几乎占据了他几年来所有的语言学精力。一堂又一堂的讲座，他拿起、剖析并抛弃了生成语义学提案：一次给 McCawley 的讲座，一次给 Postal 的讲座，三次给 Lakoff 的讲座，还有一次给 McCawley 的讲座……

But, even given his penchant for returning the fire of his critics and for attacking views he regards as intellectually dangerous, this period is anomalous. Aside from his paper to the Ninth International Congress, most of his arguments against the Bloomfieldian program are scattered among original proposals. And B. F. Skinner, the apostle of everything Chomsky considers evil in twentieth-century psychology, received only two papers, over a decade apart (1959 [1957]; 1970), his review of Verbal Behavior, and a more general, more clearly ideological assault in The New York Review of Books. Attacking generative semantics, a development within his own framework, by colleagues and former students, occupied virtually all of his linguistic energies for several years. Lecture after lecture, he took up, dissected, and discarded generative semantics proposals: one lecture to McCawley, one to Postal, three to Lakoff, another one to McCawley …

学生和反对者都感到震惊。本世纪最富有创造力的思想家之一正在顽固地扼杀异端，几乎没有做出原创研究（以他的标准来看，非常少）。即使是“评论”工作，虽然内容丰富且原创（词汇和语法最终都取得了巨大的成功），也过于粗略，无法产生太大影响，尤其是对那些没有参加讲座、只有油印版可供参考的人。证据他为词汇学家提出的假设充其量也只是没有定论，还夹杂着一些无法令人信服的类比论证，并提出了一个模糊的提议（-syntax），要求彻底改革短语结构规则。正如当时最同情乔姆斯基的学生之一在谈到乔姆斯基的开创性影响时所说：“我们都认为他已经大获全胜了。”

Students and opponents alike were alarmed. One of the most fecund minds of the century was doggedly stamping the life out of a heresy, producing little (by his standards, extremely little) original research. Even the “Remarks” work, rich and original as it was (both lexicalism and -syntax eventually became immensely successful), was too sketchy to make much impact, especially on people who weren’t present for the lectures and had only the mimeographed version to go by. The evidence he presented for the lexicalist hypothesis was inconclusive at best, spliced in with unconvincing appeals like the one to analogy, and came with a vaguely adumbrated proposal (-syntax) for completely overhauling the phrase structure rules. As one of his most sympathetic students at the time puts it, apropos of Chomsky’s seminal influence: “We all thought he had shot his wad.”

扩展标准理论

The Extended Standard Theory

通过使敌方士兵怀疑其行动的合理性，并让困惑和迷茫的心灵有理由怀疑他们的选择是否明智，你就获得了成功的所有机会。

By making the enemy soldier doubt the well-foundedness of his cause, and giving to confused and bewildered minds reason for doubting the wisdom of their choice, you bring to your side all chances of success.

毛主席

Chairman Mao

乔姆斯基巧妙地占据了名义上的制高点，迅速将Aspects模型称为“标准理论”，而他对其的词汇修订则称为“扩展标准理论”。大多数语言学家认为，Postal 的计划及其衍生的生成语义学是Aspects最自然的延伸。事实上，Lakoff 在公开信中对“评论”的回复反复提到抽象语法是“扩展的转换理论”（1967:7），并提到过滤器和约束等机制构成了“假定语法理论的扩展版本”（1967:4）。更重要的是，转换和语义解释规则的趋同似乎是卡兹邮政原则 (KatzPostal Principle) 承诺的必然实现，实际上是语言学的必然实现：“我们知道我们想说什么”，莱考夫 (Lakoff) 在为生成语义学提出的第一个论证中说道，然后我们“找到一种表达方式”(1976a [1963]:50)；在导致体 (Aspects)的创新之后，似乎很明显转换就是表达方式。

Chomsky, in a deft capture of the nominal high ground, promptly dubbed the Aspects model “the standard theory,” and his lexicalist revisions to it, “the extended standard theory.” Most linguists thought that Postal’s program and the generative semantics that it spawned were the most natural extensions to Aspects. Indeed, Lakoff’s public-letter answer to “Remarks” speaks repeatedly of abstract syntax as “extending transformational theory” (1967:7) and of mechanisms like filters and constraints as constituting an “extended version of the assumed theory of grammar” (1967:4). More importantly, the convergence of transformations and semantic interpretation rules seemed like the inevitable fulfillment of the KatzPostal principle’s promise, virtually the inevitable fulfillment of linguistics: “We know what we want to say,” Lakoff said in the first argument offered for generative semantics, and then we “find a way of saying it” (1976a [1963]:50); after the innovations leading to Aspects, it seemed apparent that transformations were the way of saying it.

一直存在一个问题，即从含义到形式的转换过于随意，就像我们熟悉的 3a 和 3b 这样的句子。

There had always been a problem with transformations moving blithely from meaning to form, sentences like the familiar 3a and 3b.

3

3

a 鸬鹚岛上的每个人都说两种语言。

a Everyone on Cormorant Island speaks two languages.

 

 

b 鸬鹚岛上的每个人都说两种语言。

b Two languages are spoken by everyone on Cormorant Island.

对于句法结构研究领域的乔姆斯基来说，3a 和 3b 说明“主动和被动之间通常不成立，哪怕是最弱的语义关系（事实等价性）也不成立”（1957a:101）；因此被动转换会改变含义；因此转换不会将您从潜在含义带到表面形式。Katz 和 Postal 试图弥补这个漏洞，对他们来说，3a 和 3b“同样具有歧义，彼此的完整释义也是如此”（1964:72）——它们都有相同的两种解读和不同的两种解读。对于越来越谨慎的体貌研究领域的乔姆斯基来说，3a 和 3b 是一个小谜团。他们似乎认为卡茨-波斯特尔假说“太强了”，但“我们可以坚持认为，在这些例子中，两种解释都是潜在的”，他认为这一主张很有吸引力（1965 [1964]:224n9），他在《Aspects》中就这一主题发表了最权威的声明，他说

For the Chomsky of Syntactic Structures, 3a and 3b illustrate “that not even the weakest semantic relation (factual equivalence) holds in general between active and passive” (1957a:101); therefore the Passive transformation alters meaning; therefore transformations won’t take you from an underlying meaning to a surface form. Katz and Postal tried to patch this hole, and for them 3a and 3b “are ambiguous in the same way and so are full paraphrases of one another” (1964:72)—they both have the same-two and the different-two readings. For the increasingly cagey Chomsky of Aspects, 3a and 3b are a minor puzzle. They seem to suggest that the Katz-Postal hypothesis is “too strong,” but “we might maintain that in such examples both interpretations are latent,” a maintenance that he finds attractive (1965 [1964]:224n9), and in his most authoritative statement on the subject in Aspects he says

显然，正如卡茨和福多尔所强调的那样，句子的意义基于其基本成分的意义及其组合方式。显然，表面（直接成分）结构所提供的组合方式一般来说与语义解释几乎完全无关。（1965 [1964]：162）

It is clear, as Katz and Fodor have emphasized, that the meaning of a sentence is based on the meaning of its elementary parts and the manner of their combination. It is also clear that the manner of combination provided by the surface (immediate constituent) structure is in general almost totally irrelevant to semantic interpretation. (1965 [1964]:162)

然而，在 1967 年的“评论”讲座中，当问题似乎已经完全解决并且人们对此相当满意时，乔姆斯基再次改变了立场，而除了杰肯道夫之外，几乎所有人都对此感到震惊。

But, in 1967, with the “Remarks” lectures, when the matter seemed completely settled and people were pretty happy with it, Chomsky shifted his position again, in ways that almost everyone but Jackendoff found alarming.

不可能重现乔姆斯基在讲座中所说的话，但在随附的论文中，他暗示了我们的 Cormorant-Island 句子等例子的新意义，将Aspects语法描述为包含“语义规则的语法，这些规则为语法生成的每对深层和表层结构分配语义解释”（1972b [1967]：12）。当然，这一说法在Aspects框架内是完全正确的，就像断言语法为音位表征或整个派生分配了语义解释一样，但在Aspects中，乔姆斯基清楚地说，深层结构是语义动作发生的地方，这种新的措辞标志着风向的改变。更明确地，但仍然带着许多人感到恼火的含糊其辞，他还在那一年的印刷品中说：

It’s impossible to recover what Chomsky said in the lectures, but in the accompanying paper, he hints about the renewed relevance of such examples as our Cormorant-Island sentences, describing the Aspects grammar as one which contained “semantic rules that assign each paired deep and surface structure generated by the syntax a semantic interpretation” (1972b [1967]:12). This statement was strictly true within the Aspects framework, of course, as would be an assertion that the grammar assigned a semantic interpretation to the phonological representation, or the derivation as a whole, but in Aspects Chomsky clearly says that deep structure is where the semantic action takes place, and this new phrasing signaled a change in the winds. More explicitly, but still with a coyness that many found exasperating, he also said in print that year:

我认为对“语义解释”一词的合理解释将导致这样的结论：表层结构对语义解释也具有有限但重要的贡献，但在这里我不会再谈论这个问题。（1967b：407）

I think that a reasonable explication of the term “semantic interpretation” would lead to the conclusion that surface structure also contributes in a restricted but important way to semantic interpretation, but I will say no more about this matter here. (1967b:407)

这些言论在他的讲座中肯定有详细阐述。他的学生可能知道他的理由和一些论据。其他人则感到困惑和不安。

Such remarks were surely elaborated in his lectures. His students likely knew his reasons and some of his arguments. Everyone else was puzzled and disconcerted.

1968 年，他更加坦率地表示，“表面结构（至少在一定程度上）决定了逻辑元素的范围 [比如3a 和 3b 中every的量词]”，从而在“确定语义解释方面发挥了作用”（1972b [1968]：209）。8到那时，他的学生们已经开始在地上地下传播论文，其中的分析都涉及到表面结构的解释。这就是卡茨-波斯特尔假设：如果表面结构在意义中发挥作用，那么转换就不可能是语义中立的。到 1969 年，对于乔姆斯基来说，像 3a 和 3b 这样的句子对于Aspects模型和生成语义学来说都是完全有问题的，需要对前者进行重大改革，并彻底拒绝后者。

In 1968, he was more forthcoming, saying that “surface structure determines (at least in part) the scope of logical elements [like the quantifier every of everyone in 3a and 3b]” and consequently plays “a role in determining semantic interpretation” (1972b [1968]:209).8 And by this point his students had begun circulating papers, over and under the ground, with analyses that invoked surface structure interpretation. There goes the Katz-Postal hypothesis: if surface structure plays a role in meaning, then transformations can’t be semantically neutral. By 1969, for Chomsky, sentences like 3a and 3b were hopelessly problematic for both the Aspects model and, a fortiori, generative semantics, requiring a major overhaul of the former and a wholesale rejection of the latter.

很多以此命名的研究都扩展了标准理论，也就是说，它们什么都没扩展。它们完全是消极的——不寻找特定问题的解决方案，而只寻找那些损害或推翻 Katz-Postal 假设（因此也是生成语义学）的数据。

Much of the work that took the name extended standard theory, that is, extended nothing. It was completely negative—looking not for solutions to specific problems but only for data that compromised or disconfirmed the Katz-Postal hypothesis, and, therefore, generative semantics.

为什么会有这样的转变？乔姆斯基再次暗示，他的这一举动完全是生成语义学的偶然产物，他说这是由他的学生雷·杰肯多夫 (Ray Jackendoff) 引发的：

Why the shift? Chomsky, again suggesting his move was wholly incidental to generative semantics, says it was occasioned by his student, Ray Jackendoff:

第一个对标准理论提出实质性批评的人，也是我记得最好的批评者，是雷·杰肯多夫——那应该是在 1964 年或 1965 年。他指出，表层结构在语义解释中发挥的作用比人们想象的要重要得多；如果是这样，那么标准假设（卡茨-波斯特尔假设）就是错误的，根据该假设，深层结构完全决定了（意义）。（1979 [1976]：151）

The first person who offered a substantial critique of the Standard Theory, and the best as far as I can recall, was Ray Jackendoff—that must have been in 1964 or 1965. He showed that surface structure played a much more important role in semantic interpretation than had been supposed; if so, then the Standard hypothesis [the Katz-Postal hypothesis], according to which it was the deep structure that completely determined [meaning], is false. (1979 [1976]:151)

乔姆斯基的时间顺序在这里有点不对。杰肯多夫直到 1965 年秋天才出现在麻省理工学院。9并且（尽管这取决于他如何定义“对标准理论的实质性批评”），乔姆斯基的优先性概念同样是错误的。莱考夫的论文被许多人视为对体貌的（建设性）批评，在杰肯多夫完成第一学期之前就已经流传开来，其他几位语言学家在杰肯多夫之前就对体貌模型进行了实质性的修改——包括格鲁伯、波斯特尔、罗斯和菲尔莫尔。我们在这里唯一能同意乔姆斯基的观点是最佳，因为这是一个主观评价，他有权表达自己的意见。

Chomsky’s chronology is off a bit here. Jackendoff didn’t even show up at MIT until the fall of 1965.9 And (although this depends on how he chooses to define “a substantial critique of the Standard Theory”) Chomsky’s notions of priority are similarly off. Lakoff’s thesis, which many people regarded as a (constructive) critique of Aspects, was in circulation before Jackendoff finished his first semester, and several other linguists were revamping the Aspects model substantially before Jackendoff—including Gruber, Postal, Ross, and Fillmore. The only point we can grant Chomsky here is best, since it is a subjective evaluation and he’s entitled to his opinion.

而且，这种表面结构批评的发展似乎并不像乔姆斯基回忆的那样简单。特别是，这位学生记得乔姆斯基至少早在他 18 岁的时候就对Aspects模型进行了批评：

Too, the development of this surface-structure critique seems not to be as simple as Chomsky recalls. In particular, the student remembers that Chomsky was entertaining this critique of the Aspects model at least as early as he was:

大二的时候，乔姆斯基不在，写《笛卡尔语言学》 ……我开始思考解释规则，并在 1966 年秋季学期在哈勒的指导下进行独立研究，写了三篇论文——一篇主张基础生成代词，其前身由解释规则决定；一篇主张选择限制是在语义成分中强制执行的，而不是作为词汇插入的一部分（如在体位置中）；还有一篇试图制定一个基础生成 PRO 和关系代词的理论，以取代当时流行的删除规则。罗斯向我指出，这需要表层结构解释，这与当时教条的深层结构决定解释的假设相矛盾。这让我很担心。我记得那年乔姆斯基在校园里短暂露面时与他进行过一次讨论，我提出了这个担忧，他平静地说，表面结构当然在解释中发挥作用。因此显然至少在 1967 年初他也是在这样思考。

During my second year, [when] Chomsky was away, writing Cartesian Linguistics, … I started thinking about rules of interpretation, and in an independent study under Halle during the fall semester of 1966 wrote three papers—one arguing for base-generated pronouns whose antecedents are determined by rules of interpretation; one arguing that selectional restrictions are enforced in the semantic component, not as part of lexical insertion (as in the Aspects position); and one trying to work out a theory of basegenerated PRO and relative pronouns instead of the deletion rules then in fashion. Ross pointed out to me that this would require surface structure interpretation, in contradiction to the then-dogmatic assumption that deep structure determines interpretation. This worried me a lot. I remember a discussion with Chomsky on one of his brief reappearances on campus during that year, in which I brought up this worry, and he said calmly, Of course surface structure plays a role in interpretation. So evidently he was thinking along those lines too by at least early in 1967.

从某种程度上来说，乔姆斯基平静的“表面结构当然起着作用”这句话看起来只是利斯的观察的另一个例子，即他“非常聪明，你想出的任何主意他都已经想到了，并且经过了长期而深入的思考”。乔姆斯基的量词范围困境至少可以追溯到《句法结构》，他的词汇学发展显然始于 1960 年左右，部分是对《英语名词化语法》的反应。但从另一个角度来看，这个问题与乔姆斯基引以为豪的分析深度关系不大，而与他在任何特定时间选择遵循哪种分析的哪条特定线索的神秘选择有关。很早就提出的量词范围、转换的语义中立性问题似乎在 1965 年得到了坚实的解决；再次提出这个问题不仅显得非常奇怪，而且似乎是倒退了一步，背叛了转换学界一直努力的一切。即使在麻省理工学院对卡茨—波斯特尔假说进行了数年的争论之后，芭芭拉·帕蒂 (Barbara Partee) 仍然对这一努力感到困惑不解，她所表达的立场让人想起了整个乔姆斯基学派最讨厌的布卢姆菲尔德派：

In one way, Chomsky’s calm “Of course surface structure plays a role” looks like just another example of Lees’ observation that he “is so smart that any idea you came up with he had already thought of, and thought over long and deeply.” Chomsky’s quantifier-scope quandaries date at least to Syntactic Structures, and his lexicalist developments evidently germinate from 1960 or so, in partial reaction to The Grammar of English Nominalizations. In another way, though, the issue has less to do with Chomsky’s vaunted depth of analysis than with his enigmatic choice of which particular thread of which analysis to follow at any given time. The quantifier-scope, semantic-neutrality-of-transformations question, raised very early, seemed to be solidly resolved by 1965; raising it again not only seemed very peculiar, it seemed like a step backward, and a betrayal of everything the transformational community had been working toward. Even after several years of MIT arguments against the Katz-Postal hypothesis, Barbara Partee expressed her bafflement over the effort in terms that harken back to the Bloomfieldian bête noire of the entire Chomskyan community:

转换规则不保留意义的立场比相反的立场更不具内在意义，因为它仅仅相当于某个强假设是错误的立场。当然，它可能是正确的立场，但它似乎不是人们理性地想要支持的东西——它类似于共时规则不反映历史发展，或者并非所有语言都使用相同的音系特征等等的立场，总和所有这些观点都是（在臭名昭著的 Joos 语录中）“语言之间的差异是无限的，并且是不可预测的。”（1971 [1969]：8；斜体为 Partee 所加）

The position that transformational rules don’t preserve meaning is of much less inherent interest than the contrary position, since it amounts simply to the position that a certain strong hypothesis is false. It may of course turn out to be the correct position, but it doesn’t seem like anything one could rationally want to champion—it is analogous to the position that synchronic rules don’t reflect historical development, or that not all languages use the same stock of phonological features, and so forth, the sum of all such positions being [in the notorious Joos quotation] that “languages can differ from each other without limit and in unpredictable ways.” (1971 [1969]:8; Partee’s italics)

现在，在这个反对卡茨-波斯特尔假设的计划中，加上乔姆斯基关于使用或过度使用范畴转换转换的论证，他的努力看起来就更奇怪了。为什么要逆阿斯派茨之后最有成果的转换语法研究潮流而动，尤其是基于“评论”中粗略而模糊的论证？而且，回想起来，为什么不在七年前提出他对范畴转换转换的担忧，因为它们显然对 20 世纪 60 年代早期乔姆斯基语言学的整个走向深层结构的运动产生了影响？

Now, add to this program against the Katz-Postal hypothesis Chomsky’s arguments on the use, or over-use, of category-changing transformations, and his efforts looked odder yet. Why swim against the current of the most productive post-Aspects line of research in transformational grammar, particularly on the basis of the sketchy and vaguely adumbrated arguments of “Remarks”? And, in retrospect, why not raise his concerns about category-changing transformations seven years earlier, since they clearly had ramifications for the whole movement toward deep structure that characterized Chomskyan linguistics in the early sixties?

谁知道呢？

Who knows?

但在许多语言学家看来，乔姆斯基只是失去了坚持信念的勇气，他无法贯彻自己工作的自然含义，他是在退缩而不是前进，令人悲伤的是，他被更有活力、更有远见的语言学家抛在了后面。

But it seemed to many linguists that Chomsky had simply lost the courage of his convictions, that he couldn’t follow through on the natural implications of his own work, that he was retrenching rather than advancing, that he was, sadly, being left behind by more vigorous, more visionary linguists.

最佳理论

The Best Theory

事实上，同质 I 是……先验上最好的语法理论。

The fact is that Homogeneous I is … the best grammatical theory a priori possible.

保罗邮政

Paul Postal

与此同时，生成语义学继续蓬勃发展，启示录的四骑士——波斯特尔、莱科夫、罗斯和麦考利——在其传播过程中各自扮演着不同的角色，就像在其起源时一样。当然，这些角色之间存在很大的分散性和重叠性，如果这种趋势被推得太远，就会出现一种讽刺的元素，但他们对这一运动的影响是相当明显的。我们已经看到，莱科夫和罗斯是福音推销员，把生成语义学带给消费者。麦考利，正如我们即将看到的那样，是教母，在芝加哥培养了第二代生成语义学家。波斯特尔是重头戏。

Meanwhile, generative semantics continued to gather momentum, the four horsemen of the apocalypse—Postal, Lakoff, Ross, and McCawley—each playing somewhat distinct roles in its propagation, as they had in its genesis. Certainly there was much scatter and overlap in these roles, and an element of caricature shows up if the tendencies are pushed too far, but their respective impacts on the movement are quite clear. Lakoff and Ross, we have seen, were the evangelical salesmen, taking generative semantics to the consumers. McCawley, as we will see shortly, was the den mother, rearing a second generation of generative semanticists in Chicago. Postal was the big gun.

尽管刚过三十，波斯特尔已是一位值得尊敬的资深学者，地位仅次于乔姆斯基，他对生成语义学的支持对生成语义学的成功意义重大。他并没有像推销早期的转换语法那样热情地宣传该模型；他参加会议是为了发表演讲，有时也是为了辩论，但并不是为了攻击。在辩论期间，他一如既往地多产，几乎所有出版物都围绕着追求生成语义学的理由，其中大部分都附有关于为什么不追求其“几乎完全开放的”竞争对手的旁白（波斯特尔，1972b [1970]：37n4），有些甚至带有他反布卢姆菲尔德运动的坚决辩论和顽固的语气。但他仅仅出现在阵营中就几乎足够了。波斯特尔为该运动提供了大量必要的可信度。

Though just into his thirties, Postal was a worthy veteran, below only Chomsky in stature, and his endorsement of generative semantics meant a great deal to its success. He did not proselytize for the model with anywhere near the fervor with which he sold the earlier versions of transformational grammar; he went to conferences to present and sometimes to dispute, but not to attack. He was, as always, prolific during the dispute, with almost all of his publications organized around reasons to pursue generative semantics, with most containing asides on why not to pursue its “almost completely open ended” rival (Postal, 1972b [1970]:37n4), and with some even carrying the resolutely polemical, doggedly certain tone of his antiBloomfieldian campaign. But his mere presence in the camp was almost enough on its own. Postal gave the movement a great deal of necessary credibility.

事实上，他看起来就像它的发明者。他引领了更深入、更抽象的句法分析运动，每个人都能看到，这发展成为生成性语义学。因此，尽管他直到 1968 年才公开支持该理论，但他的影响从一开始就弥漫并支持该理论。他和 Katz 制定的意义保存假设、他们的表演性预示和抽象触发词素为生成语义学提供了发展依据。他对 Lakoff 论文的赞助——一篇处于抽象语法和生成语义学模糊边界的文本——在很大程度上证实了该论文的有效性，因此也证实了这些理论背后的许多论点。他私下（但承认）参与了 Lakoff 的深层动词论证、Ross 的辅助分析和 McCawley 的论证，所有这些都增加了他们的权威。从抽象语法到生成语义学的进展对当时的许多语言学家（支持者和反对者）来说似乎是不可避免的，以至于他们认为 Postal 是后者的“真正”先驱。

He looked, in fact, like its inventor. His spearheading of the movement toward deeper, more abstract syntactic analyses, everyone could see, grew into generative semantics. So, even though he didn’t publicly ally himself with the theory until 1968, his influence suffused and supported it from the beginning. His and Katz’s formulation of their meaning-preservation hypothesis, and their performative prefiguration, and their abstract trigger morphemes gave generative semantics a developmental warrant. His sponsorship of Lakoff’s dissertation—a text at the blurry borders of abstract syntax and generative semantics—went a long way toward its validation, and therefore toward the validation of many arguments underlying those theories. His offstage (but acknowledged) participation in Lakoff’s deep verb arguments, in Ross’s auxiliary analysis, in McCawley’s arguments, all gave them increased authority. The progression from abstract syntax to generative semantics seemed so inevitable to many linguists at the time (both supporters and opponents) that they assumed Postal was the latter’s “real” progenitor.

许多人认为他的论点最具挑战性。例如，卡茨说，波斯特尔的工作“是那种我认为可以认真对待的东西。我觉得我必须以某种方式接受他的工作。从局外人的角度来看，在我看来，他是这个机构背后的智囊。”凯泽简单地说，“他是大师。”这种看法很大程度上与演讲风格有关；卡茨、凯泽和波斯特尔讲的是同一种语言。其他三个生成语义学原理则以更非正式和轻松的演讲形式呈现。波斯特尔的工作一贯非常详细、非常严谨，推理非常明确。这种看法的一部分也与精神有关。波斯特尔与卡茨一起工作，与凯泽一起学习，代表乔姆斯基战斗。他是他们的同事。拉科夫、罗斯和麦考利是他们的学生。对于乔姆斯基在麻省理工学院培养的年轻诠释学家来说，情况也类似。波斯特尔曾是一名教师，而且是一位传奇人物；其他三人只不过是年长的学生。波斯特尔的论证也是生成语义学中最有力的论证之一；尤其是他的论文（1971b [1969]）是生成论证的典范，罗斯认为它包含了“对生成语义学的最佳阐述”。

And many people found his arguments the most challenging. Katz, for instance, says that Postal’s work “was the sort of thing that I found I could take seriously. I felt that I had to come to terms with his work in some way. From an outsider’s point of view, it seemed to me that he was the brains behind the outfit.” Keyser says, simply, “He was the guru.” Much of this perception had to do with style of presentation; Katz, Keyser, and Postal spoke the same language. The other three generative semantics principals are given to more informal and breezy presentations. Postal’s work is—uniformly—very detailed, very rigorous, and the reasoning is very explicit. Part of the perception also had to do with ethos. Postal worked with Katz, studied with Keyser, went to battle on behalf of Chomsky. He was their colleague. Lakoff, Ross, and McCawley were their students. For the brood of younger interpretivists Chomsky was rearing at MIT, the situation was similar. Postal had been a teacher, in addition to being something of a legend; the other three were little more than older students. Postal’s arguments are also among the strongest for generative semantics; his remind paper in particular (1971b [1969]) is a model of generative argumentation, and contains, for Ross “the best articulation of what generative semantics is about.”

不过，他最为人记住的贡献或许是《最佳理论》。这本书之所以出名，部分原因在于它彻底的论战性质——论战性足以被称为波斯塔式的——书名中的最佳理论当然是指生成语义学，讨论的进行方式好像任何选择不研究该模型的人显然需要精神病咨询。它之所以被记住，部分原因是在争论最激烈的会议——1969 年德克萨斯语言理论目标会议上，它是与乔姆斯基的修辞摊牌中的败者。它之所以被记住，部分原因是乔姆斯基喜欢在将生成语义学描述为“最糟糕的理论”之前援引它，实际上是“最糟糕的理论……可以想象的最糟糕的理论”。它之所以被记住，部分原因是这是一篇伟大的论文。

His most remembered contribution, though, is probably “The Best Theory.” In part its reputation comes from its thoroughly polemical nature—polemical in terms definitive enough to be called Postalian—the best theory of the title referring, of course, to generative semantics, with the discussion proceeding as if anyone choosing not to work on the model was clearly in need of psychiatric counseling. In part it is remembered because it was the losing entry in a rhetorical showdown with Chomsky at the most heated conference of the dispute, the 1969 Texas Conference on the Goals of Linguistic Theory. In part it is remembered because Chomsky has a penchant for invoking it before describing generative semantics as “the worst theory,” in fact as “the worst possible theory … the worst imaginable theory.” In part it is remembered because it’s a great paper.

罗斯回忆说，德州目标会议充满了“糟糕的氛围、大喊大叫和尖叫之类的东西”：“到那时，很明显，不会有人要求或给予宽恕。”而 Postal 的报纸正处于这一切的中心，充满了糟糕的氛围和挑衅，既不要求也不给予宽恕。标题清楚地表明，顽固是当务之急，而不是妥协，这是一个很好的例子与乔姆斯基形成鲜明对比。他在会议上发表的论文题为“转换语法理论中的一些经验问题”，尽可能中立和温和，与波斯特尔的固有优越性形成鲜明对比，但内容比波斯特尔的论文更顽固，语气咄咄逼人，整篇论文尽可能远离妥协。10

The Texas Goals conference was full of “bad vibes and yelling and shrieking and shit like that,” Ross recalls: “By then it was clear there was going to be no quarter asked nor given.” And Postal’s paper was in the middle of it all, full of bad vibes and provocations, neither asking nor giving any quarter. The title makes it clear intransigence was the order of the day, not compromise, and it makes for a nice contrast with Chomsky. The paper he gave at the conference was published under the title, “Some Empirical Issues in the Theory of Transformational Grammar,” as neutral and mild-mannered as one could get, in sharp relief with Postal’s titular claim to inherent superiority, but the content was more intransigent that anything in Postal’s paper, the tone is bullying, and the whole paper is as far from compromise as possible.10

Postal 的论文坚定不移但直截了当，用奥卡姆剃刀原理论证了生成语义学在理论上的优先性，优于更复杂的模型，尤其是所有版本的解释语义学，还夹杂了一些诽谤和离题的反驳。Chomsky 竭尽全力地在论文中论证了生成语义学的每一个论点（还借此机会攻击了 Fillmore 的相关语法），只提供了模糊的替代方案承诺书。一如既往，他的表现令人印象深刻。他以和解的言论开始和结束，采取了一种疏离、无私的形象，只对语言学的利益表现出兴趣。但他不断发起攻击，不断将生成语义学描述为“无趣”、“空洞”、“完全晦涩”、“没有实质内容”、“允许任何可以想象的规则”、“充其量只是可疑的规则”、“仅构成一种极其不明确的术语提议”、“不仅没有动机而且实际上不可接受”等等。然而，解释语义学“本质上可能是正确的”、“非常有趣”、“更自然”、“更谨慎”、“得到充分支持”、“更受欢迎”、“再次更受欢迎”和“更具限制性，因此更受欢迎”，当然，还有更多。相比之下，《11邮政》的好战性就显得微不足道了。

Postal’s paper makes an unbudging but straightforward Ockham’s-razor case for the strong theoretical priority of generative semantics over more complex models, especially all versions of interpretive semantics, with a few aspersions and digressive counter-arguments thrown in. Chomsky goes after every generative semantics argument he can squeeze into the paper (taking the opportunity to attack Fillmore’s related grammar to boot), and offers nothing but vague promissory notes for an alternative. As always, the performance is impressive. He begins and ends with conciliatory statements, adopts a removed, disinterested persona, and exhibits interest only in the good of linguistics. But he attacks relentlessly, constantly characterizing generative semantics as “uninteresting” and “vacuous” and “totally obscure” and “[having] no substance” and “permitting any rule imaginable” and “[incorporating] at best dubious rules” and “[constituting only] a terminological proposal of an extremely unclear sort” and “not only unmotivated but in fact unacceptable” and much, much more. Interpretive semantics, though, “is probably correct, in essence” and “very interesting” and “more natural” and “somewhat more careful” and “well-supported” and “to be preferred” and “again to be preferred” and “more restrictive, hence preferable” and, of course, considerably more.11 Postal’s belligerence pales in comparison.

芝加哥的麦考利

McCawley in Chicago

本文关注的是臭名昭著的战犯美国空军中尉布鲁斯·弗雷泽在最近的一篇文章中提出的关于习语变换适用性的主张。弗雷泽坚持认为“连词减少永远不适用于”习语，“习语中的名词短语永远不能代词化[或]采用限制性关系从句”，并且习语中“永远不会出现间隙”；他还表示，他“找不到任何可以分裂名词短语的习语”。我和同事 Yuck Foo 和 Tri Bung Quim 进行了实地调查，以正在接受政治再教育的其他美国空军战犯为调查对象，证明了存在一类反例来反驳弗雷泽关于习语变换不适用的所有主张。我指的是习语take a piss、take a shit和blow a fart。

This paper is concerned with claims about the applicability of transformations to idioms made in a recent article by the notorious war criminal, U. S. Air Force Lt. Bruce Fraser. Fraser maintains that ‘conjunction reduction will never be applicable’ within an idiom, that ‘no noun phrase in an idiom may ever be pronominalized [or] take a restrictive relative clause,’ and that ‘gapping never occurs’ within an idiom; he in addition states that he has ‘been able to find no idioms in which a noun phrase may be clefted.’ Field work which I and my colleagues Yuck Foo and Tri Bung Quim have carried out, using as informants other U.S. Air Force war criminals who were undergoing political reeducation, has demonstrated the existence of a class of counterexamples to all of Fraser’s claims of supposed inapplicability of transformations to idioms. I refer to the idioms take a piss, take a shit, and blow a fart.

光福同

Quang Phuc Dong

McCawley 有点像一个布道者，比 Postal 更甚，但比 Lakoff 和 Ross 稍逊一筹，他发表了许多重要的基础论文。在会议上，他尤其引人注目的是，他（温和地）展示了一个特定的解释主义解释如何无法发挥其作者所声称的影响力，将演示表明生成语义学更适合这项任务。从纸面上看，他的论点更有说服力，事后看来，他的出版物甚至比 Postal 的出版物更具权威性。12麦考利的演讲也很精彩，并参加了几次重要的聚会。他参加了 1967 年重要的德克萨斯普遍性会议，讨论了对更深层、语义更透明的深层结构的需要；他参加了 1968 年厄巴纳语言研究所；他参加了芝加哥语言学会的所有主要会议；他在 1969 年第一届斯堪的纳维亚语言学暑期学校和 1970 年东京国际语言理论研讨会上教授语义学，而罗斯教授句法，基帕斯基教授抽象音系学。他四处奔波。他把生成语义学带到了身边。但他的主要作用是稳定这一运动，给它一个家，并在芝加哥及其周边地区培养第二代生成语义学家。

McCawley was something of a proselytizer, more than Postal but less than Lakoff and Ross, and he published a number of important foundational papers. In conferences, he was especially compelling when he showed (gently) how a given interpretivist account couldn’t pull the weight its author claimed for it, coupling the demonstration with a suggestion that generative semantics was better suited to the task. On paper, his arguments were more persuasive yet, and, in hindsight, his publications are more definitive even than Postal’s.12 McCawley also lectured winningly and participated in several crucial gatherings. He was at the important 1967 Texas Universals conference, arguing about the need for deeper, more semantically transparent deep structures; he was at the 1968 Urbana Linguistic Institute; he was at all the major Chicago Linguistic Society meetings; he taught semantics at the 1969 First Scandinavian Summer School of Linguistics and the 1970 Tokyo International Seminar in Linguistic Theory, while Ross taught syntax and Kiparsky taught abstract phonology. He got around. And he took generative semantics with him. But his principal role was to stabilize the movement, give it a home, and nurture a second generation of generative semanticists in and around Chicago.

当生成语义学开始蓬勃发展时，波斯特尔在 IBM 工作，没有学生，尽管他偶尔也接受教学任务。罗斯在唯一的解释飞地麻省理工学院，笼罩在巨大的阴影之下，他说（太悲观了）这使他无法“影响那里的任何人”。也没有对生成语义学做出贡献的学生。莱考夫从马萨诸塞州的剑桥搬到了密歇根，再搬到了帕洛阿尔托，又搬到了伯克利，这使他无法培养稳定的研究生基础。他有几位著名的学生对该模型产生了影响——尤其是哈佛大学的盖伊·卡登，以及后来在密歇根的约翰·劳勒。但麦考利的影响要大得多。他在芝加哥大学安居乐业，吸引了一群聪明的年轻学生，其中许多人对生成语义学做出了重大贡献（其中最著名的有罗伯特·宾尼克、爱丽丝·戴维森、乔治亚·格林、朱迪思·莱维和杰里·摩根）。此外，李斯当时就职于附近的伊利诺伊大学厄巴纳分校，他对这一新趋势非常宽容，兹维基也是如此，他是一位鼓舞人心的老师，也吸引了聪明的年轻研究生学习该理论。

Postal was at IBM, with no students, by the time generative semantics began to mushroom, though he also took occasional teaching assignments. Ross was at the only interpretive enclave, MIT, under a formidable shadow which he says (much too gloomily) kept him from ever “influencing a single mind there.” Neither had any students who contributed to generative semantics. Lakoff moved from Cambridge, Massachusetts, to Michigan to Palo Alto to Berkeley, preventing him from cultivating a stable base of graduate students. He had a few notable students who made an imprint on the model—especially Guy Carden at Harvard, and later, at Michigan, John Lawler. But McCawley’s impact was substantially greater. He was comfortably ensconced in the University of Chicago, attracting a group of bright young students, many of whom made significant contributions to generative semantics (among the more notable, Robert Binnick, Alice Davison, Georgia Green, Judith Levi, and Jerry Morgan). Moreover, Lees was at the nearby University of Illinois (Urbana) and very tolerant of the new trend, as was Zwicky, an inspiring teacher who also attracted bright young graduate students to the theory.

当麦考利（以及利斯和兹维基）的学生遇到莱科夫和罗斯的鼓舞人心的热情时，生成语义学就从转换语法的另一种版本转变为一场运动。有两件事情对于生成语义学的发展、其在伊利诺伊州的根基以及其天才的定义尤为重要：1968 年厄巴纳语言研究所和次年春天芝加哥语言学会第五次会议。

When McCawley’s (and Lees’s, and Zwicky’s) students encountered the inspirational fervor of Lakoff and Ross, generative semantics made the transition from an alternative version of transformational grammar to a movement. Two events were especially important for the growth of generative semantics, for its roots in Illinois, and for defining its genius: the 1968 Linguistic Institute at Urbana and the fifth meeting of the Chicago Linguistic Society the following spring.

莱考夫和罗斯在研究所任教（正式课程名为“抽象语法”），麦考利也任教，并从芝加哥带来了许多更有前途的学生。利斯是浪漫主义前阿斯派克特时代传奇的辩论家和口才家，他担任研究所主任。用当时的行话来说，这种组合令人惊叹。研究所的精神因几位参与者在“卡米洛特，1968 年”（本威克的兰斯洛特等人，1976 年 [1968]）中永垂不朽，这篇论文对生成语义学如此狂热，对解释语义学充满敌意，甚至连自由言论倡导者和流动色情作家麦考利也觉得有必要对其进行删节（1976b：249）。这篇论文，用它自己的话来说，是“对那一年的一些语言事件的叙述：其中详述了新法院的宣言和在废除旧法院某些法令的可怕战斗中使用的武器”（1976 [1968]：249）。纽迈耶，一位曾就读于该学院的伊利诺伊大学的学生对那一年发生的事件发表了更为严厉的批评，他说，

Lakoff and Ross taught at the Institute (officially, the course was “Abstract Syntax”), McCawley also taught, and brought many of his more promising students over from Chicago. Lees, the legendary polemicist and articulator of the romantic pre-Aspects days, was the Institute’s director. The mix was, in the argot of the period, mind-blowing. The spirit of the Institute has been immortalized by several of the participants in “Camelot, 1968” (Lancelot of Benwick and others, 1976 [1968]), a paper so recklessly enthusiastic for generative semantics and hostile to interpretive semantics that even McCawley, a free-speech advocate and itinerant pornographer, felt compelled to bowdlerize it (1976b:249). The paper, in its own words, is “an account of some of the linguistic Events of that Year: wherein are detailed the Declarations of the New Court and the Weapons used in the Awefull Battle to repeal Certain Decrees of the Old Court” (1976 [1968]:249). Newmeyer, a University of Illinois student who attended the Institute, has somewhat harsher words for the Events of that Year, saying the Institute

不仅是生成语义学上升潮流中的顶峰，而且是将理性论证与纯粹的表演技巧和纯粹的推销技巧相结合的典范。（1980a：152；1986a：102）

stands out not only as the high-water mark in the ascendant tide of generative semantics, but also as the epitome of mixing reasoned argument with pure showmanship and pure salesmanship. (1980a:152; 1986a:102)

研究所的参与者之间有着强烈的同志情谊，这是不到十年前麻省理工学院电子研究实验室弥漫的精神的重现。但是，正如《卡米洛特，1968》的基调所暗示的那样，主持厄巴纳的天才不是诺姆·乔姆斯基的真诚；而是莱科夫、罗斯，尤其是麦考利的不敬的热情。例如，后者曾以南河内理工学院的 Quang Phuc Dong 的笔名写作，研究所的参与者非常自豪地穿着他们的 SHIT T 恤。（Quang 在相关时期的另一个职位是魁北克中央自由大学，但这种隶属关系显然没有对服装产生影响。）

There was a strong thread of comaraderie binding the Institute participants, a reincarnation of the spirit that pervaded MIT’s Research Laboratory of Electronics less than a decade earlier. But, as the tone of “Camelot, 1968” suggests, the genius presiding over Urbana was not the earnestness of Noam Chomsky; it was the irreverent gusto of Lakoff, Ross, and, especially, McCawley. The latter, for instance, had written under the pseudonym of Quang Phuc Dong, from the South Hanoi Institute of Technology, and the Institute participants wore their S.H.I.T. T-shirts with great pride. (Quang’s other position in the relevant period was at the Free University of Central Quebec, but that affiliation apparently had no sartorial impact.)

罗斯说，到了第二年春天，“光明和真理的力量已经齐心协力了”。芝加哥语言学会第五次会议包括波斯特尔和莱考夫关于生成语义学的重要论文；罗斯和罗宾·莱考夫对该理论的重大贡献；以及第二代成员——格林、摩根、纽迈耶、劳伦斯·霍恩和劳里·卡特图宁——研究该模型含义的大量论文。（麦考利那一年关于图巴图拉巴尔音系学的论文一反常态地没有被提及。）会议记录（宾尼克等人，1969 年）构成了一份宣言，即使不完全是一份宣言——生成语义学从未产生过这样的宣言——也是对该理论的更深入探索、更仔细推理和更具挑战性的阐述，比其短暂历史上的任何其他文件都要深入得多。当然，它代表了对核心小组以外的语言学家的更全面的邀请，比莱考夫和罗斯的“深层结构是必要的吗？”甚至比麦考利早期的几篇孤立的论文还要多。

By the following spring, says Ross, “the forces of light and truth had gotten their act together.” The fifth meeting of the Chicago Linguistic Society included crucial generative semantics papers by Postal and Lakoff; significant contributions to the theory by Ross and Robin Lakoff; and a wide range of papers investigating the implications of the model by members of the second generation—Green, Morgan, Newmeyer, Laurence Horn, and Lauri Karttunen. (McCawley’s paper that year, on Tübatulabal phonology, was uncharacteristically out of the fray.) The proceedings of the conference (Binnick and others, 1969) constitute, if not quite a manifesto—generative semantics never spawned one—a much more thoroughly explored, carefully reasoned, and challenging articulation of the theory than any other document in its brief history. Certainly it represented a more comprehensive invitation to linguists outside the central group than Lakoff and Ross’s “Is Deep Structure Necessary?” or even than McCawley’s several, isolated early papers.

当然，所有参与者都玩得很开心。生成语义学家最显著的品质之一是能够将严谨的学术研究与彻底的轻松诙谐结合起来。这一特点反映在该运动的论文中，包括轻浮的标题、有趣的数据结构和相当松散的风格。例如，罗斯在会议上的论文标题为“猜猜我是谁？”，而波斯特尔的论文则包括一系列句子，如 4。

And, of course, all the participants had a great deal of fun. One of the generative semanticists’ most distinctive qualities was the ability to combine probing scholarship with thoroughgoing levity. This feature is reflected in, among other mirrors, the movement’s papers—in frivolous titles, funny data constructions, and a rather loose-jointed style. Ross’s paper at the conference, for instance, was titled “Guess Who?,” and Postal’s included a whole range of sentences like 4.

4 伊尔玛是一名金发女郎，她被风扇吹住了。

4 Irma’s a blonde and she got it caught in the fan.

罗斯的论文探索了一条规则，该规则在非常复杂的条件和现象下起作用，这些条件和现象给解释理论带来了混乱。波斯特尔的例子 (4) 说明，像blonde这样的词，虽然它们是指 has hair 这样的结构，而 hair 是 blonde，但不能用作指代hair的代词。

Ross’s paper explored a rule which operates under very sophisticated conditions and phenomena which create havoc for interpretive theories. Postal’s example (4) illustrates that words like blonde, although they are referential for constructions like has hair which is blonde cannot sponsor a pronoun that refers to hair.

生成语义学走出了“方面”的阴影，走在了光明的前列，并且在转换竞赛中远远领先于乔姆斯基新的、不明确的、词汇主义的、语法的、表面语义的解释模型。

Generative semantics was out in the light, out from under the shadow of Aspects, and well ahead of Chomsky’s new, ill-specified, lexicalist, -syntax, surface-semantics, interpretive model in the transformational sweepstakes.

坏血

Bad Blood

亲人的仇恨远比陌生人的仇恨严重。

The enmity of one’s kinfolk is far worse than that of strangers.

德谟克利特

Democritus

Postal 为这一时期贴上的标签——“语言战争”——对于任何外行以及随后进入该领域的许多语言学家来说，似乎都是极端的，但战争是唯一合适的术语。这是一个残酷、激进、常常令人羞愧的时期。一方面，有充满活力和粗鲁的生成语义学家，他们已经占据了大部分制高点。另一方面，乔姆斯基的支持者越来越多，他们年轻，渴望像李斯和 Postal 那样杀出一条血路。在中间，Katz 正在支持Aspects模型以对抗这两股势力。在他们周围，充斥着大量不成熟的问题、不明确的建议和不定形的数据。就像凡尔登一样，没有干燥的立足点。

Postal’s label for this period—“The Linguistic Wars”—looks extreme to anyone outside the field, and to many linguists who have entered the field in its wake, but wars is the only fitting term. It was a vicious, aggressive, frequently ignominious period. On one side, there were the spirited and abrasive generative semanticists, who had already captured much of the high ground. On the other side, there was Chomsky with a growing number of supporters, young and eager for the types of giant-killing episodes that had made legends out of Lees and Postal. Toward the middle, Katz was buttressing the Aspects model against both hordes. And around them all was a vast wash of ill-formed issues, underdetermined proposals, and amorphous data. Like Verdun, there were no dry footholds.

乔姆斯基的论文措辞严厉，但相对来说举止得体，只偶尔嘲讽一下——尤其是在笔记中，尤其是针对莱科夫——关于“误导性”（1972b [1969]:141n19）和“完全晦涩难懂”（1972b [1969]:148n22）的论点。然而，他的演讲要激烈得多。在这些演讲中以及整个演讲期间，他的辩论方式与往常一样——冷静、冷静，甚至友好。当他提高声音时（同样，目标是莱科夫），那是出于对对话者的激烈言辞或彻头彻尾的粗鲁感到恼火。有点暴躁是可以理解的。毕竟，这是乔姆斯基的课。

Chomsky’s papers were severe but relatively well mannered, with only occasional jibes—especially in the notes, and especially directed at Lakoff—about “misleading” (1972b [1969]:141n19) and “totally obscure” (1972b [1969]:148n22) arguments. The lectures, though, were considerably more agonistic. He argued in these lectures and throughout this period as he always argues—calmly, dispassionately, even convivially. When his voice rose (again the target was usually Lakoff) it was out of exasperation with his interlocutor’s vehemence, or outright rudeness. And a little testiness is understandable. It was, after all, Chomsky’s class.

但即使乔姆斯基的论调彬彬有礼且自信满满——或者说，部分原因是他彬彬有礼且自信满满——他的论调几乎总是让对手难以接受。《纽约时报》援引拉科夫的话称，“乔姆斯基……打斗很卑鄙”（Shenker，1972），这种印象非常普遍。尤其是，很少有人能从乔姆斯基对他们的论点的表述中认出自己。当然，布卢姆菲尔德派对他的许多作品版本感到完全困惑，斯金纳抱怨说，“乔姆斯基根本不懂我在说什么。”13但是，由于乔姆斯基对这两个来源的影响是如此毁灭性，以致他们现在不再具有很大的权威性——也许他们只是因为被严重粗暴地对待而变得暴躁——请听听尊敬的奎因对乔姆斯基对其作品的陈述之一的反应：

But even with his polite and assured tone—or rather, partially because of his polite and assured tone—Chomsky’s polemics are almost always very hard for their targets to take. Lakoff is quoted in The New York Times as saying “Chomsky … fights dirty” (Shenker, 1972), and the impression is quite widespread. In particular, very few people recognize themselves in the representations Chomsky gives of their arguments. The Bloomfieldians, of course, were completely mystified by many of his versions of their work, and Skinner complained that “Chomsky simply does not understand what I am talking about.”13 But, since Chomsky’s impact on these two sources was so devastating that they no longer carry a lot of authority at the moment—maybe they were just cranky because they were so badly roughed up—listen to The Venerable Quine’s reaction to one of Chomsky’s representations of his work:

乔姆斯基的言论让我既感到安心又感到沮丧。让我感到安心的是，他从未明确反对我的立场。让我感到沮丧的是，他对我认为的我的立场表达了很大的反对意见。（1969：302）

Chomsky’s remarks leave me with feelings at once of reassurance and frustration. What I find reassuring is that he nowhere clearly disagrees with my position. What I find frustrating is that he expresses much disagreement with what he thinks to be my position. (1969:302)

这与“乔姆斯基的斗争很卑鄙”相去甚远，但奎因对乔姆斯基的著作所持的哈哈镜感到沮丧——他在这里夸大他的想法，在这里压制他的想法——而斯金纳只是拒绝正视，其他人则感到愤怒。当然，拉科夫也感到愤怒。他回忆起乔姆斯基在 19 世纪的“反智主义”时期的主要策略。“评论”称这是系统性的歪曲事实，他自己的反应则是愤怒不已：

This is several steps removed from “Chomsky fights dirty,” but where Quine is frustrated by the funhouse mirror Chomsky holds up to his work—stretching his ideas here, squashing them here—and where Skinner simply refused to look, others are enraged. Certainly Lakoff was. He recalls Chomsky’s principal tactic during the “Remarks” lectures as systematic misrepresentation, and his own reaction as furious umbrage:

[在一次讲座中] 他分别讨论了麦考利的论文，并提出了麦考利所反对的论点作为麦考利的立场，他自己提出了麦考利所主张的立场，他说“看看麦考利有多愚蠢。”

[In one lecture] he took up McCawley’s paper on respectively, and he put forth the argument that McCawley was arguing against as McCawley’s position, and he himself put forth the position that McCawley was arguing for, and he said “See how dumb McCawley is.”

在场大约有一百人。我举手说：“不。你搞错了。你搞反了立场。”

There were a hundred people present, or so. And I raised my hand and I said “No. You’ve got it wrong. You’ve got the positions reversed.”

他说：“不，不，我会把文本读给你听。”他断章取义地读了一大堆内容。当然，除了他之外，房间里没有人有文本。我对此感到非常愤怒。

He said “No. No. I’ll read you the text.” And he read a bunch of things out of context. Of course, nobody in the room had the text, except him. I just got furious about this.

接下来的一周，他拿了我的一篇论文，做了同样的事情。他把我特意避免说的立场当作我的立场。然后他正确地反驳了这个立场。我说：“不。我特意没有在论文中提出这个立场。”然后，在我所在的房间里，他开始断章取义我论文中的引文，而其他人都没有这篇论文。这真是令人羞愧。

The following week, he took a paper of mine and did the same thing. He put forth as my position a position I specifically avoided saying. And then he argued, correctly, against this position. And I said “No. I specifically did not give that position in the paper.” Then he began, with me in the room, to take quotes out of context from my own paper, with no one else having the text. It was mortifying.

雷考夫的记忆在这里确实有些模糊和模糊，他运用诗意的笔法来呈现对话，但他的故事的核心才是最重要的：生成语义学家发现乔姆斯基对他们的立场的陈述是故意的、恶意的扭曲，其结果是一系列激烈的争论和持久的怨恨。

Lakoff’s memory is surely blurring and smudging things a bit here, and he has called upon his poetic license to render the dialogue, but it is the kernel in his story that is important: the generative semanticists found Chomsky’s presentation of their positions to be willful, mean-spirited distortions, and the result was a series of heated exchanges, and lasting bitterness.

其他人对这些讲座的记忆略有不同，特别是关于侵略根源的部分：

Others remember the lectures a little differently, particularly about the source of aggression:

• 莱科夫会坐在后排说：“诺姆！诺姆！你错了！你错了！你说的每一句话都是错的！”他基本上就是在惹人厌烦。

• Lakoff would sit in the back row and say “Noam! Noam! You’re wrong! You’re wrong! Everything you say is wrong!” He just basically made a pest of himself.

• 乔姆斯基课程的典型场景是，乔姆斯基讲完一段话，然后非常害羞但很聪明的罗宾（拉科夫）会在乔治耳边低语，然后乔治会举手，以他那种虚伪礼貌的方式发表评论。

• The typical scenario at Chomsky’s course would be that Chomsky would say something, then Robin [Lakoff], who was pathologically shy but smart, would whisper into George’s ear, then George would raise his hand and in his smarmy pseudo-civil way make some comment.

• [Lakoff] 好斗且粗鲁……[他] 会去 Noam 的课堂上，坐在教室前面。有一次 Noam 说了些什么，George 说：“我也说过同样的话。”Noam 问：“你在哪里写的？”George 回答说：“我一直在讲这些事情，如果你感兴趣，你应该来上我的课。”

• [Lakoff] was combatitive and impolite … [He] would go to Noam’s class and sit at the front of the room. One time Noam said something, and George said “I have been saying the same thing.” Noam asked “Where did you write about it?” And George responded “I have been lecturing about these things, and if you are interested, you should come to my class.”

任何人，更不用说初级讲师，如果要让该领域的发明者来上课，就必须有如此的胆量，这简直是厚颜无耻。它也可能完全不符合准确性（虽然可能不是——这并不完全不符合他的性格，而且有几个人报告了同样的事件）；在一系列引语中，一定有一些扭曲，让莱考夫一会儿大喊“你说的都是错的！”，一会儿又变得油腔滑调，坐在房间的后排和前排。而且，这种敌意可能比大多数参与者回忆的更均匀。大多数人倾向于将所有邪恶和误解的责任直接归咎于一方或另一方，很少看到双方的过错。但从所有报道中可以看出两个不变的事实：乔姆斯基对莱考夫过敏，而莱考夫对乔姆斯基咄咄逼人。

The level of gall required for anyone, let alone a junior lecturer, to tell the inventor of the field to attend his classes if he wanted to stay current goes right off the chutzpah meter. It could well go right off the accuracy meter as well (though perhaps not—it is not dreadfully out of character, and several people report the same incident); there have to be some distortions in a collection of quotations that have Lakoff exclaiming “Everything you say is wrong!” one minute and being smarmy the next, sitting in the back row and at the front of the room. And the animosity was probably more evenly distributed than most of the participants recall. Most tend to lay the blame for all evils and misunderstandings squarely on one side or the other, rarely seeing fault with both. But two constants emerge from all the reports: Chomsky was allergic to Lakoff, and Lakoff was pushy with Chomsky.

这次交锋激起了双方的热情。生成语义学家认为乔姆斯基即使不算乖僻，也是难以对付的，因此认为他的大部分批评都是空洞的。乔姆斯基的学生认为他非常通情达理，他的反对意见——大部分是体现在拉科夫身上，他的脾气是最暴躁的，但也体现在罗斯身上，以及像卡登这样零散的同情者身上——即使不是乖僻的，也是难以驾驭的。

The encounters galvanized both sides. The generative semanticists found Chomsky intractable, if not perverse, and consequently felt that much of his criticism was empty. Chomsky’s students found him to be eminently reasonable, and his opposition—mostly embodied in Lakoff, whose fuse was easily the shortest, but also in Ross, and in scattered sympathizers, like Carden—to be intractable, if not perverse.

卡茨也在那里，他在这一切中扮演了一个特别有趣的角色，就像赫伯特·巴特菲尔德所描述的马林·梅森的角色一样，他是现代科学诞生的重要推动者，“一个激发探究、收集结果、挑拨科学家对立、煽动同事争论的人”（1957:83）。卡茨当然做出了自己的宝贵贡献，但他最突出的角色是煽动者，在各方煽风点火。例如，当时的一名学生回忆起他参加乔姆斯基的讲座：“杰里·卡茨非常有争议——不仅仅是关于生成语义解释问题，而是关于各种东西。”他对各种事物都持争议性态度，但卡茨最害怕的是任何威胁到综合理论-方面深层结构概念的分析，他当时称之为“CKP 深层结构论题”（1970:221）——讽刺的是，这是一个恰当的称谓，因为首字母缩写代表Chomsky-Katz-Postal，而卡茨现在在深层结构问题上站在他老盟友的中间。对卡茨来说，乔姆斯基是熊妈妈，其深层结构太浅，而 Postal 是熊爸爸，其深层结构太深。他自己的结构，也就是大家一年前一致同意的结构，是正确的。

Katz was there too, and he played an especially interesting role in all this, one much like the role Herbert Butterfield describes for Marin Mersenne, an important presider at the birth of modern science, “a man who provoked enquiries, collected results, set one scientist against another, and incited his colleagues to controversy” (1957:83). Katz certainly made valuable contributions of his own, but his most prominent role was that of provocateur, fanning the fires on every side. One student of the period, for instance, remembers his participation in Chomsky’s lectures thusly: “Jerry Katz was very contentious—not just about generative semanticsinterpretive issues, about all kinds of stuff.” He was contentious about all kinds of stuff, but Katz’s particular bugaboo was any analysis that threatened the Integrated Theory-Aspects notion of deep structure, what he called at the time, “the CKP thesis about deep structure” (1970:221)—an ironically appropriate designation, since the initials stand for Chomsky-Katz-Postal, and Katz now stood midway between his old allies on the question of deep structure. For Katz, Chomsky was Momma Bear, whose deep structure was too shallow, Postal was Poppa Bear, whose deep structure was too deep. His own, the one everybody had agreed upon only a year ago, was juuust right.

在乔姆斯基的课堂上，捍卫 CKP 论题很大程度上意味着与乔姆斯基作斗争，但在麻省理工学院之外，乔姆斯基对Aspects模型的修改并没有得到非常认真的倾听，主要的反对者是新兴的计划，该计划正式始于发现对“[CKP] 深层结构是否必要？”这个问题的否定答案。卡茨当时的主要辩论文章都是对生成语义学的攻击，尽管他与当时剑桥的总体趋势截然不同，但卡茨对Aspects模型的忠诚使他在敌对行动开始时的核心问题（语义规则的性质）上站在了乔姆斯基的阵营。他是解释语义学旗帜最坚定的支持者之一。

In Chomsky’s class, defending the CKP thesis largely meant fighting Chomsky, but away from MIT Chomsky’s revisions to the Aspects model were not getting a very serious hearing, and the main opposition was the burgeoning program that officially dated itself from the discovery of a negative answer to the question, “Is [the CKP] Deep Structure Necessary?” Katz’s chief polemical writings of the period are all attacks on generative semantics, and, although he differed sharply from the general trend in Cambridge at the time, Katz’s allegiance to the Aspects model put him in Chomsky’s camp on the central issue at the outset of the hostilities, the nature of semantic rules. He was one of the staunchest bearers of the interpretive semantics banner.

乔姆斯基讲座上的摩擦和怨恨为随后几年的争吵定下了基调。有一些激烈的出版物，如雷·多尔蒂（1974 年）的《生成语义学方法：布鲁姆菲尔德式的反革命》，以及卡茨和麦考利之间的交流，标题包括《解释语义学遇见弗兰肯斯坦》（McCawley，1976b [1971]：333-42）和《解释语义学遇见僵尸》（Katz，1972a），但更公然辱骂的论文通常仅限于油印流通——例如《卡米洛特，1968 年》和多尔蒂的《生成语义学：伽利略为你的罪孽而死》，以及一篇匿名模仿杰肯多夫的文章，在这篇文章中，杰肯多夫被描绘成一名攻击犹太人的纳粹科学家。

The friction and rancor at Chomsky’s lectures set the tone for the several years of bickering that followed. There were a few frothing publications, like Ray Dougherty’s (1974) “Generative Semantics Methods: A Bloomfieldian Counterrevolution,” and an exchange between Katz and McCawley that saw titles like “Interpretive Semantics Meets Frankenstein” (McCawley, 1976b [1971]:333–42) and “Interpretive Semantics Meets the Zombies” (Katz, 1972a), but the more blatantly abusive papers were generally confined to mimeograph circulation—“Camelot, 1968,” for instance, and Dougherty’s “Generative Semantics: Galileo Died for Your Sins,” and a best-kept-anonymous parody of Jackendoff, in which he is portrayed as a Nazi scientist attacking a Jew.

出版物中确实有很多争论，但很少是公开的。它通常以两种一般形式之一出现，在外行人看来，这两种形式都不像是争论。一种形式最能代表乔姆斯基对生成语义学的多次攻击——明确反对理论立场或提出的机制，但并没有表现出太多明显的敌意。另一种形式最能代表许多生成语义学论文——例如，Lakoff 的句法融合论文 (1974)。它包含对乔姆斯基语法的两个基础的隐性攻击计划（转换派生和能力-绩效二分法），但除了顺便提及外，没有提及这些问题，甚至没有提及乔姆斯基，甚至似乎没有参与任何形式的争议。14

There was certainly a lot of bickering in the publications, but little of it was overt. It usually took one of two general forms, neither of which look like bickering to the uninitiated. One form is best represented by Chomsky’s many attacks on generative semantics—explicit in its disagreement with theoretical stances or proposed mechanisms, but not betraying much overt hostility. The other form is best represented by many of the generative semantics papers—for instance, Lakoff’s syntactic amalgams paper (1974). It contains implicit attacks on two foundations of the Chomskyan program (transformational derivations and the competence-performance dichotomy), but does not, except in passing, mention either of these issues, or even Chomsky, or, for that matter, even appear to be participating in a controversy of any sort.14

大部分明显的敌意并不在期刊或论文集上。与乔姆斯基对布卢姆菲尔德派的第一轮敌对一样，大部分谩骂都是口头上的。例如，1967 年在拉霍亚举行的一次小型会议上，发生了一次著名的爆发，这可以说是生成语义学的一次亮相派对。杰肯道夫回忆说，他骑马向西，基本上是“作为乔姆斯基的联络人”，生成语义学家对他的看法就像乔姆斯基第一次出现在麻省理工学院时对李斯的看法一样，后者是被派去平息叛乱的枪手。然而，与李斯不同，杰肯道夫并没有改变主意，他们之间发生了许多尖锐的争吵，包括他和另一位著名的乔姆斯基枪手波斯特尔之间大声交换的生动咒骂。几年后，在 1969 年美国语言学会的一次全体会议上，杰肯道夫和拉科夫之间进行了一次同样激烈、甚至更加公开的交流，“当时他们在 200 名尴尬的旁观者面前互相辱骂，辱骂声持续了几分钟”（Newmeyer，1980a:162；1986a:126）。

Most of the explicit enmity was not in journals or proceedings. As in the first round of Chomskyan hostilities, against the Bloomfieldians, the majority of invective was oral. There was, for instance, a celebrated flare-up in 1967 at a small conference in La Jolla which was something of a coming-out party for generative semantics. Jackendoff rode west, as he recalls, essentially “as Chomsky’s point man,” and the generative semanticists regarded him much as Chomsky regarded Lees on his first appearance at MIT, a gunslinger sent to quell the insurrection. Unlike Lees, though, Jackendoff was not converted, and there were a number of shrill exchanges, including the loud swapping of graphic imprecations between him and another renowned Chomskyan gunslinger, Postal. There was an equally vitriolic, and even more public exchange between Jackendoff and Lakoff a few years later, at a plenary session of the 1969 Linguistic Society of America conference, “when for several minutes [they] hurled amplified obscenities at each other before 200 embarrassed onlookers” (Newmeyer, 1980a:162; 1986a:126).

还有更多，更多。当时，甚至接近主流的语言学家都有很多关于个人争执的轶事，无论是在座谈会、求职面试、课堂上，还是偶然的走廊会议中……似乎双方代表接触的地方和时间都有。这些故事的色彩和可信度相当广泛，很难相信其中许多故事是表面上的。它们在复述中变得史诗般：对手的愚蠢、主角的忍耐、争论点的简单和清晰，都肯定被夸大了。一个故事甚至让乔姆斯基和拉科夫为争夺麦克风而展开了肢体搏斗，他们不太可能扮演阿喀琉斯和赫克托尔的角色。

There was more, much more. Every linguist even close to the mainstream at the time has a host of anecdotes about individual firefights, in colloquia, job interviews, classrooms, chance hallway meetings … seemingly wherever and whenever representatives of the two sides came into contact. The stories range quite widely in color and credibility, and it is difficult to take many of them at face value. They have grown epic in the retelling: the stupidity of the antagonists, the forbearance of the protagonists, the simplicity and clarity of the point under dispute, are all surely exaggerated. One account even has Chomsky and Lakoff, very unlikely in the roles of Achilles and Hector, physically wrestling for a microphone.

但总的来说，这些故事具有任何民间传说都具有的普遍文化价值。以一个生成语义学故事的几个版本为例，故事中杰肯多夫（有时是道尔蒂）面对棘手的反对意见，无法独立思考，重击《圣经》等事物，哀怨地吟诵“但诺姆说……”。在分裂的另一边，有一个故事的几个版本，其中有些解释语义学家试图使用抽象语法的荒谬论证（例如，论证是动词），生成语义学家对此深信不疑。（“天哪，是动词。我们必须立即改变理论以适应这个新事实。我今天下午会打电话。”）这些故事的一些近似可能已经发挥作用，但它们的准确性不如它们所揭示的态度重要。生成语义学家认为另一阵营主要由乔姆斯基和他的傀儡组成。解释语义学家认为另一阵营太愿意根据他们在当天午餐时听到的任何少量证据来彻底修改其一般理论。双方都认为对方缺乏批判性，对不言而喻的观点视而不见。

But, in concert, these tales have the general cultural value any body of folklore has. Take the several versions of a generative semantics story which has Jackendoff (or sometimes Dougherty), up against thorny opposition and unable to think for himself, thumping Aspects like the Bible and intoning plaintively “but Noam says …” On the other side of the schism, there are several versions of a story which has some interpretive semanticist attempting to use an argumentum ad absurdum of abstract syntax (say, arguing that the is a verb), which a generative semanticist falls for, hook, line, and theoretical sinker. (“By golly, the is a verb. We’ll have to change the theory right away to accommodate this new fact. I’ll get on the phone this afternoon.”) Some approximations of these stories may have played themselves out, but their accuracy is less important than the attitudes they reveal. The generative semanticists felt that the other camp consisted largely of Chomsky and his puppets. The interpretive semanticists felt the other camp far too willing to overhaul its general theory on whatever scanty evidence they heard over lunch that day. Each side thought the other uncritical and obtuse to self-evident points.

尽管总体上双方的相互容忍度相当低，在个人接触中许多人脾气暴躁，一些人的嘴里还留有持久的怨恨，而且在争论中也出现了明显的伤亡，但值得注意的是，礼貌、友谊和对彼此工作的尊重并非完全缺失。对手。例如，在战争最激烈的时候，波斯特尔将他彻头彻尾的生成语义学著作《论提升》 （1974）献给了乔姆斯基。杰肯多夫在《语义解释》的前言中向生成语义学家致敬，感谢他们激励了他的研究，尽管这种称赞确实暗流涌动——他说，他的许多解释模型“源于我强烈反对他们的工作，并想对此做点什么”（1972:xii）。乔姆斯基本人至少对一些对手的职业生涯给予了不懈的支持，为他们写信，支持罗斯在麻省理工学院的任命和晋升，为珀尔马特做同样的事情，试图让波斯特尔留在那里。麦考利和乔姆斯基就各自的论点进行了热情而相互尊重的通信，尽管几乎没有达成一致。

Although the general level of mutual tolerance was pretty low, and many tempers ran high in individual encounters, and there is lasting bitterness in some mouths, and there are clear casualties of the debate, it is important to note that courtesy, friendship, and respect for one another’s work were not completely absent between antagonists. Postal, for instance, at the height of the wars, dedicated his through-and-through-generative-semantics book, On Raising (1974), to Chomsky. Jackendoff saluted the generative semanticists in the preface to his Semantic Interpretation, for motivating his research, though the compliment does have an undercurrent—he says much of his interpretive model is “due to my being in sufficiently violent disagreement with their work to want to do something about it” (1972:xii). Chomsky himself was unflaggingly supportive for the careers of at least some of his opponents, writing letters on their behalf, supporting Ross’s appointment and advancement at MIT, doing the same for Perlmutter, trying to keep Postal there. McCawley and Chomsky corresponded about their respective arguments, with warmth and mutual respect, albeit with little agreement.

然而，战斗仍在继续，并进入了更公开的论坛，首先是乔姆斯基传统之外的语言学家参与其中，然后是邻近学科的学者。此时，乔姆斯基已经声名鹊起——心理学家和哲学家经常辩论他的工作，他的书受到相当广泛的读者群，《纽约书评》、《地平线》、《时代》、《纽约客》等杂志上都有他的简介和文章，甚至在诺曼·梅勒的《夜之大军》一书中也有他的身影，他还是抗议美国入侵越南的最前线。此外，生成语义学家的兴趣变得非常广泛，借鉴了扎德这样的逻辑学家、格赖斯和塞尔这样的哲学家、罗斯这样的心理学家以及戈夫曼这样的社会学家的工作。他们四处寻找数据和机制来构建他们的理论，并且毫不掩饰他们对乔姆斯基的不满。不可避免地，乔姆斯基框架内的宗派之争引起了广泛的关注。

Still, the battles went on, boiling over into more public forums, first to include linguists outside the Chomskyan tradition, and then to include scholars in neighboring disciplines. Chomsky had acquired a great deal of prominence by this point—psychologists and philosophers routinely debated his work, his books were reaching a fairly broad public, there were profiles and articles in magazines like The New York Review of Books, Horizon, Time, The New Yorker, even an appearance in Norman Mailer’s book The Armies of the Night, and he was at the forefront of protests against the U.S. invasion of Vietnam. Additionally, the generative semanticists became very wide-ranging in their interests, drawing on the work of logicians like Zadeh, philosophers like Grice and Searle, psychologists like Rosch, and sociologists like Goffman. They shopped far and wide for data and mechanisms to build their theory around, and they were never reticent about letting their discontent with Chomsky be known. Inevitably, the sectarian squabble within Chomsky’s framework found a wide audience.
